CANADA
Sir,

I beg to transmit to you a requisition which has been received from the Reverend Sister Gabriel, Principal of the Sechelt Indian Boarding School, and would inform you that during a recent visit to that institution I was requested to bring this requisition to the attention of the Department, with a request that the things asked for in the requisition be granted, if it is the pleasure of the Department to do so. As I am new to this territory, I do not know if any precedent exists in connection with these extraordinary supplies, but if they can be furnished, I would recommend that the assistance asked for be given.

Your obedient servant,

C.C. Perry,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, March 31, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing a requisition from the Rev. Sister Gabriel, Principal of the Sechelt Indian Boarding School. I have noted the request for a crosscut saw and bed spreads. It is the Department's wish that this equipment be purchased from per capita grant or other school funds. Relative to the need for linoleum in the staff dining-room, I should be pleased to have a report from you, following the occasion of your next visit to the school.

I note that the Rev. Principal is asking for a milch cow and states that there are but two old animals on hand. Mr. Inspector Cairns' report, dated January 4th, last, mentions that there are five cows at the school. The Department is of the opinion that even this number of milch cows will not give more milk than is required for the use of the children, pupils and the staff. Mr. Inspector Cairns reports that the pupils do not receive much whole milk and he strongly advises that, when the milk supply is limited, butter be purchased for the staff.

I have to inform you that it is the Department's practice to arrange for a sufficient quantity of stock at the time a school is commenced. The natural increase in the stock should relieve us of any further financial outlay. There should be sufficient young animals for milking purposes and also for butchering. If, however, the stock at the Sechelt Boarding school is so depleted that the Department will have to come to the help of the authorities, I should be pleased to have your recommendation.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

C. G. Perry, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Room 401, Holden Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
Sechelt, B.C., March 22, 1927.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Second Report of Progress, on Bungalow for Chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

Dear Sir:

This building is now ready for the plaster, the rough plumbing, and electrical wiring is in place, and supplies for plastering are on the ground.

The outside of the building is ready for the painter with the exception of entrance steps and a little casing and trim.

I note that the contractors have used 5-x shingles throughout although specification only called for 3-x this gives a much better job as shingles are heavier.

At present there are only two carpenters employed on the work.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.

Ref. No. 153-1-5B

With reference to Filter Basin, for new school here

Dear Sir:

Acting on instructions contained in your letter of January 30, the filter basin has been constructed as outlined by you, the same has been completed and in operation for some time, and is working satisfactorily.

As one hundred and thirty cubic yards of rock were required for the filling of pit, and the only horses available here are owned by Johnson Bros., the contractors for bungalow for chaplain of school I employed them at the rate of $10.00 per day of eight hours for team and teamster, and as one horse was used to a great extent in excavating I arranged with them to furnish same at $7.50 per day. Johnson Bros. also have in their employ an experienced man on sewer construction, this man they let me have at the same rate that they pay him namely $5.00 per day. Sergeant is a local man used in loading rock, and helping with excavation, and was paid the usual rate for unskilled work 45¢ per hour.

I enclose herewith time slips or accounts from Johnson Bros. and N. Sergeant, in duplicate and certified, this is the total cost of filter basin, except three days time and timekeeping and inspection by me.

I have carefully checked these time slips with the time book kept by me and find them correct.

Yours faithfully,

Arthur W. Webb,
Inspector of Construction.
Sechelt, B. C. April 12, 1923.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Enclosed please find Voucher No. 16 in duplicate. This with the two accounts sent to you on the 9th instant includes all costs of the new filter basin.

Re Bungalow for Chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

Dear Sir:

As the electric lighting fixtures for the said bungalow are to be furnished by the Department and put in place by the contractor, see page 23 of specifications, I would suggest that a sum not to exceed, say twenty-five or thirty dollars be allowed for this purpose, allowing the Chaplain of school to make his own selection, should fixtures selected cost less than the amount allowed, only cost to be borne by the Department, but should fixtures selected cost more than the amount allowed the additional cost to be borne by the chaplain.

I make the above recommendation as these fixtures will be needed in about two weeks' time, and the above plan will save delay.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Inspector of Construction.

Dear Sir:

I wish to report that this building is now practically complete there remains only the setting up of the furnace, and plumbing fixtures, and a portion of the painting to be finished.

All fixtures and goods to complete the contract are on hand so there is no reason to suppose that everything will not be completed before the end of the present month.

The contractors have done a good job, and the building has a nice appearance, the colors used on outside of building are, shingles of basement walls, slate gray, the siding cream, with white trimings and green roof which matches that of the school building.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of March 31st, last, No. I67-18-5, in connection with the requisition of Rev. Sister Gabriel, of the Sechelt Boarding School, for 45 plain bed spreads and a square of linoleum for the Staff dining room, I beg to say that I have since made two visits to this School. It was decided that the Principal, upon visiting Vancouver, would select a suitable pattern for the linoleum required. This has been duly carried into effect, and I have pleasure in enclosing a sample priced at $1.05 per yard (square). Sales 5 (reference). Other linoleums looked at were priced higher in the various stores. I would recommend that authority be given for the purchase of a piece of linoleum size 16 feet by 14½. The staff dining room is barren looking with a composition floor and the linoleum is needed.

The bed spreads are also needed as the beds are covered with blankets only at the present time. I would recommend the purchase of 45 medium quality spreads.

The matter of the cows is held in abeyance at the request of Mr. School Inspector Cairns, who desires to revisit the school and make a further report thereon. He expects to visit Sechelt soon.

Your obedient servant,

C.C. Perry,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, July 21, 1923.

Sir:

I have your No. 1-2-8 of the 14th instant, with reference to the need for linoleum at the Sechelt Indian Boarding School. In reply I beg to state you are authorized to purchase a piece 16' x 14½' for the staff dining room. The sample is being returned.

As you were informed in official communication of March 31st, last, the Department considers that the bed spread should be purchased from the per capita grant. I have noted that the matter of milk supply will be given special attention by Mr. Inspector Cairns, upon the occasion of his next visit to the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

G. C. Perry, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Vancouver, B. C.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed please find the final Certificate for the construction of bungalow for the chaplain of Sechelt Indian Boarding School.

The materials furnished, have been No. 1 in quality and the workmanship good. The Pipeless Furnace was made by Fawcett and works splendidly.

The building is homelike and cozy, has a nice appearance, and an unobstructed view of Trail Bay, and a considerable portion of the Gulf of Georgia, and Vancouver Island.

I enclose a small snap of bungalow herewith.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Sir:

Re—Water Supply for Indian Boarding School and Village at Sechelt, B.C.

With reference to my report dated May 4th, 1923, I beg to submit the following supplementary report.

In accordance with the request of the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, I returned to Sechelt on August 14th and spent three days investigating the possibilities of increasing the present water supply to meet the present and future requirements of the Indian Boarding School and Village.

Summary of Investigation

By enlarging and extending the water works system an adequate supply of water may be obtained for the irrigation of 15 acres of school land, in addition to requirements for domestic and fire protection purposes throughout the year.

The estimated cost of a complete system as herein proposed would amount to approximately $9,000.00.
Available Sources of Supply

As previously reported the present supply is obtained from a small stream flowing through Lot 2465. This stream was examined to its source on the mountain side where it is fed by springs. A measurement taken above the swamp and about a quarter of a mile above the present intake showed the discharge to be 0.17 c.f.s., about 90,000 gallons per day. This measurement was made after an unusually long period of dry weather and should, therefore, represent as low a flow as may normally be expected.

Although the flow from these springs would be ample for the immediate requirements of the school and village, it would not be sufficient for the irrigation of additional land for school purposes as contemplated by the Department of Indian Affairs.

It was found possible to augment the flow from springs by diverting water from a stream, about one mile to the north, which flows westerly and drains into Porpoise Bay. The bed of this stream is strewn with boulders and bears every indication of carrying an abundant supply of water at all but the driest period of the year and for this reason I was fortunate in finding the stream at a very low stage. At the time of inspection the discharge amounted to 0.3 c.f.s. (about 150,000 gallons per day).

The two sources, at low stage, would provide a combined flow of 250,000 gallons per day.

Water Requirements

At the present time, the school has an area of four acres under cultivation, and it is considered essential that this area should be increased to fifteen acres. The Department has agreed to set aside additional land and further development is dependent on an irrigation supply of water.
On inspection of this land I found the soil to be very sandy, similar to that under cultivation, and for this reason provision has been made for a quantity of thirty acre-feet of water to be applied to the land during July and August. The following is a revised estimate of water requirements:

| Domestic          | No. persons | Gallons per day |
|-------------------|-------------|-----------------|
| Boarding School   | 100         | 10,000          |
| Indian Village    | 100         | 10,000          |

Irrigation

15 acres @ 2 acre feet per ac. in 60 days, 156,000.

Total........... 156,000 gallons.

The quantity of water available from the two sources mentioned provides a fairly safe margin of nearly 100,000 gallons per day to cover possible losses during the driest period of the year.

Proposed enlargement and extension of present system

An efficient system capable of carrying a maximum quantity of 275,000 Imperial gallons per day, which is 119,000 gallons in excess of estimated requirements, would necessitate the construction of the following works:

1. A new diversion (North of the present system) consisting of a small concrete intake and 2000 feet of wood stave pipe, four inches in diameter, to carry the water to a ravine which drains naturally to the springs below. Under a head of forty feet available in this distance, the capacity of the pipe would be 185,000 Imperial gallons per day. The discharge, however, should be controlled by installing an iron body straight-way gate valve at the intake.

Note: A ditch to carry this quantity of water is not feasible owing to the porous nature of the ground to be
traversed. The line of the proposed diversion lies along timbered, rocky sidehill, which slopes towards the pond and drains into the creek to the North, as shown on accompanying plan.

Many years ago, an attempt was made by the Indians, to dam the pond at the outlet, the object being to divert water from the stream into the pond, raise the water level, and re-divert water through an open ditch into the ravine leading to their present source of supply. The attempt was unsuccessful owing to the failure of a crudely constructed dam, and there is now a deep washout at what would otherwise have been a good damsite.

2. A new intake at a point about 1040 feet upstream from the intake of the present system. At this location water may be diverted into the supply line from the clean gravel bed of the stream instead of from the swamp as at present. Details of concrete tank with intake, spillway, screens, etc. are shown on accompanying sketch.

3. New supply line consisting of approximately 10,300 feet of wood stave pipe, four inches in diameter, to take the place of the two inch pipe now used. The available head in this distance, based on levels taken by Mr. Morley, Superintendent of Works for the Department of Indian Affairs, is 414 feet, which would make the maximum carrying capacity of the pipe 275,000 Imperial gallons per day. A standard four inch Gate Valve should be installed in the pipe line near the intake to control the discharge.

4. Concrete distributing tank, at the end of the four inch main, to take the place of the wooden tank previously described under "Works" and designated "C". By means of this tank the water supply may be permanently divided for three separate services:-
(a) Domestic and Fire Protection—Indian Boarding School.
(b) Domestic—Indian Village.
(c) Irrigation—Indian Boarding School.

On the accompanying plan it will be noted, from the relative positions of the two service pipes and spillway, that consideration has been given to the services in the order named. Should any temporary shortage occur, through obstructions at the intake or leakage in the main pipe line, the irrigation supply would first be affected, and in an emergency the school pipe would draw from the entire supply available.

The distributing tank should be so installed that the elevation of the spillway will be one foot below the top of the Wood Stave storage tank. By doing so the storage tank will be kept full (within one foot of the top) but will not overflow.

5. Irrigation supply line from distributing tank to school land, consisting of approximately 2,500 feet of wood stave pipe, four inches in diameter. This pipe will have a fall of about 100 feet in 1000 feet and a capacity greater than that of the main supply line.

A small concrete surge-tank should be installed at the end of this pipe line, and a flume to convey water for distribution on land.

6. Domestic and fire protection line from distributing tank to school. At present the wood stave storage tank is fed by a wrought iron pipe, one and a half inches diameter, and is drained by a three inch wood stave pipe, reduced to one and a half inch wrought iron pipe. The rate of flow into the tank when empty is only 23 Imperial gallons per minute and the pipe, draining the tank, has a capacity of 42 gallons per minute.
By laying a three inch diameter W. I. pipe from the distributing tank to the storage tank, a distance of 100 feet, a continuous supply of 42 gallons per minute could be maintained indefinitely.

If it is desired to further increase the capacity of this line for the development of power for lighting purposes, a three inch diameter wood stave pipe continued to the school would deliver 145 gallons per minute. After deducting domestic requirements this quantity, under the available head of 290 feet, would develop eight and a half net horse-power on water-wheel at the school buildings.

The system would carry an adequate supply for a twenty-four hour day development during ten months of the year. During the remaining two months, July and August, a plant could operate eight hours during the night by drawing from the irrigation supply.

Repairs to the village supply line can be made by removing damaged sections and replacing with newer pipe from the present two inch main from the springs.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

The Sechelt Indian Residential School, in British Columbia, has lost during the past year or two some of its popularity with the Indian communities. Investigations have revealed the fact that a change in the management is desirable. The Sisters who have been in charge and the Provincial of the Oblate Order are agreed that the appointment of a resident priest as principal is desirable. Changes are being made in the instruction offered; and the institution is placed in the Industrial School class and will receive a larger per capita grant. The preparation of a larger garden is imperative and I shall be pleased to have your authority to allow a grant of $1,000 for clearing purposes. The work will be performed under the supervision of the Indian agent. A small boat with an engine is required for the supplying of fish, which are not to be found in the waters immediately in front of the school, and will be useful in the training of the older boys in the handling of marine boats and engines. It is estimated that $600 will secure suitable equipment.

I shall be pleased to have your authority to authorize this expense. Funds are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.
January 9, 1924.

Dear Mr. Perry:

I have examined the letter of Mr. Inspector Cairns and yourself which recommends certain changes at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and I have also been in correspondence with the Sister Superior and the Very Rev. Father Weigh. I am pleased to inform you that arrangements have been made to allow a per capita grant of $170 for this institution. I have also arranged for the Oblate Fathers to assume the responsibility for the management, and the temporary appointment of Rev. Father Anthony Sadowski, O.M.I., has been approved.

You are authorized to purchase a small gasoline boat for the use of the Sechelt Indian Residential School. This equipment should be used not only for fishing activity but for the training of the boys. You should secure competitive prices from the best local sources of supply, and when presenting the voucher in favour of the firm given the business, you should support it with either an abstract of tender form or a complete explanation of the manner in which the business was awarded. Your estimate of $600 should be a guide to you in this connection.

Please arrange at an early date for clearing operations on land at the school which can be used later for gardening. You should secure as foreman for this work someone who is qualified to use a shovel, and you would be well advised to engage members of the Indian Band for the rough labour. If it is advisable to use the older boys at the school for some of this work, please instruct the foreman you engage to take precautionary measures to see that they receive no injury.

You may arrange for the rental of the 2-1/2 acres at Saycokas Reserve No. 3, which is owned by Dan Paul. The Department will allow a special grant of $25 per acre per annum for three years. You should secure the concurrence of the new Principal before making the arrangements for this land.

I am instructing the new Principal to make organized efforts at vocational training for both the boys and girls, and you should give this your hearty support and cooperation upon the occasion of your visits to the Institution.

I am sending Mr. Inspector Cairns a copy of this communication.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS Ottawa, Jan. 18, 1924.

CANADA

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

A report has been submitted by the Dominion Water Power Branch upon the proposed addition to the existing water supply system at Sechelt, B.C., in accordance with your instructions given them on the 14th of August last.

The work as projected is intended, as you know, to improve and increase the output of the present water work supply, and to provide a further supply of water to irrigate fifteen acres of school land, in addition to the requirements for domestic and fire protection purposes of both the Indian Boarding School and the village of Sechelt throughout the dryest season of the year. The work would consist principally in diverting the water from a stream in order to augment the flow of the existing spring, thus providing a combined flow of 250,000 gallons per day, which would represent an increase of 100,000 gallons over the quantity of water required for domestic and irrigation purposes. The present water pipe line would mostly have to be replaced by a new wood stave pipe of larger diameter provided with the necessary valves and other supply regulating appliances. New concrete intake and distributing tanks would have to be installed to replace the wooden ones, thus providing three separate services, one for domestic and fire protection of the Indian Boarding School, a second one for the water supply to the Indian Village, and a third one which would insure a reliable irrigation system for the land intended to be placed under cultivation at the Indian Boarding School.

In view of the location of the distributing tank and the pressure available sufficient power (6H.P.) would be developed during a period of ten months to provide for an electric lighting system at the school building. The estimated cost of the above mentioned work would amount to $9,854.00.

Before recommending the granting of such an expenditure I would suggest that Commissioner Ditchburn be requested to advise the Department whether the above mentioned improvements are absolutely necessary, also whether the present requirements of this institution warrant the immediate consideration of this proposal.

Departmental Engineer.

Sir:

In accordance with instructions contained in your letter dated 10th March, regarding an inspection and report covering the water works system at Sechelt, as requested by Mr. J. D. McLean in his letter to Mr. J. B. Challies dated 27th February, I beg to submit the following:

Accompanied by Indian Agent C. C. Terry I proceeded to Sechelt on the 16th March and spent three days investigating the present system and source of supply, also the proposed extension of the present system to Wilson Creek.

Present Source of Supply.

The present supply is obtained from a small stream, which is probably fed by springs and surface water and is diverted at a point on Lot 2465 about two-and-a-half miles in a northeasterly direction from the Indian village. During ten months of the year an adequate supply is available to meet all requirements of the village and Indian Boarding School on the Reserve but during the remaining two months the quantity available is doubtful.

At the time of my visit fully one cubic foot per second was flowing to waste about half of which found its way to Porpoise Bay and the remainder was distributed over a swampy area near the intake, eventually seeping into the ground.

In contrast to the abundance of water at this season of the year Mr. Tebbes, Superintendent of Works at the School, informed me that during the dry season the quantity carried by the present pipe line amounted to only 17½ gallons per minute by actual measurement. It is not known whether the total available flow during the dry period is carried by existing works or whether a portion of the flow is lost above the intake in the swampy ground. As this information is of prime importance in considering the adequacy of the present source of supply, a series of measurements should be made to determine the quantity of water available in the stream bed above the intake as compared with the quantity flowing through the system.

The watershed above the intake is timbered and has
been cruised for timber quantities. Should this area be denuded of timber it is probable that the water supply would be affected to some extent during the dry period by increased evaporation.

No natural storage sites are known to be available but the possibilities would not be overlooked when a further examination of the creek is made during the dry season.

Present Supply System.

About twenty-eight years ago the Indians constructed an open box flume from the present intake to a wooden tank or trough set in the ground at point "C" on sketch plan, a distance of approximately two miles. In 1910 this flume was replaced by a two-inch wood stave pipe which is now in use.

Following is a detailed description of works with references to accompanying sketch.

WORKS

"A"...........Headworks consisting of a short length of flume with a crudely made screen of tin plate through which the water flows to a small wooden tank, thence into a two-inch wood stave pipe.

"A" to "B"...Two-inch wood stave pipe approximately 8,000 feet in length with a fall of about 160 feet in this distance (or 22 feet in 1,000 feet).

"B"...........Wooden trough sunk into ground with cover of loose planks, fitted with screen to arrest leaves and debris.

"B" to "C"...Two inch wood stave pipe approximately 2,500 feet in length with fall of about 225 feet (or 87 feet in 1,000 ft).

"C"...........Wooden trough or tank sunk into ground and covered by loose planks.

NOTE: An iron Y connection is fitted to the two-inch wood stave supply pipe at this point to divide the flow between the Boarding School and the Indian Village. Two one-and-a-half inch wrought iron pipes are fitted to this connection, one discharges directly into the trough and the other is carried through the trough to discharge into the circular storage tank for the school supply.

"D"...........Circular wood stave storage tank twelve feet in diameter ten feet high—capacity 7,000 Imperial Gallons. This tank was so installed that the top would be at the same elevation as the water level in trough "C". By a simple adjustment of the Y, that is, by raising or lowering the short length of pipe which discharges into "C", the flow to the School or village may be increased or decreased as necessity may require.

"C" to "E" to "F"...Two-inch wood stave pipe at present supplying Indian village through a number of half-inch iron stand pipes.

"D" to "E"...Three-inch wood stave pipe, length 1750 feet.
fall 214 feet (or 122.3 feet in 1,000 feet).

"E" to "G".... Wrought iron pipe 1½" diameter, length 1,000 feet to Indian Boarding School.

The building is equipped with four hydrants for fire protection, three of which are within the building. They are connected to a two-inch stand pipe and are fitted with 1½ inch hose and connections with 3/8 inch nozzles.

The hydrant outside the building is not provided with hose.

It will be noted that the carrying capacity of the supply line is limited to the capacity of the first section of pipe from "A" to "B". This section is under a low head of 32 feet in 1,000 feet and is capable of delivering a maximum quantity of 26½ Imperial gallons per minute or 28,160 gallons in twenty-four hours.

With certain exceptions the works appear to be in good condition and can be made to function properly if improvements are warranted by the available supply of water at the source.

Water Requirements.

The heaviest demands upon the system unfortunately occur during the low water period so that requirements for both domestic and irrigation purposes must be considered, in addition to providing an emergency supply for fire protection.

The following figures are based on domestic requirements at 50 Imperial gallons per person per day and irrigation requirements at one acre foot per acre in sixty days which should be ample.

| Domestic          | No. persons | Gallons per day |
|-------------------|-------------|-----------------|
| Boarding School   | 100         | 5,000           |
| Indian Village    | 100         | 5,000           |
| Irrigation Present acreage | 4 acres | 18,000          |

Total........... 28,000

No discharge data is available at the present time on which to determine the average quantity of water carried through the system during the dry period, but for the purpose of comparison I again quote Mr. Tebb's figures of 17½ gallons per minute. This would give a flow of 25,500 gallons per day or very nearly the estimated requirements.

The domestic requirements amounting to 10,000 gallons would be drawn say within a period of twelve hours. It will therefore be apparent that irrigation, which is practised by a sprinkling system, must be carried on during the remaining twelve hours.

From the foregoing it would appear that if the supply can be augmented by eliminating possible losses above the intake, there should be no shortage excepting that which is caused by waste.
Shortage in the past has been due, in part, to the unreasonable waste of water by Indians at the village who have a habit of allowing pipes to discharge freely into barrels for the purpose of soaking or cleaning fish, etc. This practice should be stopped at least during the period of low water. Another and most important cause of shortage is the extension of the pipe line from the Indian village to supply the Whitaker interests.

The extension of the pipe line was installed by Mr. Whitaker under a verbal agreement with the Indians, whereby Mr. Whitaker was permitted to obtain water from the system in consideration of the sum of $200.00 per annum, which was to be expended on the upkeep and maintenance of the Catholic church on the Indian reserve.

The Whitaker interests referred to, comprise a hotel and annex, general store, number of dwellings continuously occupied, and a number of cottages occupied during the summer season; at the present time 22 persons on the Sechelt Reserve depend on the system for domestic supply, and draw water from the extension installed by Mr. Whitaker.

It will thus be apparent that the total demands upon the system, under existing conditions, exceed the supply during the dry season and it will therefore be imperative that the supply to the Whitaker interests be cut off.

Apart from the consideration of shortage the unauthorized delivery of water to other than a licensee is illegal. Mr. Whitaker is not a licensee and the Department of Indian Affairs does not hold a license for conveying purpose consequently the delivery of water to Mr. Whitaker is an offence against the B.C. Water Act 1914. (See Section 47 sub-section 6)

On the other hand Mr. Whitaker has not been authorized, either by license or by the Department, to take water from the system, therefore diversion on his part is unlawful and he is liable to the penalty provided under Section 47, sub-section 2 of the Water Act.

Recorded Rights.

Two records have been granted in favour of the Department authorizing diversion of water from the present source of supply:

W.R.No.123—dated 20th September, 1906—10 miners inches

W.R.No.179—dated 17th April, 1907——-10 Miners inches

(No water rights have been granted to other users).

These records were granted under the "Water Clauses Consolidation Act, 1897". Under Section 35 of this Act, the approval of the Lieutenant Governor in Council was necessary before a record could be authorized for the benefit of all or any Indians located on any Indian reserve in the Province.

Water Record No.123 was confirmed by Order-in-Council in 1908 but W.R.No.179 has not been confirmed. The Board of Investigation has not yet adjudicated upon these records, although there is no doubt that a Conditional licence will be issued to supersede W.R.No.123 the status of W.R.179 is doubtful.

In any case the record dated 20th September, 1906, is sufficient to cover the present requirements, ten miners inches being equivalent to 150,000 gallons per day.
The storage tank described under "Works" and designated "D" was intended to provide an emergency supply for fire protection. On inspection the tank was found to contain about 2½ feet of water and I was informed that the tank had never been filled, though filled varying from about one to three feet. I adjusted the "Y" connection at "C" so that the tank filled to within three inches of the top in less than four hours. The tank when full automatically shuts off the inflow as the top of the tank is the same elevation as the water in trough "G". As the water level in the tank is drawn down the difference in elevation between "C" and "D" is increased so that with an empty tank the inflow would be greatest, gradually decreasing as the tank fills. It follows that when the tank is full the whole flow from the main supply pipe is available for use in the village.

The present adjustment of the "Y" should work satisfactorily, and will ensure a reserve supply of 7,000 Imperial gallons for the school without affecting the village supply to any appreciable extent.

The pipe from the tank to the school is capable of delivering about forty-two Imperial gallons per minute so that with an average inflow of say ten gallons per minute while the tank is emptying, the reserve supply (during the dry period) should last 3½ hours in an emergency.

Wilson Creek.

This stream carries an abundant supply of water during the low-water period and would be a most desirable source of supply if a system could be installed at reasonable cost.

Many years ago, the Indians constructed a flume and ditch line from Wilson Creek to the reserve but failed to get water on account of seepage losses in porous ground. Parts of the old ditch were inspected, also sections of flume built of hollowed cedar which bear evidence of the industry of a past generation. The route of this old ditch lies along steep and heavily timbered side-hill and probably follows the best location obtainable (although no levels were taken) but since it was built two deep gulches have been formed by washouts which would materially add to the cost of a new system.

Headworks would have to be substantially built to obtain water at the lowest stage of the stream and withstand the pressure of high water. Both above and below the location of the old Indian intake the creek flows through a rock canyon, deep and narrow in places, with wider stretches strewn with large boulders. The nature of headworks required and the cost of constructing same could only be determined after making a detailed survey. That is to say, the type of dam would depend on the nature and contour of the...
stream-bed and banks at the particular site selected for construction, and this could only be determined after running a grade line for the system.

The lack of transportation facilities for delivering materials and supplies onto the ground would also add considerably to the cost of the proposed scheme.

From the foregoing examination we would estimate the cost of constructing a system from Wilson Creek, including concrete dam and headworks, the laying of a six-inch wood stave pipe, treestling over gulches etc., at from $12,000.00 to $15,000.00. This estimate might be reduced according to the suitability of the dam-site and any natural advantages which might be presented should a more detailed investigation be made.

A survey of a proposed water supply system from Wilson Creek was made in 1914 by Messrs. Cleveland and Cameron (consulting engineers) for the Canadian European Investment Company. Notes and plans of this survey are now in possession of Messrs. Heming & Horie, Consulting Engineers, 106 London Building, Vancouver, B.C.

The Canadian European Investment Company was composed principally of Germans and, after the outbreak of war, their interests reverted to the Whiteaker interests of Sechelt.

A project from Wilson Creek to supply the combined interests of the Sechelt townsite, Sechelt Indian Reserve, Union Steamship Company and smaller private interests has been mooted for some time. As Mr. Whiteaker is perhaps the most vitally interested, and as he has complained of the inadequacy of the Indian system and source of supply, the Department might be well advised to allow him to take the initiative in providing plans and estimates or costs of the proposed system. The Department could then accept or reject any offer for delivery of water on its merits. In other words, it would devolve upon Mr. Whiteaker to offer the Department something better than it now has installed.

Conclusions.

(1)- The source of supply now used is adequate to meet the requirements of the Indians of Sechelt Indian Reserve No.8 and the Sechelt Indian Boarding School for ten months in the year. During the remaining two months the supply does not fall far short of present demands and it is considered possible to sufficiently augment the flow so as to provide an adequate supply throughout the year.

(2)- In order that the Indians and the Boarding School should enjoy the benefit of recorded rights, from a source that is barely sufficient for their needs, the unlawful diversion of water from this system should be stopped.

(3)- Owing to the heavy cost of constructing a system from Wilson Creek the Department would be well advised to withhold consideration of the project until the adequacy of the present source of supply, during the dry season, is determined.
Recommendations.

(1) That the supply of water from the present system to the Whitaker interests be cut off before June 15th.

(2) That a further examination of the source of supply be made during the dry period with the view of eliminating possible losses or augmenting the supply by storage or diversion from any other source which may be found to be available.

(3) That in the meantime no action be taken with regard to the Wilson Creek project.

Your obedient servant,

"M. Balle",
Assistant Engineer.

R. G. Swan Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power Branch,
Vancouver, B.C.

Sir:

Replying to your telegram of the 8th instant, regarding the blasting required for clearing purposes on the land at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, I beg to confirm the following night letter of yesterday's date:

"Reference your night letter 8th instant. You may engage white labour for blasting at Sechelt School. Do not award contract. Purchase necessary material yourself and engage foreman and other labour by the day."

It was considered that it would be more satisfactory to have this work done by day labour, and as you stated that Indian labour was unsatisfactory, the Department therefore approved of white labour only being employed under the charge of a competent foreman. It will be necessary for you to keep time sheets, in duplicate, of the labour employed. These sheets should contain the name of the foreman, as well as the names of the men employed, also the hours worked and the salary paid, and should be signed by the individual men employed, and forwarded to the Department for payment. You, yourself, should arrange for the purchase of any materials required. SIR:

Replying to your letter of the 1st February in which you refer to the installation of an extensive water system for the Sechelt Indian School as proposed by the Engineers of the Dominion Water Power Branch, at Vancouver, at an estimated cost of $9,854.00, I beg to say that the scheme as suggested by Assistant Engineer Balls is to provide a greater supply for domestic purposes as well as for irrigation, if necessary, of fifteen acres of land for garden purposes.

As this area has not yet been cleared of the timber and stumps it has not been ascertained as to whether the land will have to be irrigated, though it has generally been thought it will owing to land in the vicinity being of a dry sandy character, capable of cultivation if watered for at least two months in the summer. The fifteen acres spoken of cannot, however, be cultivated during the coming season and it would, therefore, be advisable that the proposed enlargement of the present supply be held over till next year, when the Department will be in a better position to know just how much water is needed.

Massey-Harris Grub Breaker

The Massey-Harris 22-inch Grub Breaker is built for Horse or Engine plowing in extra heavy, rooty land. It will cut through any size roots likely to be encountered, and has done good work in reclaiming land that was untillable owing to the tangled growth of scrub and young trees.

The construction is very strong throughout as will be seen from the illustration. Beam is re-inforced with Steel Straps both top and bottom, and is further strengthened by the Plate of Steel on the right hand side at the Standard. Standard is mortised into the Beam. Board and Share are Solid Steel, not too highly tempered so as not to break. Runner on land side of Beam protects when transporting.

Coulter being fitted onto the Nose of the Share acts as a further brace between Plow Bottom and Beam, and also saves the point of Share from catching in or under anything. If the Coulter should be found to be leading the Plow, which fact is indicated by Plow winging over or climbing, then wedge the Coulter to or from the land as the case may be. This is worth knowing. The Heel Piece on the landside serves to keep the Plow away from wall of furrow and thus reduce landside friction.

The Improved Forecarriage ensures steady running and makes plowing easy. It is all Steel; Wheels have 3-inch Tires and Dust-Proof Bearings.

The two Steel Levers regulate the depth, level the Plow, and raise it from the ground.

Shipped as illustrated, with two Steel Wrenches.

A Great Plow for Cleaning Bush or Rooty Land.
I beg to inform you that during a recent visit to the Sechelt Indian Boarding School, for the purpose of inspecting the blasting and clearing of an additional area to the cultivable area of the school property, I found that three and a half acres of land had been blasted of all stumps and cleared sufficiently to admit of the use of a strong plough for purposes of breaking the said area. The principal, Rev. Father A. Swenceski, furnished me with page No. 69, of the Massey Harris Company's Implement catalog, upon which is illustrated the Massey Harris grub breaker, which he has found in his considerable experience to be of great advantage in bringing the area referred to into condition for working during the present season. It is likely that potatoes will be planted for the first season on some portion and clover on another portion.

I have telephoned to the Massey Harris Company and have ascertained that the price of this implement will be $131.00, delivered at Sechelt. I am submitting herewith the catalog page referred to. The Reverend Principal has asked me to request the Department to be good enough to supply this plough for the benefit of the Sechelt School, and he states that this plough in particular has been selected by him as being likely to do more work than the ordinary furrow plough, as it is possible that in the future additional areas of new land may be cleared and this style of plough is considered more efficacious in dealing with land in which there is a great deal of brush and roots, as is the case at Sechelt.

Sir,

I have the honour to transmit herewith Voucher No.774, in my favour for the sum of $156.35 paid as wages connection with the clearing and blasting at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, as authorized by the Department, together with duplicates returns of labour for the weeks ending April 12th, April 19th and April the 26th, ultimo., together with a statement also in duplicate showing how this balance is arrived at. I have pleasure in informing the Department that about three and a half acres of land that will be good when irrigated have been cleared in the immediate vicinity of the school, some of which is being put under cultivation immediately and will relieve the Department of the necessity of leasing a portion of the No.3 Reserve in Torpoise Bay from Indian Dan Paul, which action had been contemplated and which was authorized by the Department. In discussing this matter with the principal, Rev. Father Swenceaski, it was agreed that the leasing of Dan Paul's improvements would not now be necessary. The Department will be aware that it was decided to spend the sum of $1000.00 in the clearing of additional land. The cost of labour to date has been $714.75 and tools, explosives, wharfage, freight and sundries total $211.82, making in all $926.57.

In view of the fact that a plough has been requisitioned which will cost in the neighbourhood of $100 or more dollars, I have stopped work on this project, for the time being. I think it would be advisable, however, to carry out more blasting and clearing in the near future. The area set apart for the school grounds is, I understand fifteen acres and the greater part of this area is under wood; the timber therein being suitable for school fuel and not strictly merchantable in character.

Very appreciable strides have been taken in the matter of improvements in the grounds surrounding the school. The Reverend Principal, and his able staff having done a great deal of valuable work such as fencing.

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that a request has been made by the Reverend Father Wenceski, Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School, that the Department supply him with a stump puller as described in the attached portion of a catalog showing a machine known as the Kirstin Model 137, double power 4" main cable. The cost of this puller which is sold by Mark Dumond, Wholesale and Retail Hardware dealer at Vancouver, is $218.10.

In this connection the Department will be aware that an additional area to the cultivable land surrounding the school was cleared during the spring of the present year. One and a half acres of this land is being placed under immediate cultivation and it was expected when the blasting was completed that the stumps covering an additional two acres which had been blasted but not cleared could be removed by means of a horse team. While a large number of the broken stumps have been removed with the school tools there are numerous stumps on this plot which cannot be removed by the horses, but which would have to be pulled out with a stump puller or else blasted again. The Reverend Principal states that if he is supplied with a stump puller he will be able to remove the present obstructions as well as having the machine for the clearing of further areas within the fifteen acre school grounds as time goes on.

I am in accord with the views of the Reverend Principal and would recommend that if the Department is able to do so this school be provided with a suitable stump puller, preferably the one which has been selected by the Principal.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Oct.17th, No.167-18-5 with which you re-enclosed Voucher No.1002 for $216.00, in favour of Mark Diamond for a stump puller in connection with the Sechelt Residential School farming operations.

In reply to your request for an explanation as to why purchase of this stump puller was made at the price quoted—namely $216.00—by Mr. Mark Diamond, I beg to inform you that when making requisition for this machine the Department was informed that the Reverend Principal of the School had requested a stump puller of the Kirstin type which is especially adapted for efficient work and in reply the Department on August 2nd stated in its letter that it understood that the expenditure in this connection would be approximately $218.00. In view of the foregoing and in view of the fact that the stump pullers offered by the other firms at a cheaper price were not of the type desired for this school, also in view of the fact that the remarks column in the sample copy of tender abstract prepared for the guidance of those making purchases for the Department makes provision for a remark "Not Government Grade" where the officer considers such remark to be necessary, I assumed that it would be sufficient for me to make note in the remarks column concerning the purchase of this stump puller to the effect that the stump pullers not chosen were not of Government grade. I trust that this explanation will be satisfactory to the Department.

The machine has been in use since delivery and is giving splendid satisfaction. I am satisfied that the machine selected at $216.00 is of better value than the other machines which were offered and I used my discretion in the matter of this purchase and I trust not contrarily to the rules of the Department. The voucher in question, with abstract of tenders is returned herewith.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Your of 5th inst. No. 1813948 is here.

At present our stock consists of four cows, one bull and two horses, besides a calf. I am storing up seventy-five tons of feed for the year—twenty-five tons of hay and fifty tons of salt grass for the barn. By doing this, my freight is reduced to half.

I intend to increase my stock by six cows in order to be able to supply butter and a great deal of meat by ranch sales. I shall be in a position to do this shortly, as I am ploughing a new acre of land in a few days, and two more acres will be most likely under cultivation early in spring. This will furnish sufficient supply for the barn. I feel that I must have recourse to some means of reducing the high freight rates on our supplies. Hence, the necessity of increasing our stock. As time goes on, I shall clear more land.

Therefore, from the above, I do not think the size of the barn I requested is by any means too large. Implement also should appear, be held at present, two ploughs, one double harrow, a stump puller with cables, and a drag saw.

Trusting the above will be satisfactory,

I remain,
Sincerely Yours,

A. J. Spencer

MEMORANDUM:

An item of $4,500 is provided in this year's estimates for the building of the necessary barn and store house required for the Seehelt School.

In July of this year a letter was directed to Commissioner Ditchburn asking him to communicate with the Principal of the School and advise the Department if he would undertake the building of the barn and store house providing the Department furnished the material and allowed him the services of one carpenter, the remainder of the work to be done by the school. He was also asked to furnish a rough sketch showing the size and style of buildings recommended.

In September a letter was received from Commissioner Ditchburn enclosing the information asked for and advising that the Reverend Principal would undertake the erection of the buildings, as suggested. On examining the sketches, however, it appeared to me that they were asking for more accommodation than was necessary from what I had seen on my visit there last year. I therefore wrote to Mr. Ditchburn for more information and have today received a letter which fully explains the accommodation asked for, and it would appear that a big improvement has taken place at the Seehelt School since the Reverend Father Sylvester has taken charge.

The cost of the barn and store house required will be well under the amount provided in the estimates. I am of the opinion that the same can be built for approximately $3,500.

I beg to recommend that Mr. Ditchburn be authorized to proceed with this work.

ARCHITECT.
Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 24th of September, file No. 15-3630 and your letter of the 21st instant regarding the building of a barn and storehouse for the Sechelt School, I beg to say that the Department approves of the carrying out of this work in accordance with the sketch submitted with your letter of the 24th of September, and I would ask you to please purchase all the materials required in the regular way.

It is noted with reference to the labour that the Principal agrees to be responsible for all of the labour with the exception of one carpenter who will be paid by the Department. An accountable cheque for the payment of labour performed by this carpenter will be sent you on application, and time sheets should be kept by the Principal showing the number of hours he works, and these should be forwarded to the Department when submitting the vouchers.

I am returning herewith the sketch and bill of material which you asked to have returned. Please see that the expenditure is kept as low as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Since I came here I found it necessary to make certain purchases to enable me to carry on the work about the school satisfactorily.

I bought a truck for $38.00 to haul wood for the school. But owing to the sandy nature of the roads, the work was too heavy for our horse. So I bought another horse for $8.00 to meet the one already here.

I bought a bull for $28.00, so the nearest one was at Nelson's Landing, some twenty miles away. As time went on I noticed that the demand for wood at the school was greater than the supply. So I bought a good smooth-hand wood sawing outfit for $300.00. It has been used to a great advantage ever since.

I have cleared an acre of new land. And after having staked it, the land required discing, so I bought a disc for $75.00. The disc harrow will be tried on other fields that I shall clear in time.

I bought faulty netting for $6.15 to fence the cleared acre. The field will serve as a faulty yard when the crop will be taken in.

The whole of the above amounts to $725.15.

I have no doubt at all that the Department will approve of the above purchases.

I beg you, therefore, to kindly submit these with attached vouchers, to the Department for their kind approval.
and refund the school for the purchase that I have made.

I have taken a great interest in this school and everything that pertains to it.

Sincerely Yours,

Father Anthony Swenceski, principal of the Sechelt Indian residential School, in which he makes application for two hundred and forty feet of one and one-half inch galvanized pipe and two T's, for purposes of irrigation.

Accompanying the voucher is an Abstract of Tender.

In this connection, I beg to report that the purchase was not made sooner as the Principal of the School was not ready to receive the boat on account of the many improvements of greater importance to the School upon which the Principal and staff have deemed it advisable to concentrate. Moreover, we have been on the lookout for a suitable boat and have seen a considerable number but we have not been able to find, until now, a boat that would be suitable for the purposes desired, the sum of approximately $600 being low for a complete boat ready for sea.

The boat has been purchased after conferring with Mr. H. H. Cairns, Inspector of Schools, the Principal—Rev. Father Swinecki, Mr. Dominion Constable Bartlett (who is also engineer of the Department's launch) and others. We are satisfied that this boat is a good buy at the price and the Principal is well satisfied with the vessel after giving it a good trial.

I would recommend that the account be paid.

NOTE.

Sechelt Council June 8, 1925.

Rev. Father Anthony's Boat House.

Rev. Father Anthony, Principal of the Residential School, having sought permission of the Council to erect a Boat House for the housing of the school launch, somewhere on the beach in front of Sechelt Reserve No. 2. The Council appointed Councillor Dan Paul and Secretary Thomas Julian, a committee to wait on Father Anthony to show him the place where the Council was willing that he should erect a boat house. KELVINATOR
ELECTRIC REFRIGERATION

Kelvinator is an appliance for chilling home refrigerators electrically. It can be installed in any good refrigerator, and will keep it at a much lower temperature than ice will. It requires no attention. Once installed Kelvinator operates automatically, doing away entirely with the daily attention demanded when ice is used.

Kelvinator is the oldest existing system of domestic electric refrigeration and is a time-tried product. Installations made years ago are still working as efficiently as ever.

IMPROVED Refrigeration—Not a Mere Substitute for Ice

While Kelvinator takes the place of ice in the refrigerator, it should not be regarded as an ice substitute. It is a new method entirely, as great an improvement over older methods as the vacuum cleaner over the broom.

Kelvinator chilled refrigerators are much colder than ice-cooled ones; foods stay fresh for days, not merely for a few hours; the refrigerator never gets musty; the interior is full of dry cold air.

Kelvinator really refrigerates, and true refrigeration has many characteristics hitherto unknown to the home.
What Is Kelvinator—How Does It Work?

Kelvinator consists of two parts: first, the freezing unit that goes into the compartment ordinarily used for ice; and second, a mechanical unit, usually placed in the basement, that extracts the heat from the refrigerator and thus leaves it cold.

The freezing unit is shown in the above illustration. This is made in sizes for any refrigerator. When Kelvinator is in operation this unit gets so cold it becomes thickly coated with frost. It stays that cold, and maintains a very low refrigerator temperature.

The trays of the freezing unit are used for freezing crystal-like cubes of pure ice for table use, or a large number of frozen desserts, salads and other dainties. Kelvinator furnishes a recipe book for making these things.

The mechanical unit that 'furnishes cold' to the freezing unit is shown below. This is usually placed in the basement or in any other convenient place. It may also be installed on top, below or at the side of the refrigerator according to space available.

This part is connected to the freezing unit in the refrigerator by two small pipes. A simple electrical connection furnishes power. Once the installation is made and the current turned on, you simply forget refrigeration. It stays cold without attention—colder than you ever imagined a refrigerator could be.

The Zone of Kelvination—Where Foods Stay Fresh for Days

It is a strange fact that at temperatures of from 40° to 50° the bacteria in foods multiply only about 1/400 as rapidly as in corresponding temperatures from 50° to 60°. Below 50° deterioration practically stops.

Kelvinator can, and does, maintain temperatures constantly below this danger line. Ice does not. For this reason the ideal range of temperature—from 40° to 50°—is called the Zone of Kelvination. Foods placed in this Zone stay fresh for days.

The atmosphere of the Zone of Kelvination is not moist and clammy as is ice-cooled air. It is dry and actually frosty. It has the same crisp "sting" as the air on a frosty night. There is a reason for this.

Remember that the freezing unit is many degrees colder than ice. It is so cold that the moisture crystallizes on it, and it soon becomes thickly coated with pure, white frost.

How Foods Improve in the Zone of Kelvination

The cold, frosty air of the Zone of Kelvination does far more than merely "keep" foods. It actually improves them.

Take, for example, green vegetables such as are used for salads. When they come from the market they are seldom as crisp and inviting as when fresh from the garden. But put them for
a few hours in the frosty Zone of Kelvination and they "crisp up" until they almost fall apart at the touch of a fork.

Take meats. Everybody knows that the thick steaks served in the best hotels and restaurants have a tenderness and flavor that the housewife seldom duplicates. Make use of the Zone of Kelvination and you can serve steaks just as delicious.

Try it. Keep your meats for a few days in a Kelvinator-chilled refrigerator and they will acquire that same delicious tenderness and flavor. The frosty air removes all objectionable animal taste and gives meats a flavorful mellowness totally different from meats direct from the market.

**KELVINATOR-Chilled Refrigerators Are Always Fresh and Clean**

Kelvinator is a joy to the careful housewife because mustiness never develops. It is moisture that causes this mustiness, and since Kelvinated air is dry air it prevents the unsanitary conditions caused by dampness.

Kelvinator-chilled refrigerators always have a clean, cold interior with the same frosty snap you have often noticed on clear autumn nights. The owner of such a refrigerator is always proud to show it.

**Kelvinator Makes You Independent of Ice Delivery**

Even if Kelvinator required the same care as ice, you would like it for its superiority, but when you consider that it relieves you of all the annoyance of ice-handling it is twice as desirable.

Kelvinator refrigerates for months or years with practically no attention. You need never worry about ice melting over Sunday. You need not inconvenience yourself by waiting for the ice man before you can go calling or shopping. Mud or snow will never be tracked over your clean floors.

In short, your refrigerator will become as free from care or trouble as any article of furniture. You will accept refrigeration as naturally as the presence of a built-in cupboard.

**Market Only Once a Week—Forget Daily Trips to the Store**

When you have Kelvinator you can buy foods for a week in advance. Put them in the Zone of Kelvination and you will be prepared for any emergency. Unexpected guests will cause you no embarrassment.

Having the Zone of Kelvination in your home is just as convenient as having a complete store, once it is well stocked with provisions.

**With Children in the Home Kelvinator Is A Real Necessity**

Where there's a baby to look after, Kelvinator relieves mother of endless work and worry. The delicate foods that must be prepared so care-
Kelvinator Freezes New and Novel Kelvinated Desserts or Dainty Cubes of Pure Ice for the Table

Each Kelvinator freezing unit contains one or more removable trays. These trays are for the purpose of freezing cubes of ice for the table or preparing frozen desserts, salads and other dainties. If you fill these trays with your favorite table water and set them in place for a few hours, the result is crystal-clear cubes of ice for chilling beverages or similar uses. If you color the water, the ice cubes will be beautiful and decorative. Thus while Kelvinator relieves you of the cares of ice delivery it provides you with ice in its purest and most attractive form.

Fruit juices, creams and other special preparations frozen in the trays make sherbets, ices and other dainties. Colorful frozen salads can be made in the same way. To prepare these frozen dainties with Kelvinator you do not have to work with cracked ice and salt; you merely put the material in the trays and forget them for a few hours. Among the Kelvinated delicacies are ices, frappes, sherbets, mousses, chilled fruits, frozen custards, puddings, salads and many others. They are so numerous that a special book has been compiled on their preparation—the "Kelvinator Book of Delicacies." A copy of this book may be obtained from any Kelvinator dealer.

One important fact should be noted in regard to the process of Kelvination as compared with freezing with ice—Kelvinated products are pure. There is no chance of contamination from ice from an unknown source. Ice frozen by Kelvinator is as pure as table water, and Kelvinated delicacies are equally wholesome.

The process of freezing requires little attention. After the water, fruit juice, salad or other material is placed in the tray, you simply forget it until you are ready to serve it. Many find it convenient to fill the trays and leave them overnight.
fully can then be prepared for twenty-four-hour periods instead of half-a-dozen times a day. Kelvinator will keep them safe.

With older children it is easy to keep on hand the many special articles of diet upon which their health depends. It is not difficult to put them on a diet that is both scientific and tempting, for Kelvinator puts at your call any article of food required.

When Kelvinator Is Truly a Life-Saver

Kelvinator is a necessity to the family in health, but when sickness comes it is even more—it is a vital aid to recovery.

Nothing is more important in cases of sickness than diet. With Kelvinator you can not only keep on hand articles of food that are demanded, but you can also prepare an endless variety of dainties to tempt dormant appetites. How Kelvinator Refrigerates

To understand the principles of a refrigerating machine, operated on the so-called compression system, it is first necessary to understand a few of the fundamental laws of heat, particularly the conditions under which a liquid will boil and evaporate, and a vapor or gas will condense and liquefy.

In the first place it is important to understand the difference between HEAT and TEMPERATURE.

Heat is a form of energy, and is therefore capable of performing work, or, in other words, it is capable of producing a change in the state of a body. For example, iron or steel are ordinarily in the solid state, but through the application of heat it is possible to change them to the liquid state. Water, in a liquid form, may be changed into a vapor or gaseous state by a similar application of heat.

On the other hand, TEMPERATURE only indicates the relative hotness of various bodies.

Whenever temperature is referred to in this article, the Fahrenheit scale is used.

Heat, being a form of energy, cannot be destroyed or lost. It may be transferred from one body to another, or it can be transformed into a different kind of energy, e.g., electrical energy, but for our purpose it will only be necessary to consider what takes place when heat is transferred from one body to another.

Heat can be transferred of itself, or can flow, only from a body of a higher temperature to a body of a lower temperature, never in the reverse order. When the colder of two bodies receives heat, two changes take place: First, the temperature of the body may be raised; second, the state of the matter may be changed. If a solid, it may become a liquid; or if a liquid, it may be evaporated into a vapor or gas.

The difference between heat and temperature.

Changes taking place in the transfer of heat.
If a cold body has received heat from a body of higher temperature, it naturally follows that the hotter body has lost some of the heat which it previously contained. This loss of heat can have two results: the temperature of the hotter body may be lowered, or its state may be changed, but since it has lost some of its heat, this change will be from a gaseous state to a liquid state (condensation), or from a liquid state to a solid state (freezing or solidification).

Temperature of body undergoing change of state unchanged during process.

When the state of a body is changed, either from the solid to the liquid, or from the liquid to the gaseous, or conversely, from the gaseous to the liquid, or liquid to solid, the temperature of the body remains constant during the time this change is taking place. By way of illustration, suppose we have a vessel filled with crushed ice. The temperature as registered by a thermometer placed in the vessel will be 32 degrees. We now start to heat this vessel. The ice will begin to melt, but even though we continue to add heat, the temperature will not rise above 32 degrees until all the ice has melted. After the ice has entirely melted, the temperature of the water will rise until it reaches about 212 degrees. The water will then start to boil, but the temperature of the boiling water will remain at 212 degrees even though we continue to add heat. The continued application of heat to boiling water will only result in evaporation of the water into steam.

Water, however, does not always boil at 212 degrees. Water in a boiler under 100 pounds gauge pressure, boils at 338 degrees, and under 200 pounds gauge pressure, at 367 degrees, while water in a perfect vacuum would boil at 32 degrees. The temperature at which water will boil is not constant, but varies according to the pressure to which it is subjected.

Temperatures at which various liquids will boil. Effect of atmospheric pressure.

The boiling points of different liquids vary a great deal. Under atmospheric pressure, water will boil at 212 degrees, mercury at 676 degrees, benzine at 176 degrees, alcohol at 173 degrees, ether at 94 degrees, sulphur-dioxide at 15 degrees, and ammonia at minus 30 degrees. As is the case with water, if the pressure of any of these liquids be increased, the temperature at which they will boil is raised, and if the pressure be decreased, the boiling point will be correspondingly lowered.

To boil a liquid, it must receive heat from a body of a higher temperature. To boil mercury, the source of heat must have a higher temperature than 676 degrees. To boil sulphur-dioxide (SO₂), the source of heat need be only a few degrees hotter than 15 degrees—brine at 20 degrees is sufficient.

Relative coldness of ice and sulphur-dioxide.

Melting ice at 32 degrees is ordinarily considered cold, but it is really warm when compared with boiling sulphur-dioxide at 15 degrees. Liquid sulphur-dioxide at atmospheric pressure can easily be boiled and evaporated by melting ice, because the ice is 17 degrees warmer. Its heat will flow to the sulphur-dioxide, causing it to boil and evaporate into a vapor or gas.

By placing liquid sulphur-dioxide inside of a coil of pipe and immersing the coil in cold brine, the temperature of which is 25 degrees, the liquid sulphur-dioxide will be boiled and evaporated by the brine. At this point it is important to bear in mind that although the liquid sulphur-dioxide is receiving heat from the brine, yet this heat will not increase the temperature of the sulphur-dioxide, so long as the pressure remains constant, for the reason that the addition of heat to a boiling liquid cannot increase its temperature, but will result only in evaporation. Therefore, with the pressure remaining constant, the liquid sulphur-dioxide will continue to boil at a temperature of 15 degrees so long as it receives heat from the brine.

If the brine is giving up its heat to the boiling sulphur-dioxide, what change is taking place in the brine? There can be but one result—the lowering of the temperature of the brine. Brine of a proper strength will not freeze until its temperature is about zero. As the brine continues to give up its heat, its temperature will drop until it is equal to that of the boiling sulphur-dioxide. When this occurs, heat can no longer flow from the brine to the sulphur-dioxide, and the boiling and evaporating process will stop.

When water is boiled in a tight vessel or boiler, the evaporation of the water into steam will cause an increase in pressure, unless the steam is utilized or carried away as rapidly as it is generated. If sulphur-dioxide is evaporated inside of a closed coil, the pressure inside of this coil will also rise unless the vapor or gas is carried away as fast as

it is formed. If the pressure inside the coil rises, the temperature at which the liquid will boil will also rise. Therefore, if a constant boiling temperature is to be had, we must maintain a uniform pressure inside the coils while evaporation is taking place. A simple way to do this would be to let the gas pass off into the atmosphere, but this would necessitate having almost an unlimited supply of refrigerant and would be impractical, owing to the expense involved. The practical way to secure the desired result is to again liquefy the vapor and use it over and over.

How is liquefaction brought about? It has been shown that in order to boil a liquid and evaporate it into gas or vapor, heat must be applied. To change this vapor or gas back to the liquid state, the process must be reversed, and it must be caused to lose or give up the heat received during evaporation. As heat can flow only from a body of higher temperature to one of lower temperature, this vapor or gas cannot be condensed or changed into a liquid at atmospheric pressure, unless a substance of a temperature lower than 15 degrees can be found. This, of course, is not practicable.

It has been explained that the temperature at which a liquid will boil rises as the pressure is increased. It therefore follows that the temperature at which a gas will condense will also rise if the pressure is increased. It must be emphasized at this point that the pressure being constant, the temperature at which any liquid will boil is the same as the temperature at which its gas will condense, the only difference being that heat must be applied to evaporate a liquid, whereas heat must be extracted in order to condense a vapor or gas.

It has been shown how the liquid sulphur-dioxide is evaporated into a gas by the heat received from the brine. As a result of giving up its heat, the temperature of the brine is reduced. As the sulphur-dioxide takes heat from the brine, so does the brine take heat from the circulating air in the refrigerator in which it is placed.

How frost deposits appear on brine tank.

The air contains a certain amount of moisture, or water, which, when it comes in contact with the brine tank, is immediately frozen and deposits on the tank as frost. In this manner the air inside the refrigerator cooled by a brine tank not only is kept at a low temperature, but is also kept relatively dry.

Circulation of air in modern refrigerators.

Modern refrigerators are so designed as to obtain the greatest possible circulation of air, in order that the entire box may be kept at a uniformly low temperature. Cold air, being heavier than warm, will drop to the lowest point of the refrigerator. Inasmuch as all refrigerators are practically air tight, if the cold air drops, it forces the warm air to rise. This sets the air in motion and if the refrigerator is properly designed, the air can be made to follow a certain definite path of circulation inside the box.

Customary arrangements to facilitate the easy circulation of air in refrigerators.

The usual arrangement for proper air circulation in a refrigerator with an ice compartment at the side is shown in Fig. 1. As the air surrounding the brine tank is cooled, it will drop to the lowest point, which will force the remainder of the air inside the refrigerator into motion. The construction of the refrigerator is such that the air must follow a certain definite path, as indicated by the arrow.

In this manner the warm air is forced out of the food compartment, passes into the ice compartment through the flue at the top, where it is cooled by contact with the brine tank, and again drops to the lowest point in the refrigerator.

A common arrangement for circulation in a refrigerator made with an ice compartment on top is shown in Fig. 2. By this arrangement the cold air descends through the flue in the center of the box, which in turn forces the warm air to rise through the passages on the sides of the ice chamber with the result that the warm air comes in contact with the brine tank and is cooled.
