Sir:

Re Sechelt Indian Boarding School Electric Light Plant

In compliance with your request of the 26th ultimo, I have had an investigation made of the Electric Lighting Plant of the Sechelt Boarding School by Mr. W. C. Warren and from his report to me of September 20th, I have to advise you as follows:

"The plant consists of a 6 H.P. Fairbanks, horizontal type, gas engine rated at 450 R. per minute, belt connected to a 3½ Kw. Fairbanks shuntwound generator rated at 1400 R. per minute and a 56 cell, 180 amp.hr. 112 volt, Western Electric storage battery. This plant with the exception of the engine, which was replaced about two years ago, has been in operation since the school was built.

The work of the plant has reached its total capacity. About 25% more lights are now required than when the plant was installed. In addition to the lighting requirements, the gas engine also drives the laundry machinery and requires about 4½ H.P. to operate. The laundry machinery consists of a washing machine 1 H.P. and extractor ¾ H.P. These of course are only operated one day a week. The process of charging the battery and operating the washing machine being carried on at the same time, while to operate the extractor, the generator load has to be released. The extractor, however, is only run 5 or 10 minutes at a time. In summer the battery requires charging twice or three times a week, while in winter it is necessary to charge everyday.

The present battery is almost completely worn out and will have to be replaced before the present winter. The engine, although not very economical in operation is in fair condition and the generator has recently been overhauled.

The cost of renewing the present battery would be practically as much as the cost of a new one and the results would be uncertain.

The engine is slightly under the amount of power necessary to operate this plant successfully and cannot be run economically. The fuel consumption at full load amounts to one gallon per hour. By the installation of a crude oil engine a saving of about $125.00 per year, in operating cost, could be effected."
In view of the contemplated future installation of a refrigeration plant and the necessity of more storage for the additional lights already added to the system, it is recommended that a battery of larger capacity be installed in place of the one now in use. The cost of a new system of approximately 300 ampere capacity would be $1500. This cost would be somewhat lessened by the salvage value of the old one, which might amount to $150. The engine while serviceable requires constant repairs as it is overloaded under the present arrangement. Economy has been practised at the school in the matter of labour, and where formerly three men were employed, one now attends to all the outside work and also operates the heating plant and electric light plant. It is necessary that these plants operate successfully so that this arrangement can be maintained.

It is recommended that the engine now in use be disposed of and a 6 H.P. crude oil one be substituted at a cost of $600.00. The salvage value of the old engine would be about $100.00

The total cost of the improvements proposed would be $2,275.00. Allowing for possible recovery from plant disposed of, this might be reduced to about $2,000.00.

**Itemized Cost of Plant**

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| New Battery 300 ampere        | $1500  |
| Diesel Engine - 6 H.P.        | 590    |
| 2 pulleys                     | 35     |
| Freight                       | 100    |
| Installation & Inspection Expenses | 50    |
| **TOTAL**                     | **$2275** |

It is of course possible to make some improvements to the plant at a cost less than outlined above, so that system may function more or less satisfactorily for a year or two. However with the installation of a large battery and diesel engine as above recommended a most satisfactory system will be obtained which should function at a minimum cost of operation for seven or eight years.

Your obedient servant,
"G.E.Webb",
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

Re-Lighting Plant Sechelt School.

On the 23rd March last you wired me to see about having a new set of battery plates installed at the Sechelt Indian School as the old ones were reported to be in poor condition.

I obtained a price of $722.50 from the Jervis Electric Company, of Vancouver, which was for the providing of new plates to replace the old ones, and a 50-gallon electrolyte tank. The company also used up the old battery jars. The capacity of the present batteries is 160 ampere hours. I was instructed to accept this price providing it was the most satisfactory one I could obtain. The Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Company then quoted a price of $840.00 f.o.b. Toronto, for a 280 ampere hour set of batteries.

As the supplying of a new battery set appeared to be contingent on the installation of a Kelvinator cooling plant for the School, I preferred to take no action until I had learned whether the cooling plant would be purchased this year. The Department, however, decided that the installation of a Kelvinator plant must be laid over until next year. Nothing further was therefore done about the purchase of a battery set. On June 29th Rev. Principal of the School wrote to me that the lighting system in the School had given out and that he had sent the Dynamo to Vancouver for repairs, thus indicating that the trouble was not with the batteries. The Principal also stated that the 6 h.p. engine in use at the School was not large enough to run a 3½ K.W. dynamo, which required a 5½ h.p. engine, and at the same time run a 20" laundry extractor also requiring 5½ h.p., as well as a 30" x 36" washing machine requiring a further 1/2 h.p. The repairs to the dynamo apparently were sufficient for the time being but at the end of August it was found something further would have to be done to meet the requirements and as this was a subject with which I was not familiar, I seemed it in the best interest of the Department and Mr. Webb, District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch at Vancouver, to have one of his engineers, who had experience on such matters, go to Sechelt as soon as possible to see just what was required to put the plant in proper shape.

On the 25th ultimo Mr. Webb furnished me with the report of Engineer Warren, which provided for a new set of batteries.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
batteries of 300 ampere hour capacity, a new Diesel engine and two pulleys, the total cost of which, including freight, installation and inspection is put down at $2,275.00. A copy of Engineer Warren's report is attached hereto for your information in which you will observe that it is deemed essential that a new battery set should be installed at an early date.

Owing to the difficulty in obtaining money at Ottawa at present, I again wrote to Mr. Webb pointing this phase of the question out, and asking him if it would not be possible for the School to get along for a time by merely renewing the batteries. I also pointed out the prices which had been submitted by the Joliet Electric Company and the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse, they being much lower than the figure quoted by Engineer Warren, but he has now informed me that neither the battery at present at the School nor the one quoted on by the Canadian Fairbanks-Morse people are large enough for the requirements of the School and he would recommend the larger size set. So far as a new engine is concerned, Mr. Webb concludes that this is not necessary at the present time except to cut the cost of operation. The engine now in use at the School is apparently good for several years yet.

In view of the above I would strongly recommend that if it is impossible at the present time to provide sufficient funds for the full new equipment as recommended by Engineer Warren, that the new and larger battery set be purchased and installed at as early a date as possible, under the direction of an engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch.

Father John Duplanil, Principal of the Sechelt Residential School, and he brought to my attention the necessity of being furnished with a DeLaval 1½ h.p. boiler for the laundry, which will greatly facilitate their work at the school in this regard. He informed me that the boiler can be purchased from the DeLaval Agency in Vancouver at a cost of about $150.00. Father Duplanil has only recently been transferred to Sechelt from St. Mary's School at Mission, at which place he had one of these boilers and he spoke very highly of its usefulness.

The Rev. Principal also pointed out that the outside doors of the school are in need of re-varnishing and oiling afterwards. Memorandum to Mr. Webb.

The equipment purchased for Sechelt Boarding School installed during the past week was found to be in good order and no fault can be found with it. Although the plant is not operating satisfactorily it is not due to the new equipment but rather to the restricted area in which it has to operate. It is intended to run a series of tests after which the necessary changes in connecting the installed machinery will be made. By the end of next week the plant should be operating satisfactorily. No difficulty is anticipated in having a completely satisfactory plant.

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter dated July 18th, No. 167-18-5, covering copy of a communication from the Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School making requisition for repairs to the roofs of the Sechelt Residential School buildings and other desired work.

In reply thereto I beg to say that I have consulted with the Principal of the School, who informs me that if the expenditure referred to are authorized by the Department the management will have the work done, except the installation of a new drum for washing machines and the repair of the roofs, which require expert labor. The management expects the Department to pay for labor.

Reporting on the work, etc., for which authority is asked under their respective heads I beg to state:

1. Permanent repair of flat roofs over kitchen, laundry and boiler room at cost of approximately $80.00 is recommended. I can procure a cauldron and spreader for the asphaltum in Vancouver and return it after use, the cost for loan of these utensils being nominal.

2. The staining of the roofs of the main building and chapel at approximate cost of $109.00 is recommended inasmuch as the roofs have not been stained since the building was first completed.

The cost of the above two items over and above the estimate of the Principal is on account of freight charges, hire of utensils, wharfage and cartage at Sechelt, not estimated by the Principal. I think the work should be done if possible before the frosty weather sets in. If this can not be done it should be left over until the spring.

3. Thirty-one windows to be covered with hardware wire cloth 3 x 3 mesh, 30 inches wide, galvanized, would involve a cost of approximately $57.00 complete. This work is not considered urgent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
4. Drum of washing machine. As this is purchasable in Toronto, I would recommend the same to be obtained and forwarded at the earliest possible date, as it is urgently required to replace one worn out. The cost can not be given or obtained in Vancouver in so far as I am able to ascertain.

5. Fencing. In this matter the Department will be aware that on the 16th April 1925 by letter No. 27167-1 the Department authorized Mr. L. S. Cokely, Land Surveyor of Courtenay, B.C., to proceed with the surveying of the limits of a fifteen acre parcel on Sechelt Reserve No. 2 which it was agreed by the members of the Band on February 17th, 1925 should be set aside for the purpose of the Indian Boarding School at that point. I have not since that time been advised of the completion of this survey by Mr. Cokely nor have I on file any map or data in this connection. I think it is advisable that a map should be sent to me that would aid me in locating the posts planted by this surveyor who carried out his work under the supervision of the Indian Commissioner at Victoria. The fencing is not considered urgent except that it would prevent horses and cattle from straying onto the public highway. A small portion only of the property assigned to the school has as yet been cleared, in fact some of the stumping which was done under direction of this Department has not been followed up by clearing of the debris as had been anticipated by the Rev. Father Anthony, a former Principal, who was inclined to outdoor activities and farm development, and was later removed by the Church authorities to Kamloops or another Interior Boarding School. Reverend Father John, Rev. Father Barney and the present Principal, Rev. Father McCaffrey are men of scholastic type and do not appear to be as enthusiastic about developing this land as Father Anthony was. Had Father Anthony remained at Sechelt, no doubt a great deal more land would have been cleared. I would also point out that the land is poor and sandy and even when treated with heavy applications of fertilizer has not been as productive as might be desired. This matter could receive fuller consideration and an estimate of material required could be better prepared were I provided with a surveyor's plan showing definite areas and the description given by the Reverend Principal under Section 5 of his letter could be more useful if augmented by this plan.

6. Chicken house. This I believe to be necessary as the houses in present use are very old and some are getting rotten. Approximately $15.00 should be added to the Principal's estimate of $260.00, to take care of freight, wharfage and cartage. I would recommend that this work be carried out as early as possible.

7. The Reverend Principal has been advised of the Department's observations to the effect it is considered this equipment.

Dear Mr. Ditchburn:

Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental letter dated September 29th last, No. 167-18-5, in which authority was given by the Department for the expenditure of the sum of $80.00 for the repair of the flat roofs over the kitchen, laundry and boiler room at the Sechelt Indian Residential School and a further sum of $275.00 for the erection of a chicken house in connection with this school. I would inform the Department that after consulting with the Principal, Rev. J. McCaffrey, it was considered advisable on account of the very inclement weather to defer the carrying out of this work until a little later in the spring. I wrote a letter to the Principal on January 25th, pointing out that I would like to have this work finished before the end of the present Fiscal Year, but the Principal replied that on account of the then adverse weather conditions it was considered an unprompted time to carry out the work. Moreover the engineer at the school, Mr. Field, upon whom the Principal had counted to do this work, was so occupied that he could not promise the Principal any aid especially as the heating plant and engines impose a heavy duty upon him, therefore he could not see any likelihood of the work on the chicken house being begun, much less completed, before the end of the present month of March. The Principal regrets that this should be so but expresses the hope that the appropriation so kindly granted by the Department can be held in abeyance for more favorable conditions a little later.

I would therefore request that, if possible, the appropriation for this work be extended beyond the end of the present Fiscal Year.

Your obedient servant,

(C. C. Perry)
Indian Agent.

INSPECTION REPORT VANCOUVER AGENCY No. 1.

SECHELT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL:

This school had broken up for the holidays and the Rev. Principal was away. However, one of the Brothers was in charge and took us around. I found the building in good order and well kept. Some of the plaster on the walls, however, requires renewing, as if this is not done soon, it is liable to spread and get worse. Here too, I found that the chemical extinguishers should be replenished and suggested their being emptied for training purposes. The fire alarm system in this school is inadequate, there not being enough bells. Some bells should certainly be placed over each dormitory door, and I wondered whether those bells that were in use for three years in the Girls' Wing at Kamloops Residential School might not be sent up there and installed as soon as the work of installing the new system at Kamloops is completed. Proper fire drill too, should be organized.

There is not much agricultural land available at this school, but the vegetable garden at this school is well kept and creditable. The Brother informed me that good potatoes were difficult to get and costly. I should think that Indian schools like St George's at Lytton, would be only too pleased to sell their surplus and by purchasing a carload they would not be costly, provided Sechelt school dug a potato cellar in which to store them. I will make enquiries to that effect.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

He recommends that the bells that have been in use at the Kamloops School, but are not further required, be sent to the Sechelt School and installed over each dormitory door. We are requesting Mr. Inspector Pragnell to forward the bells to the Sechelt School and when they arrive you should arrange to have them properly installed. You may, if necessary, obtain the services of an electrician to do this work. Report on Indian School Sewage Disposal.

Present Conditions - Filter Bed not absorbing affluent from Septic Tank, as soil has become sealed up on account of grease, soap, etc. not being properly broken up in septic tank. Ground surrounding filter basin is water-logged or so filled with moisture as to prevent renewal of oxygen. Surface ditches have been dug outside the school boundary; these are in a very insanitary condition.

Cause of these conditions - Septic tank rather small for the number of persons accommodated by the system. Too much soap, grease, bleaches, or disinfectants used for the proper working of anaerobic bacteria, the disintegrating agency. Too much water on wash days, not allowing sufficient time in the septic tank, for the proper breaking up of the solids, and greasy matter, before same is discharged. Stone filter beds have not proved very satisfactory in the case of this school, for the ultimate disposal of the affluent, as the space between stones fills at course of time rendering the bed unable to take care of the discharge from the tank, which is of the intermitting syphon type, that several times each day discharges 897 gallons into the filter basin, so if the space between the stones cannot absorb this quantity it backs up in the pipe filling the septic tank, above the proper water level, thereby disturbing fluids in tank, and preventing the proper functioning of same. Nearly all the trouble is caused by the filter bed being unable to receive the full flow from the septic tank, on the instant of discharge, and the ultimate sealing up and water logging of the said basin.

I have formulated three plans for the remedy or removal of these conditions. You will note that none of these are without objections. Plans No. Two and Three would be ideal in as far as the school is concerned and would be permanent.

Plan No. One.

Construct a crate of rough heavy cedar five by sixteen by five feet, properly braced but with no bottom, but with a strong close cover, the whole to be buried eighteen inches below the surface of the ground, so the soil could be tilled above it. Connect crate to discharge of tank, with six inch vitrous pipe, and storm water drains with four inch vitrous pipe. Locate this crate a short distance from the present filter basin. This, I believe, would be satisfactory for from four to six years, after which it would necessary to renew and relocate.

Plan No. Two
Plan No. Two.

Connect discharge of septic tank, with joints properly cemented for a distance of about nine hundred and fifty feet, to a pot hole, or a depression in the ground, said pot hole is located on the Indian Reserve, in North Westerly direction from the school, but unfortunately outside the school property, on the north side of the Government Road. It would be necessary to erect a rough log or other fence surrounding the discharge end of this pipe. This plan would in my opinion be the best to follow, if arrangements can be made with the Indian Council.

Plan No. Three.

Would be to pipe discharge to sea water, either on the front or to Porpoise Bay. This plan would be costly and would certainly raise a lot of opposition to discharging sewage into salt water so near to the summer resorts.

Whatever plan is followed, the whole system should first be thoroughly cleaned out, and the septic tank restarted.

Trusting this is the information desired.

I am Yours truly,

A. R. Tebb.
Selma Park,
Skeetch, B.C.

Sir:

I have the honour to refer to telegram of Mr. Indian Agent Perry to the Department dated May 20th, last as follows:-

"Sechelt Indian Residential School septic tank overflowing and should receive immediate inspection and attention. Please state if Engineer Tebb of Sechelt may do necessary work."

also to the Department's reply dated May 21st., viz:-

"Arrange with Tebb for inspection and attention septic tank Sechelt School."

In this matter I beg to say that on receipt of the Department's wire Mr. Agent Perry immediately communicated with Mr. Tebb and also with Rev. Principal McCaffrey. Unfortunately Mr. Tebb was engaged in other work and could not give immediate attention to the matter and as there was no other person at Sechelt qualified to submit engineer's report, Mr. Tebb's inspection and report were delayed until recently when a report was submitted by Mr. Tebb dated August 26th., original and copy of which are sent herewith.

Mr. Tebb was subsequently asked by Mr. Agent Perry to submit his estimate of the cost of plans numbered 1 and 2, respectively, eliminating plan No.3, which would have been objected to by the white people in the vicinity. Mr. Tebb has by letter dated September 15th., the original of which is also sent herewith, estimated the approximate cost of plan No.1 at $185.00 and plan No.2 at $505.00. Original letter dated September 3rd. signed by Reverend J. McCaffrey endorsing the carrying out of plan No.2 is also sent herewith.

It is recommended after discussion with Mr. Perry that plan No.2 be carried out as being the best means of eliminating the sewage difficulties at this school.

I should point out, however, that the "pot-hole" referred to by Mr. Tebb may be found to be on the Sechelt Reserve No.2, beyond the limits of the recently surveyed 15 acres for the school but this point can be cleared up as soon as a visit can be made to Sechelt when the Council's consent might be obtained, should it be found that the area of sewage discharge is outside the school property.

In the meantime the Reverend Principal has been requested to take all possible steps to prevent entrance into the septic tank at present existing of too great a body of soapy water, etc., and the principal and his staff are endeavoring to do so.

Sir:

Re Your File No.167-18-5.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo with reference to staining and cleaning moss from the roof of Sechelt Indian School. The moss has become very thick on about 1500 sq.ft. of the roof, the total area of which is 10,338 sq.ft.

The Principal considers it would cost approximately $500.00 to scrape the moss and pay for stain and labour but he has valued the stain at $4.50 per gal. and covering 120 sq.ft. to the gallon. I have taken it up with the shingleen vendors here who state that 1 gal. should cover approximately 150 ft. and the cost of the shingleen in barrels in Vancouver $2.00 per gallon. Father McCaffrey's estimate is excessive as I am quite sure the complete job could be done for $350.00 including freight charges on shingleen from Vancouver. It is necessary that this work be done immediately while the school is closed, first to protect the shingles and avoid heavy expense of re-shingling, as it is 8 years since the shingling was done and unless protected will not last their full term. Sechelt is on an exposed part of the Coast, and high winds strike the school continually.

The principal reason for removing the moss is on account of fire risk. The moss is dry and inflammable and a spark from the chimney might start a fire at any time. This part of the work at least is urgent but it would not be economical to remove the moss without re-staining the shingles.

I respectfully recommend that this work be done at an early date.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(P.J.C.Ball)

Sir:

With reference to the recent outbreak of typhoid at the above School, I am advised that there were actually only two cases, the third has been diagnosed as other than typhoid. There has been some delay about obtaining analysis of the milk and water used by the School but neither is considered by the medical officer and others to have been the cause.

I am having the sewage disposal system checked up for possible trouble as the Principal says there is a distinct odour in the basement.

The children at this school are not clean and I consider the lack of bathing facilities responsible. There are forty girls and forty boys usually in attendance and each section has two baths, one a small one for infants and two toilets. There should be installed as soon as possible six shower baths for each section. These could be installed very cheaply, the woodwork would be done by the school and the plumbing would be a simple matter. They do not need any elaborate fixtures—merely a row of sprinklers with valves. I am advised that at present there is so much congestion at bathing time that two use the same water. I was surprised to hear it and consider it disgraceful. Shower baths would take care of six at a time and would be infinitely more sanitary, and quicker.

I would recommend therefore that these fixtures be installed at an early date.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Mr.Ball,-

In reply to your letter of the 13th inst., No.1665, would say I have been to the School and find the outlet sewer is working perfectly and you can rest assured that this piece of work will not, at any time, give you any trouble.

I also inspected the sanitary installation in the basement and find on the boys' side there is considerable odour due to urine on the floor. Now I do not wish to imply that it is due to want of cleanliness on the part of anyone of the staff. There used to be a urinal for the boys but this is not there anymore and there are only two closets for forty boys which in my opinion is not enough. There is always a grand rush, when classes are dismissed or play is over and no doubt a good deal of jostling and a large amount goes on the floor. One of the closets was found partly choked by some obstruction in trap discharge orifice. This the Principal is having the engineer clear to-day by taking up bowl and clearing and resetting. I also found considerable leakage from the closet tanks either from a worn douglass float or for want of a new washer on intake valves, but covers of tanks were nailed down, no doubt to keep the children from interfering with the mechanism, so I was unable to determine which. This leakage results in only about a half flush and is not enough to insure proper clearing of the bowl. There is also the matter of newspaper being used and sometimes in such large pieces to cause the bowl to overflow by clogging the outlet. This happened yesterday. There was a large piece of paper in bowl and when I flushed it, it clogged for a few seconds, but finally passed through. There are no wood seats on any of the closets in the basement. One bowl has the rim broken.

On the girls' side there are three closets, but one is not in commission being broken and the water turned off. This side is clean. There is no odour. I certainly think that a battery of urinals or more closets should be installed on the boys' side, and a new closet to replace the broken one on the girls' side of basement.

Trusting this is the information you require,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) A.R.Tebb.
Re Typhoid Fever at Sechelt Residential School.

Sir,

I beg to report further in connection with the outbreak of typhoid fever at Sechelt Residential School which I reported upon March 13th instant. The water has been found pure and the sewage disposal system is working perfectly. I mentioned in my letter of the 13th the uncleanly condition of the boys and also some parts of the school. These are matters for stricter supervision by the Principal, the Rev.Father Mailhard, and the responsibility is entirely his own; even if there are inadequate sanitary facilities.

On May 26, 1930, I wrote you asking if a urinal could be installed at the school as the principal then, the Rev.Father McCaffrey, found it extremely difficult to keep the lavatories clean, but in your letter of June 2nd, File 167-18-5, this was refused. Under date of March 13th, I asked for permission to have shower baths installed and I now enclose a copy of a letter from Mr.A.R.Tebb, of Sechelt, which explains the necessity for further lavatory accommodation.

I may add that the School authorities are of the opinion that effluvia from these lavatories caused the typhoid, but medical opinion does not support such contention.

I respectfully request authority to have the lavatory accommodation repaired and enlarged to meet the needs of the School and an inexpensive set of showers installed at the same time. The principal of the Provincial Industrial School for Boys made a strong complaint that three boys committed to his institution recently from the Sechelt School arrived there in a filthy condition and this does not redound to the credit of the School.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I have your 1746 of the 21st instant, with reference to sanitary conditions at the Sechelt Indian Residential School. You may repair the lavatories and have an inexpensive set of showers installed. I regret our funds are such that we cannot authorize additional lavatory accommodation, with the exception of an inexpensive urinal for the boys' side. The Department relies on you to see that no unnecessary expense is incurred.

I note that there has been a complaint from the Provincial Industrial School concerning the condition of some of the boys who were committed from Sechelt. I am writing to Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn, asking for a report in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Ball:

Your letter of the 20th and enclosed copy of a communication from Dr. Inglis came to hand last Saturday, as you mentioned that you had requested the Doctor to call on me to discuss his complaint. I have not answered more promptly; to the present time I have not seen Dr. Inglis though I believe he has been to Sechelt twice recently. I have been to point where discharge takes place, and while there is odor distinguishable inside the enclosure, but is not noticeable at any great distance from the said enclosure, and the conditions are not comparable to conditions prevailing for a number of years within 70 feet of class rooms and the boys dormitory; now, the present point of complaint is approximately 500 feet distant from the school, across the Government Road and there is not any other building as close as the school is, except the stable.

However, if this open discharge is considered a menace to health or otherwise objectionable a rock and gravel filter bed could be constructed at the outlet, or better still a rough crate like box built of 2x6 cedar with joints spaced 1 inch apart at sides and ends, no bottom, and a close top, this would need be 3 feet wide 3 feet deep by 40 feet long placed under ground and covered by a foot of earth. I would recommend the box first on account of cost, and also from the danger of a filter bed to overflow at point where the sewer enters.

Regarding the tile drain method of treating the effluent, mentioned by the Doctor. This method was recommended by Portland Cement interests, for farm and suburban homes, but has never been extensively used as the plot on which the tiles are laid must have a lower level than the outlet of the septic tank because they will not function if laid more than 20" to 24 inches below the surface of the ground, so that it was impossible to adopt this system at the School as the septic tank is placed, and necessarily so, at about the lowest point on the school grounds. The tank is of the intermitting syphon discharge type, with the outlet six feet below the ground level; it would be impractical to install the Drain Tile system at the end of the new drain instead of the filter bed or filter box above mentioned but the cost as it would require, in order to absorb the amount flow from this system 60,000 feet of 4" drain tile or 40,000 of 6" tile, which with the laying etc. would be a very expensive piece of work.

A rough estimate of the cost of the filter bed, and filter box, without getting actual figures on material would be Rock and Gravel Filter Bed $300.00 Box Filter $180.00

Now for a little history of the attempts to adequately take care of the effluent from the sewerage system of this school, as you were not stationed here at the time it may be interesting for you to know what has been done in this matter; when the school was built in 1921 the plans called for Filter Basin 12 feet in diameter at the top 8' at bottom and 6 ft. deep placed 50 feet south of septic tank, this by myself the general contractors, and plumbing contractors was considered too small,

so....
without extra cost to the Department, it was installed 14 feet diameter at top 8 feet at bottom and 10 feet deep. The School was opened in the summer of 1922, and before the next spring sewage was laying on the surface of the ground. I still was of the opinion that this condition was brought about because the filter basin was yet too small for the service, so I recommended to the Department that one be installed 20 feet in diameter and 20 feet deep, this was done and for three or four years gave good service; then again sewage made its appearance on the surface of the ground and from that time on it has been a perfect seep pool a few yards from the school building until the new outlet sewer was put in last August, at which time the sewage had formed a lake 40 feet long 10 feet wide and 2 feet deep in the center, there also was a ditch outside of the school property, on the Indian Reserve, which also was full this at over flowed and ran down toward the Indian village.

The septic tank had ceased to function so a large amount of this was crude sewage, the main sewer of the school was full to the school building endangering the whole system.

Now the new effluent discharge pipe has been put in, carrying the waste to a lower level we find the septic tank again functioning, and it is an impossibility for the waste matter to back up and prevent it so doing, or endangering the school sewer, but there is bound to be some odour at the outlet, but not to be compared with the conditions which had prevailed on the school grounds for years previous to this installation. The next time you are in Sechelt I would like to go over the ground with you.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) A. R. Tebb.

Sechelt School Water Supply.

Dear Sir,

I beg to advise that Father Mallard, Principal of the above school, called here today with reference to the water supply at the school. He states that the storage tank held only ten inches of water this week and that by summer the situation will be worse. The main trouble is in the condition of the system between the intake from the creek and the storage tank. Father Mallard advises me that when he saw you in Ottawa immediately before he left to take charge of the School, you told him the water system at the School was going to be fixed up and that you already had a report on it from the Dominion Water Power Branch. This report will probably show that the intake is about two and one-half miles from the tank and consists of a wooden catch-basin at the intake and lengths of pipe and flume from intake to tank. The catch-basin has rotted and leaks badly and the pipes and flumes are also in poor shape. There is ample water if properly carried to the School. From the tank to the School, the system is in good order.

Will you kindly advise whether you have full particulars of these matters, and also whether the Department intends to have the works renewed in the near future?

Should full details be required, I could go over the system and report to you, but Mr. Webb, of the Water Power Branch, advises me that they reported on this water system some time ago.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

Sir:

EXTRACT from Report of G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools, on his inspection of the SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, on May 19 & 20, 1931.

Original on File 167-18-6.

Water Supply:

This is from a spring about 2½ miles from the school. The water is piped to the school and to the Indian Village. The water is good but the supply is limited, particularly in summer. The Indians in the village are reported to be leaving the taps open. Some of the water runs away. During July, August and September the school is without sufficient water. During these months, there is no pressure in the pipes sufficient for fire fighting. There is no water available at that season for irrigation.

I would recommend that, as soon as possible, the school be connected with the main water pipe of the Union Estates. This pipe runs near the school, and as far as I can learn, there is abundance of water in this pipe line at all times of the year. This would give proper fire protection to the school.

EXTRACT from Letter of W.E. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner for B.C., dated June 5, 1931, forwarding above Report.

Original on File 167-18-6.

In connection with the water supply mentioned by Capt. Barry, I beg to say that I have asked Mr. Webb, District Chief Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch, to negotiate with the Union Estates of Vancouver in the matter of obtaining a reasonable rate for the Department tying into their large domestic water system which was only installed a couple of years ago. This matter will be reported upon at a later date at which time an estimate will also be given as to what the cost will be for the laying of the necessary main from the Union Estates pipeline to the school.
Fire Protection:

There are two wooden fire escapes. Outside the building, there is one fire hydrant with hose. In the summer months, neither the supply of water nor the pressure would be sufficient to make this hydrant of any practical use. The same remark applies to the three stand pipes (one on each floor) inside the building. There are 18 chemical extinguishers inside the building. With these, a small fire might be fought. The door from the small girls' dormitory to the fire escape is kept locked. The key to this door is in the supervisor's room. The big girls pass through the supervisor's room to the escape. The door to the supervisor's room is not locked. I held a fire drill while inspecting the school. The children were in their classrooms, etc. I was not very satisfied with the results of this drill. The children were clear of the building in less than sixty seconds; but they did not walk out in an orderly manner. Some ran, which is a very bad practice during any sort of fire drill. The Principal explained this by saying that the children were happy. I still do not think that they should be permitted to run at fire drill.

Sanitary Conditions:

The wash rooms were perfectly clean. In the kitchen, which was also clean, the wall tiles are much worn. It looks to me as if very inferior material was used here when the school was built. The girls' toilets seem to be in good condition. The boys' toilet in the basement was not in satisfactory condition. There are only two toilets here for 35 boys. One of these toilets was completely blocked up. The Principal informs me that this particular toilet bowl keeps on blocking. There is nothing wrong with the drain as the other bowl flushes properly. There is also great need for a urinal in this boys' basement. I took this matter up with the Indian Agent, who informs me that he has arranged for the clearing of the toilet bowl and the installation of urinals. He had been working on this matter previous to my visit to the school.

The boys' recreation room might, I consider, be kept much cleaner. There is plaster off the wall due to the kicking of balls about the room. I do not consider that the Department should be called on to pay for repairs to the walls when proper supervision would make such a condition impossible.

The bitumastic top has worn off the cement in the girls' basement. There are only two bath tubs on each side of the school. I understand from Mr. Indian Agent Ball that he has arranged for the installation of six shower baths on each side of the school. Some large cracks have developed in the wall of the boys' infirmary.

The linoleum of the corridors is much worn. The Principal asks for 65 yards of plain brown Battleship Linoleum 3 ft. wide. I do not consider that the need for this is very urgent, when the funds of the Department are so badly needed for urgent matters.
Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo with reference to the Sechelt water system.

In compliance with your instructions, I am now forwarding full particulars. In January last Mr. Ditchburn sent me a copy of the Dominion Water Power Branch's report dated January 7, 1931, upon the extension of the system, and as the Sechelt Band had asked for this extension several years ago, I asked Mr. Ditchburn to recommend it. Because of the situation which has developed since that time regarding the shortage of funds and in view also of the partial breakdown of the whole water system, I beg to withdraw the recommendation to extend the present system.

The Department is aware that the Union Estates constructed their water system through the Indian Reserve at Sechelt without payment for the privilege but the understanding seems to have been that at some future time they would supply the School and Reserve with water at a price to be agreed upon, but no definite arrangement was made. Instead of incurring the expense of replacing or repairing our system, I would suggest that if we can so arrange, we tap the Union Estates line from one of the T's placed in position for that purpose and supply the School from that source, leaving all other water in the present system for the Indians. We have on file an estimate of $1,623.00 for material and labour to construct a six inch wood stave pipe from the Company's system to the School with three hydrants and 150 feet of hose for each hydrant. With steel pipe the cost would be $800.00 more but with only two hydrants instead of three. This would cover cost of construction only; we would still have to arrange with the Union Estates. I understand that their system cost about $23,000.00 and they will ask for proportion of this amount and upkeep. This proportion was estimated at that time to be $3,850.00 so that on this basis our total cost for the School would be $5,473.00. Major Harold Brown is out of town but as soon as he returns I have an appointment with him and can give you further information as to the Company's views. Our requirements would be about one-half cubic feet per second for the school and reserve. The Company's system carries 4-1/2 c.f.s. No one in Vancouver at present

Re: Water Supply, Sechelt Indian Residential School.

I have to inform you that this morning, in company with Mr. Indian Agent Ball, I had an interview with Mr. Harold Brown, General Manager of the Union Steamship Co., with reference to Indian participation in the water supply system of the Union Estates Ltd. at Sechelt which passes through the Indian Reserve.

Mr. Brown at that interview stated that his company would supply water for domestic and fire fighting purposes for the Indian School at a flat rate of $100 per year, it being understood that the Department of Indian Affairs would bear the expense of all connections necessary from the Union Estates system.

So far as the school is concerned, I think this is a very equitable and satisfactory offer on the part of Mr. Brown. So far as irrigation at the school is concerned, I think it would be advisable, for the present at least, to obtain the irrigation supply from the existing Indian system, the Indian village being deserted during most of the summer months when water is required for irrigation.

Dear Sir:

On January 26th last I wrote you with reference to the Sechelt water system, asking you to recommend an extension in the village of that system.

Since that time, the situation has changed completely because there is an apparent breakdown in the pipe line from the intake to the school tank as Father Maillard reports there is only 1-1/2 feet of water in the tank and very little coming into it. Sir:

Re: Water Supply, Sechelt Indian School

Further to my letter of January 17, 1931, I have at the request of Mr. Indian Commissioner Ditchburn taken up with the Union Estates Ltd. the question of supplying the above mentioned school with a water supply for domestic use and fire protection. They have agreed to provide such a supply for the school at a charge of $100. per year, any connection charges or pipeline installation to be borne by the school. The proposed arrangement does not include the Indian village.

It would appear that the acquisition of such a supply will provide the most desirable solution of the water problems at Sechelt and will permit of the development of the present system supplying the school for the use of the Indian village along the lines suggested in my letter of January 17th.

The cost of an extension of the Union Estates pipeline to serve the school was estimated at $2400. but may be, at present, constructed for approximately $2800. see attached estimate.

A supply of water for the school such as the Union Estates are willing to provide at almost a nominal fee appears to be a very favorable concession on their part which I am sure will be fully appreciated by the Department of Indian Affairs and will no doubt be accepted when circumstances permit.

In the past, the Sechelt Indian Residential School and the contiguous Indian village have secured water from a wooden stave pipe. The system has not been very satisfactory, particularly in the summer months, when the supply is very limited. In addition, the pipe is constantly in need of repairs. At the present time, under authority of P.C. 130/1118, of May 16th, 1920, is being expended from Band Funds for the purpose of extending the system to additional homes on the reserve.

For some years, the Department has known the desirability of securing a better supply for the Sechelt School. The Union Estates, in 1929, provided a splendid water supply system for their property at Selma Park and for the village of Sechelt. Their water main for Sechelt passes through the Indian village. The easement to the Company was granted by the Indians gladly, on the understanding that, at some future date, we should be granted the privilege of connecting with the water system for the Indian village and for the residential school.

The Union Estates have offered water to the Sechelt Indian Residential School for an annual charge of $100. Mr. Commissioner Ditchburn and Mr. C.E. Webb, District Chief Engineer, of the Dominion Water Power, consider this a most favourable proposition, and, as a suitable supply for the school is now a matter of real urgency, it is strongly recommended that we tie on to the Union Estates system. The school would secure a domestic water supply and outside fire protection by hydrants.

The Dominion Water Power Branch has estimated the cost of connecting up with a 6 inch steel pipe at $2,193.50. This amount can be charged to the miscellaneous item in the Indian Education Vote, in which there remains approximately $5,000 unassigned. I shall be glad to have your instructions in the matter.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith a voucher for paint used at Sechelt Residential School in much needed renovations. The purchase was not authorized and Father Maillard has requested me to report the circumstances in support of his claim.

I regret to say the School had been allowed to become dilapidated under previous management and Father Maillard asked for authority to have it painted and varnished throughout. I advised him funds were not available and he insisted it must be done for hygienic reasons. Just before school closed he commenced on the work and everyone, including the sisters and pupils were kept diligently employed in scraping, varnishing and painting from top to bottom and I am pleased to say that the whole school is now a credit to the Department.

Every bed in the school was taken apart, washed in lysol, scraped and enamelled and looks as good as new. All walls are painted with a washable paint and floors scraped and varnished. Every desk was scraped, sanded, painted and varnished and I admit they were particularly dirty. Lavatories, wash-rooms, etc., were also treated with lysol and painted or white-washed and the school when it closed for vacation was absolutely clean, sanitary and wholesome.

Only one room—the boys' playroom in the basement—was untouched. This was walled with gyproc or similar material and has been broken into small pieces. It needs a lumber finished interior instead of a brittle substance as used and to do this work $40.00 worth of plain lumber is required.

I have been particularly pleased with the great improvements made by Father Maillard at this school recently and it reflects much credit upon him and his staff.

I hope this account for the paint will be refunded to him, the labour has been given free and to have had the work done privately would have cost many times the amount.

B/HM.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

EXTRACT from Inspector Barry's Report on his inspection of the SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL on April 19th, 20th and 21st, 1932. - Original on File 167-18-6.

I strongly recommend that the following be authorized in order that the above Manual Training class may complete the work on their own shop and do some very necessary repairs before the end of the fine weather this summer:

Shingles for wood shed, implement shed, and manual training shop.
32000 shingles, 100 pounds galvanized shingle nails - 1 1/8 in.
1200 ft. 1 inch by 8 inches shiplap.

I believe that it would be perfectly proper to charge this to our Special Vote as most of it is for the Manual Training class and the remainder will be used by the class in doing practical and very necessary repairs.

During the year, the boys have painted the interior of the rooms on the boys' side. This includes the dormitories and classrooms on this side. They have started on the girls' side but have not the necessary paint. The school asks for a grant of $75.00 for the necessary paint to finish the work. I most strongly recommend this. Much money has been saved to the Department by having the boys do this work and it is splendid training for them.

The barn is in a satisfactory state of repair, although it badly needs a new coat of paint. This may perhaps be put off for another year, as we are so short of money.

Sanitary Conditions:

In the boys' basement the recreation room reported in poor condition last year still has plaster off the walls and windows broken. The Principal informs me that he has the lumber necessary for the repairs to this room; but that the necessary work is far too big a job for the Manual Training Class to undertake. I agree with him in this. In my opinion, it will be necessary to employ an experienced carpenter to complete this work. The damage to this recreation room was caused by boys from the village for the most part, and occurred before the present Principal took charge of the school. I still do not consider that the Department should be called on to pay for the repairs to this room. The damage was obviously caused by lack of proper supervision.

Laundry
Laundry:- There are five double enamelled tubs, one rotary washing machine, one extractor and one hot air drier. A new heater for the laundry drier is urgently required. The present heater is now worn out. It is a Number 24 Peck Williamson Co. Cincinnati model. It is possible that some other form of heater made in Canada would be just as good. The heater supplies hot air to the drier, and is made to fit the hot air intake. I do not think that the Principal's idea of turning an old bakery, which has never been used as such, into a "Dry Room" is a satisfactory substitute and I prefer to recommend the supply of another heater as mentioned above.

I recommend that the school be given lumber, cement, and paint, sufficient for the construction of a modern chicken house 60 ft. by 15 ft. The materials would cost about $250.00 at the wharf at Sechelt, and the boys of the Manual Training class could erect the house under the direction of the Manual Training Instructor. As funds are so urgently required for several other recommendations made in this report, it might be better to leave this particular item till next year; but I do not wish the Department to take it from this that such a building is not necessary, as I am only suggesting that, owing to the lack of funds it may not be possible to do things that are badly wanted.

Electric Light:- An electric light bulb should be placed on each landing of the fire escapes. Teachers should have electric torches at hand in case the lighting system broke down during a fire. It is very dangerous to practice Fire Drills at night without some light on the wooden fire escapes. Repairs were necessary on the lighting plant during the past year. A short circuit burned out a resistance coil and a number of fuse boxes (?) The repairs cost $96.00 and were done by the Jarvis Electric Co. of Vancouver. This is one of the necessary expenses which I consider the Department might well bear the cost of, and which I would recommend that the school be reimbursed for. The electric light plant appears now to be working properly.

EXTRACT from Commissioner Ditchburn's Letter of June 6, 1932, enclosing above report. - Original on File 167-18-6.

He also made recommendations in regard to the repayment to the Principal of moneys spent by him in the purchase of a horse and harness, repairs to the electric lighting plant, etc. Apparently the Principal applied to Mr. Indian Agent Ball for the materials mentioned and repayment of funds expended. Agent Ball informs me that the Department had refused to authorize the expenditure in connection with the shingles, etc., as well as the mattresses, but I may say of course the Department was not aware of the School Inspector's report in connection with the several items.

1. Roof repaired and re-painted ------------ $454.60,
2. Water system connected with Union Estates system, fire hydrants and hose supplied ----------------- $1,830.12,
3. Sewage disposal works constructed ------- $566.90,

6. Paint supplied for interior work -------- $154.12,
7. Paid $186.75 hospital expenses of tonsil operations unauthorized by Dept. also grant to the M.O. for the work of about --------------------- $200.00,
8. Paid for dentistry work for pupils ------ $287.00,
9. Paid Medical Officer for special examination of the children ------------------ $50.00,
10. Paid for installing shower baths, new urinals, etc. at school ------------------ $490.27,
11. Lumber supplied for playroom ------------ $50.00,
12. Fire bells installed ---------------------- $37.20,
13. Fares are paid for children going to hospital and Dept. will consider reasonable accounts for their travelling expenses home. Paid in June, 1931, ----- $13.00, (No record kept of these items).

15. Unlimited drugs ------------------------ $6,087.49.

Indian Affairs (RG 10 Volume 6460, file 887-5, part 5)
The following requests were made either to me or to Mr. Ditchburn, the Principal erroneously complaining that I am preventing him from obtaining them.

1. Shingles for the woodshed, implement shed, manual training room etc.
2. Shiplap, nails, galvanized iron, place not specified,
3. 30 mattresses to replace worn ones in use at present.
4. Fares to hospital of pupils going to Vancouver for treatment.
5. Payment to and from their reserves of pupils going home (presumably for holiday).
6. Payment of hospital accounts and other expenses of pupils sent to Vancouver without authority for tonsil operations.
7. Re-payment to the Principal for a horse and harness.
8. Repayment of repairs to electric light plant.
9. Repayment of fares travelling expenses, etc., paid last year taking children back to school from holidays.
10. A new wagon for the school.
11. New chicken houses.
12. A launch for school use.
13. Two milch cows.
14. Linoleum throughout the corridors.

There are others which have escaped my memory for the time being, but the Principal is insatiable.

With regard to No. 4, I have already advised Father Maillard that the Department pays such fares and we have done so. I do not know why this is included in his list to Mr. Ditchburn.

No. 5 will also be given attention if accounts are sent to me for any children travelling by public conveyance. Most of them are taken home by their parents.

No. 6 has already been dealt with by the Department.

No. 13—The Department offered to purchase one cow if Father Maillard would purchase the other, but this offer has never been accepted.

No. 12 was never recommended and is totally unnecessary.

No. 14 was recommended to you and refused.

Fruit and vegetables are grown at the School and there......
there is ample room for chicken raising, but the soil is not good. Wholesale prices of flour, meat and all other commodities are the lowest for years and Father Maillard's predecessor managed the school when prices were considerably higher, and never referred to it as a "poverty stricken school" as Father Maillard does continually. If he can not run this school on the allowance granted, the solution would be to find a Principal who can. We have spent over $6,000.00 in something over one year in improvements at this fairly new school. The other Residential School in this Agency is a very old structure and should have consideration ahead of Sechelt in future. If the Department is unable to provide funds for the whole list of fourteen items shown above, I do not know which ones to recommend as being most necessary.

I note that extra transportation costs are given as a reason why the School should receive special consideration. The cost of shipping from Vancouver to Sechelt is as follows, the School being near the Union S.S.Co. dock at Sechelt:

- Vegetables: 20¢ per 100 lbs.
- Groceries (crated): 20¢
- Meat, fresh: 60¢
- Feed: 17-1/2¢

Dear Sir:

Re Sechelt Indian School

At the request of Rev. Father Maillard, we have made
2 trips to Sechelt to repair the electric lighting plant.

We find the plant in bad condition and respectfully tender
the following report.

Generator: (1)
The commutator on the generator is badly worn down causing
severe sparking and excessive wear on the brushes.

There are 2 remedies for this condition, namely to turn down
and undercut the commutator or to install a new commutator.
We believe that turning the commutator down would be
satisfactory for several years more wear.

(2). The generator bearings are well worn and should be renewed.

(3). The brush holders should be repaired and new brushes supplied.

(4). The coils should be thoroughly cleaned out and repainted
with insulating compound and baked.

This would necessitate shipping the machine in to our shop.
The work would require about 3 days time.

The total cost would be including freight to and from Vancouver
seventy five dollars ($75.00).

Batteries:
This set consists of 56 cells, 25 plate storage battery with
thin type auto battery plates and not the proper type for
lighting service.

They will not hold a full charge because the plates are
crumbling and in many cases buckled and insulators are cracked.

Dear Sirs:

Re: Inspection of Boilers and Machinery,
Indian Residential School, Sechelt, B.C.

On July 11th, 1933, I made an inspection of the mechanical plant of this school, which consists of:

Two large sectional boilers
One vertical tubular boiler used for the laundry.
One Diesel Engine and storage battery.

BOILER NO. 43561 B.C.

I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found it well kept. I then gave it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs., and found everything perfectly tight. I adjusted the Safety Valves to blow off at 10 lb. pressure. They are working free. The fusible plug is to be renewed and the water glass and valves repacked. The steam gauge is 1 lb. light. Boiler was built in 1924.

BOILER NO. 43560 B.C.

On the same day I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found it in good condition. I then gave it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs., and found everything quite tight except the glands of the water gauge and test cocks. These must be repacked. The steam gauge quadrant appears to be broken and a new steam gauge must be installed. The fusible plug must also be renewed.

I have issued a certificate for both the above boilers, allowing a steam pressure of 10 lbs. and condition good.

BOILER NO. 6504 B.C.

This is a vertical tubular and is used to supply steam to the laundry. I gave this boiler a careful internal and external inspection and found it in good condition.

The construction of this boiler is not good and none are now made; the long joint is single riveted lap. The present construction is either single or double butt joint. The fusible plug is inserted in the tubes instead of the plate.

The tubes are getting quite thin in the top head and will need

The manual training class is quite capable of carrying out the lining of the upper part of the walls of the boys' basement, which I recommended in my last report. Nothing has been done yet; the walls are still in a terrible state as far as the upper parts are concerned. Some form of Lamatco or Beaverboard, or Three-ply wood should be used. The material might well be supplied by the Department. Reference is requested to my last report on manual training at this school. I am not repeating the information given in that report.

In the Sisters' dining room the leakage in the wall reported previously became much worse through the bursting of a steam pipe. The plaster of the end wall of this dining room is down. The lath work is breaking away. The lath work needs to be replaced over a section of perhaps 100 square feet and the wall requires to be replastered. The same type of work requires to be done on the other side of this interior wall, in the primary classroom. There is a large opening now between the Sisters' dining room and the primary classroom. I do not understand why such a condition is allowed to exist, regardless of who is responsible for the payment for repairs. There is some doubt in my mind that the Department should be called on to pay for this repair. I do not know of course if the Indian Agent reported this to the Department. I have the honour to request that this wall be repaired as soon as possible.

There are only two toilet bowls on the boys' side in the basement. These are of course more used than the upstairs toilets. There are about 30 boys. It will be easily seen that the toilet accommodation is not sufficient. When I have to report that one of these toilet bowls is quite out of commission through a completely blocked pipe, it will be apparent that a very serious state of things exists. The Principal informs me that everything has been done to clear the drain pipe, which runs under the basement floor. They have used hose pipes to supply water under pressure. This is, of course, about the worst thing they could have done. It is evident to me that there is a block of paper or some cloth in the drain pipe which should be removed with a wire or draining cleaning apparatus. I would ask the Department to issue instructions for the immediate cleaning out of this toilet and drain, the matter being more or less urgent. I certainly consider that when drains are blocked like this, through what will probably prove to be carelessness and poor supervision, the entire cost of repair or cleaning should be borne by the school authorities, and not paid by the Department.

I also reported a year ago that a new set of batteries was very urgently required. I am sorry to have to report now that my advice was not taken, and only 30 out of 56 cells were renewed. There are still 26 cells to be replaced. By now some damage at least will have been caused to the new cells by working them with old cells. The Principal states that the old cells on March 1st will have been seven years in use. Why a complete set of battery cells was not provided at the same time, I fail to understand. The old cells are preventing the electric light plant working in a satisfactory manner, and if kept in this battery will ruin the new cells in a short time. I have therefore to request that 26 new battery cells of the suitable type be placed here to take the place of those cells now worn out.

The batteries for the lighting plant, Sechelt Indian Residential School, required renewal last year and thirty new cells were purchased and installed. The battery is a fifty-six cell outfit and the twenty-six old cells are now in such poor condition that they are damaging the new ones installed last fall.

This would indicate a difference of $132.79 in the price quoted by the Jarvis Electric Company, which is a considerable amount and cannot very well be overlooked.

I would be pleased to have your direction as to whether this order may be placed with the Bretell Distributing Company.

Boiler No. 43507 B.C.

On June 15th, 1934, I gave this boiler a careful
inspection and found it in a good condition. I then gave
it a hydrostatic test of 25 lbs. and found it perfectly
tight.

The steam gauge expansion tube was split but there was
a spare gauge there which I recalibrated and installed.
It is now correct.

The fusible plug must be renewed.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of
5 lbs. and condition good.

Boiler No. 43506 B.C.

On the same date I gave this boiler a similar inspection
and found it in first class condition.

The steam gauge is correct. A new water gauge glass is
required and a new fusible plug. The blowdown pipe is
in a fair condition.

I set the safety valves of both boilers to blow off at
5 lbs. water pressure.

The repairs pointed out in my last report have been
attended to.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure
of 5 lbs. and condition good.

Boiler No. 6504.

On the same date I gave this boiler a careful internal
and external inspection and found that many of the tubes
were quite badly pitted, also there was some on the
combustion chamber head and plates, but I do not anticipate
any trouble this year.
Boiler No. 6504 (Cont'd).

I then gave it a hydrostatic test of 50 lbs., and found one tube leaking on the top tube sheet. This must be rerolled.

The steam gauge is 2 lbs. light. The water gauge requires a new glass and packing. I set the safety valve to blow off at 25 lbs. water pressure.

I have issued a certificate allowing a steam pressure of 25 lbs. and condition good.

I would recommend that this boiler be allowed to last as long as it will without extensive repairs and when it requires retubing, which will be within two years, that a new boiler be procured as this boiler is much too small for the work required of it. These vertical boilers, in nearly all cases, are much too small and are not suitable for the work required of them and when replaced one of a submerged tube type should be installed.

whilst I was there the Principal of the school called my attention to the primitive method of drying the clothes, but under the present type of plant the only method which I could see to improve it would be to partition off a portion of the Chapel, which is above the boilerroom and cut two openings in the Boilerroom ceiling and enclose two ventilators which must have adjustable shutters so that when clothes are to be dried, they can be opened and the heat of the boiler-room allowed to go through into the new drying room, or install a new high pressure boiler and a new rotary drying machine in the laundry which is the better method, but more expensive.

I would also recommend that the following solution be used in all the boilers:

Mix 2 lbs. of Sal Soda with 4 gals. clear lime water.

Use about 1/2 pint of mixture to each boiler per week.

If a lime deposit appears on the fittings, reduce the amount of lime.

Blow down about 1/2" of water each day and keep vertical boiler dry when not in use. A new 1/2" injector should be installed on the vertical boiler.
Auxiliary Machinery.

The auxiliary machinery is generally in a fairly good condition and is well kept.

Whilst I was there some new batteries were being installed in the set. Some were installed last year and have been doing double duty. This is not good practice. When this set is done, I would recommend that consideration be given to a Batteryless set of Diesel Engines, similar to the set installed at Lejac School, which are both efficient and very economical.

The Cold Storage plant is in a fair condition, but will soon need a good overhaul. Unfortunately, the Agent who supplied the Compressor, I have been informed, is out of business and as there is no name plate the spare parts are hard to procure and perhaps a new Compressor may be required; but by the present appearances no repairs will be required this season.

Yours respectfully,

Sir:

I beg to report that the Sechelt Residential School has applied for a new range. In the School Inspector's report he recommends this, as the Reverend Principal is desirous of giving the pupils a more varied diet than is now possible.

The range in use is a three-oven "Canadian Lang" in fair condition, but this type of range is not suitable for burning wood, as the two outer ovens do not heat; it requires fuel burnt under pressure, either coal or oil, to give proper heat to all three ovens.

The one desired by the School is called the Malahat Albion heavy-duty with two ovens. The total cost of this range with warming closet and freight to Sechelt would be $250.00 approximately.

There has been much criticism of this school under the former Principal because of the diet of the pupils, and the present Principal is anxious to avoid such criticism in future. The School Inspector states that beans and similar foods are given too often, and the Principal would give more roast meat if he had a range to cook it. If this range is supplied, we could probably sell the present one to a logging camp where they are generally used. The hardware company occasionally has calls for them, so could sell ours possibly for $100.00 to $125.00, as they do not stock the three-oven range now.

I respectfully recommend the School's request for your favourable consideration.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Fred Ball]

Indian Agent.

Sir,

I beg to report that the batteries of Sechelt Indian Residential School lighting plant need renewing within the next few weeks, as it is necessary to run the engine continuously at present. Some repair work and overhauling on the engine will also be necessary. These batteries cost approximately $600, and are good for about four years.

In the past year, the Columbia Power Company has installed a lighting plant for Sechelt district covering about thirty miles surrounding that town and they offer us full service for $35 per month. This will include lighting at the school, barn, priests residence and staff house, and power for two motors in the refrigerator and laundry.

The boiler inspector reports as follows:

"The batteries are in a very bad condition and will need renewing before winter. I would suggest that consideration be given to purchasing power. If done, a small motor would operate refrigerator and also one for the laundry. Then the fire hazard of gasoline engines would be removed."

The present plant is 1-8 Horsepower Diesel Petter engines, with 66 batteries and a 3 Horsepower gasoline engine for the refrigerator, and another ½ Horsepower gasoline engine.

The running costs are approximately $120.00 per annum for fuel oil, $15.00 for lubricating oil and $100.00 for gasoline, so that the annual cost is $235.00 for fuel and approximately $150.00 for batteries or $385.00 against $420.00 for service from the power company. This does not include depreciation or repairs to engine, or the labour cost of engineer.

I consider it would be advantageous to purchase power both from the financial standpoint and also as the boiler inspector points out, the fire hazard.

We should require two small motors costing approximately $150.00 for the two.

With regard to the present engine, it would be quite suitable for Homalco Reserve where the Band is considering purchase of an engine for the village, they are already wired for it as they had a Pelton wheel which broke down many years ago. No batteries would be required there.
Under all the circumstances I respectfully recommend that the change be made.

If this is done, will you please advise me whether the school would pay for the light from their grant or will it be paid by the Department in addition to the grant.

Your instructions are respectfully requested.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[F. J. C. Ball]

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, regarding allowance on an old boiler at Sechelt Indian Residential School.

When the laundry boiler was replaced, the Vancouver Iron Works offer of $225.00, less allowance for old boiler, was accepted. No valuation could be set on the old boiler until it was brought to Vancouver and tested and when this was done, it was condemned by the boiler inspector as worthless, and the Vancouver Iron Works allowed us $10. as scrap iron.

According to the agreement with the Vancouver Iron Works of "$225.00 less allowance for old boiler" I considered it to be one transaction. The $10. allowance should have been deducted from the account, but they had not had time for the old boiler to be examined when they sent their account in for payment.

The above offer of $225.00 less the old boiler was authorized by your letter of October 13th, 1937, and considered to be the complete transaction, otherwise we should have advised the Vancouver Iron Works not to take the old boiler, but to leave it at Sechelt for instructions of the salvage officer.

I regret if there was anything in the above transaction which was contrary to regulations. I telephoned the Vancouver Iron Works this morning and they advise me their records show that the old boiler was sold to the Schwartz Junk Dealers for $8.00, at a total loss of $13.35 as they paid the freight from Sechelt to Vancouver.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters of the 22nd and 28th ultimo regarding electric light and power for Sechelt Indian Residential School. I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant regarding the refrigerator at the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

The reason I did not ask for the 1/3 H.P. motor and new refrigerator was that I felt the high cost would be prohibitive at the present time, and that the School could get along very well for a few years with the old refrigerator.

The price would be over $400.00 for a refrigerator of the required size. The present refrigerator would not sell for $50.00 as these old ammonia affairs are obsolete, and difficult to dispose of. The Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received this morning from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential school.

With regard to the drinking fountains, these are a health measure. The two I recommended and placed in Squamish Residential school last year have been worth a great deal to them, and the Reverend Principal there is most grateful for them. The cost was $51.96 for the material, and the school supplied the labour. There would be a slight extra cost for freight and packing if they are supplied to Sechelt School, and if funds are available, I would recommend it as a health measure.

I have the honour to be,

F.J.C. Ball.
Indian Agent.
Sir:

The enclosed accounts are forwarded to you under the following circumstances. Authority was received last year for connecting the Sechelt Residential School with the Columbia Power Company's light and power system, in place of the plant then in operation, and in need of batteries. The engine was later sent to Churchhouse for use by the Homalco Indians, as per your authority, and will be utilised there as soon as the expense of installing it has been approved, chargeable to Homalco Band Funds.

When authority was received from the Department to connect with the Columbia Power Company, I asked them for an estimate of cost, and was advised that it would be only a small amount, but they could not say exactly what work would be required until they reached the old plant which I authorised them to do. From that point, and without advising me, they took their instructions from the Reverend Principal who acted in good faith, of course, and thought the Company was authorised to do whatever he required. The gymnasium is in a separate building, and I did not know that it was being wired until after the job was completed. The Reverend Principal repaired and lined and re-floored the upper part of a big barn for a gymnasium, which is in continual use for basketball, roller-skating, etc., sports previously unknown at Sechelt School, and which have proved a great asset. The Reverend Principal did not know that he should have obtained authority for this work, and instructed the Power Company to do it.

The wiring in the school and staff houses was not up to standard for the Company's system, and much of it had to be re-wired to pass inspection. The Company claims that nothing was done unless it was absolutely necessary to pass inspection and that the labour of their own workmen, and the material is at cost price, plus 10%. They have itemized their account, and although it is higher than expected, I consider they have done the job as economically as possible, and the wiring, in the school buildings especially, is now safe. The Company states that they found open fuses which might have proved a fire hazard, and this has all been replaced by conduits. I have been over the whole job, item by item, and everything charged has been installed as stated. The account is now forwarded for your approval; it has been delayed since last year for various reasons, and the Company is now asking for an early settlement.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.
