Some time ago we discussed the question of some repair work which had to be done at the school here and you instructed us forward you the details of the work and an estimate on the cost. We have picked out the items which are of most importance and are forwarding them to you.

The first item is the repair of the furnaces in the school building. The grates in both furnaces are burnt out but the Boiler Inspector, Mr. Arnold advised us that it was not necessary to renew the grates. He said that if the floor and sides of the fire box were lined with fire brick it would give us just as good if not better results. I called in a brick layer from Robert's Creek and his estimate for labor and material for one furnace (which is all we need at present) would be $33.00.

I asked Mr. Morley for an estimate on the carpentry work to be done and it amounts to $80.00 for labor and I am forwarding the list of materials he would require.
I am sending along Mr. French's estimate on the painting work to be done.

There are a few other repairs to be made but we will be able to do some of them ourselves and the rest are not urgent. At present our workman is removing the moss from the roof of the school building and although it is quite heavy, it does not seem to have done any material damage to the shingles. The roof will not need painting for another year or two.

Hoping that you will be able to have this work done during the holidays, and that the details supplied are sufficient, I remain,

Sincerely yours,

Sir:

I beg to report that the batteries of Sechelt Indian Residential School lighting plant need renewing within the next few weeks, as it is necessary to run the engine continuously at present. Some repair work and overhauling on the engine will also be necessary. These batteries cost approximately $600 and are good for about four years.

In the past year, the Columbia Power Company has installed a lighting plant for Sechelt district covering about thirty miles surrounding that town, and they offer us full service for $35 per month. This will include lighting at the school, barn, priest's residence and staff house, and power for two motors in the refrigerator and laundry.

The boiler inspector reports as follows:

"The batteries are in a very bad condition and will need renewing before winter. I would suggest that consideration be given to purchasing power. If done, a small motor would operate refrigerator and also one for the laundry. Then the fire hazard of gasoline engines would be removed."

The present plant is 1-8 Horsepower Diesel Petter engine, with 56 batteries and a 3 Horsepower gasoline engine for the refrigerator, and another ½ Horsepower gasoline engine.

The running costs are approximately $120.00 per annum for fuel oil, $15.00 for lubricating oil and $100.00 for gasoline, so that the annual cost is $235.00 for fuel and approximately $150.00 for batteries or $385.00 against $420.00 for service from the power company. This does not include depreciation or repairs to engine, or the labour cost of engineer.

I consider it would be advantageous to purchase power, both from the financial standpoint and also as the boiler inspector points out, the fire hazard.

We should require two small motors costing approximately $150.00 for the two.

With regard to the present engine, it would be quite suitable for Holman Reserve where the Band is considering purchase of an engine for the village, they are already wired for it as they had a Pelton wheel which broke down many years ago. No batteries would be required there.
Under all the circumstances I respectfully recommend that the change be made.

If this is done, will you please advise me whether the school would pay for the light from their grant or will it be paid by the Department in addition to the grant.

Your instructions are respectfully requested.

Sir:

I beg to advise that the enclosed request has been received from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School for repairs to the school building.

The chief need is for repairs to the roof. The moss is a fire hazard in the dry months, and should be removed. Until this is done, I cannot say in what condition we shall find the shingles. It is difficult, therefore, to give an estimate of cost. The kitchen roof must be reshingled, but this will be a minor matter, costing approximately $50.00.

I would suggest, therefore, that, if any funds are available for repairs at this School, an estimate be obtained in detail for each job, but until the question is settled regarding payment of the electrical work ordered by the school I presume no funds will be available for repairs for the present.

In June, 1930, the roof was repaired, all cracked and broken shingles replaced, moss cleaned off and the entire roof shingle-stained, at a cost of $350.00 for labour and material, almost equally divided. At that time, the then Reverend Principal applied for new shingles for the roof, but I suggested cleaning and staining as the shingles were only 8 years old, and they have lasted over 9 years longer. It is probable that after 17 years, they may be in bad shape, as the moss is destructive, and in this climate, cannot be avoided.

An amount of $17.64 included in the account in question was spent by the company for Indian labour.

The wiring, etc., done by the Company at the school was carried out by experienced workmen and is regarded as satisfactory.

Referring to the penultimate paragraph of your letter, my opinion is, and such is all that I can give in the absence of corroborative information, that Mr. Ball did instruct the company to proceed to make the necessary connection to the school to supply power, but did not intend this authority to extend to the new wiring, repairs and extensions in the school buildings, which the company proceeded to do at the request of the principal and on the assumption that the authority given by Mr. Ball did include such work.

RECOMMENDATION:

As the amount involved is about what the Department would have paid for a new set of batteries, which would have been required for the school plant had the change over not taken place, and, as the maintenance costs of the school's plant hitherto borne by the Department have been eliminated as a result of the change over, thus effecting a saving to the Department, and further that changes were necessary in the wiring to pass provincial inspection, I would recommend payment of the company's account less the 10% charge on "overhead and profit." This deduction would amount to $44.87, and in my opinion is not a fair charge against the Department, inasmuch as we could have purchased the materials at wholesale rates ourselves and secured competent labour at the same rate per hour or less than the company paid.

In conclusion...
In conclusion I should like to observe that this particular case has taken time that should have been available for other work and involved expense that would not have been necessary had very ordinary precautions and business methods been employed from the beginning in dealing with the matter.

I was not advised by the Department of the proposed changes nor asked to pass upon them. Had this office been consulted in the matter, as it might well have been and in my opinion should be in such matters from an administrative point of view, the results would have been satisfactory both to the Department and the company.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Ball:

It is unfortunate that conditions prohibit the outlay necessary to recondition our plumbing in the school, since it is in a serious state of disintegration. However, we can fully understand the difficulties with which the Department must be faced at the present time, and we will do our best to carry out repairs in so far as we are able until such time as these materials are available.

The following articles are the most essential:

1 bbl. roofing tar for kitchen roof
100 ft. galvanized tin down pipe 3"
1 pipe reamer
1 pipe wrench 12"
5 gals. green roofing paint.

Mr. Stanton, the manual training instructor, is being retained by us for the summer vacation period to do this work and he has a suggestion to make regarding the staining of the main roof. When you come up again we can discuss the matter with him.

Yours sincerely,

"E.J. Cornell," O.M.I.
Principal
Sir:

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School. He sent me a long list of plumbing supplies which amounted to several hundred dollars, which I could not recommend, but the repairs mentioned are an immediate necessity to protect the building (except the green roofing paint). The down pipe has rotted away and the rain runs down the side of the building, which is of brick, and causes some dampness inside.

The cost would be approximately $30.00 delivered to Sechelt, including freight, and I understand the labour is free.

With regard to the last paragraph of the letter, the roof was re-shingled recently, but has not painted. I discussed with the Reverend Principal the matter he refers to. The man mentioned, Mr. Stanton, says he can make an oil stain or shinglozen for about $25.00 sufficient to cover the new shingles, and the portion of the building for which he asks for five gallons of green roofing paint. It is a debatable question whether shingles are made more enduring by painting, although, of course, the appearance of the building is much improved by staining.

I quite understand the difficulty of providing funds for any purpose, and will not send any applications to the Department unless they are to save more expense later.

I respectfully recommend that the above expenses be authorized.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Sir:

re: File No.167-18-5

With reference to your letter of the 13th instant I cannot understand what you mean by saying that I should have supplied detailed information regarding the type of boiler required by Sechelt Residential School.

This information was contained in the letter from the School which accompanied mine of the 8th instant and which stated that it is a 100-gallon upright boiler with standard openings, two on top, one in the side and one at the bottom.

Possibly the word "boiler" is a colloquialism for hot water tank - it is a receptacle connected with the kitchen range for heating water used in the kitchen and other domestic offices at the school.

When I visited the School recently the Principal showed me where it had been repaired several times. On the last occasion it burst late at night, causing much alarm and confusion among the staff.

The 100-gallon boiler, or tank, actually contains 77 Imperial gallons and the price in Vancouver is $50.10 for the standard and $57.10 for extra heavy galvanized iron. There would be no labour cost involved and as this is a necessity, I would recommend that it be supplied.

Aug. 29th, 1941

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I am enclosing a copy of a list of recommendations for repairs at the school here which I submitted to the Department last year through our Local Agent Mr. Ball. To date I do not think that any steps have been taken to have these repairs done and as I think that many of these are urgent for the upkeep of the buildings, I am taking up the matter with you with the hope that you will be able to have this work done. I should like to make a few further remarks in connection with the enclosed list.

1. Laundry -
   I think the proper thing to do about the Laundry, the condition of which is really disgraceful, would be to have it completely replastered. However, as expert labour would be required for this, it would possibly be as well if we were to give it one or two coats of extra heavy wall paint which work we could do ourselves. We would require about 15 gals of paint but it would have to be the heavy wall paint like that used on cement. We would also require about 10 gals of sizing. I think a light buff would be a suitable colour for the paint. We would also need about half a dozen brushes.

2. Roof -
   The roof over the kitchen, pantry and Laundry is flat and gravelled. The galvanized iron all around the edges is corroded and the rain leaks through to the ceiling and the walls. This would have to be repaired before we could repair the Laundry. About 75 or 100 ft. of 3 ft. galvanized iron would be required. We would also need a barrel of hard tar.

3. Floor -
   We have patched up the holes in the floor of the boys' recreation hall with cement and I think it will do for a while.

4. Manual Training shop -
   The shop is still an eye-sore for lack of paint. We would need about 10 gals of flesh tint exterior paint, about 1 gal of white and about 5 gals of shingle stain.

5. Toilet tanks -
   These have deteriorated still more and are urgently needed for sanitation. Eleven required.

6. Refrigeration Plant -
   We have done more work on this and although it is better, it still takes an excessive amount of power to keep the supplies cool.

7. Land clearing -
   We have not been able to make much headway with the clearing of our land and I think that a more practical plan to have it clear would be to hire a local bull-dozer which would cost about $50.00 an acre. We cannot afford to hire it and badly need the land for pasturage.

8. School building -
   Nothing has been done to stain the newly shingled roof of the main school building and I'm afraid it will deteriorate.
unless steps are taken to have it stained. I haven't any definite figure on the amount of stain required but I imagine it would take about 50 or 60 gals.

We are of course quite anxious to do all we can to see to the upkeep of the property but last year's cut in our Grant has made it impossible for us to undertake any of these major repairs and the best we can do is to supply the labour. The interior of the school itself is very much in need of a thorough paint job but as this has more to do with the appearance than any deterioration, I think this is one thing which can wait, in view of the present war effort. However if it would be at all possible to procure for us about 10 gals of cream wall paint and 10 gals of medium green wall paint we could make at least the main entrances more presentable to the many visitors we have here.

Hoping that you will be successful in obtaining these things for us and thanking you for past favours, I am,

Sincerely yours

J.M. McGrath O.M.S.
Principal

Sir:

re: Sechelt Indian Residential School.

With reference to repairs to the above school, there are two jobs which are urgently required to be done.

Owing to the change in Principals, this matter has been delayed and the season for doing the outside work is getting short. The laundry is in deplorable condition, and the roof above it must be repaired before the rainy season. This wing of the building has a flat roof and cannot be shingled. The following items are required:

**Material - For Laundry**

1 sack "Gilt Edge" plaster of paris  
1 " hydrated lime  
1 " cement  
4 gals. filler or sealing liquid  
8 " gloss, oil and lead paint

**For Laundry Roof**

1 roll heavy felt roofing paper  
1 bbl. roofing pitch (asphalt)  
4 sheets 4' x 8' 26 gauge galv. iron  
4 gals. white gasoline for torch

**Labour - 1. Taking off remaining plaster on west laundry wall, making good other walls and ceiling. Sealing (inside) the surface and give the whole laundry 2 coats of good paint ........................................ $75.00**

**Labour - 2. Repairing roof, tar and gravel, take off portion of iron all around parapet and insert new flashings, re-lay and put roof in perfect shape (gravel obtained free from beach). $65.00**

**FOR THE MAIN BUILDING:**

**Material - 150 lbs. Red Oxide dry**  
65 gals. boiled linseed oil

**Labour - Shingle staining whole roof of school....$75.00**

I have gone carefully into this question of repairs with the new Principal, and he agrees that this work is the most essential and is urgent. The former Principal, Rev. J.M. McGrath, was anxious to do this work before he left and
had tried to find someone capable of doing the job, which
the new Principal, Father Dunlop, and I have now done, and
he has given us the above figures for labour, which are
much lower than any figures obtained before; there is
no question that the work will be done satisfactorily.

Your early instructions will be appreciated.

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am submitting estimates on repairs necessary for the good maintenance of the Sechelt Residential School.

a) 11 toilets --------------------- $430.00
b) Refrigeration plant repairs --- $200.00
c) Paint interior ----------------- $150.00
   Exterior ---------------------- $30.00
d) Drain pipe for dairy --------- $50.00
e) Oil & Varnish for ext. doors -- $15.00
f) Land clearing ------------------ $600.00

Total $1,475.00

a) Re. Toilets: For several years the sanitary condition of the toilets has been quite bad. On one occasion since my arrival here, the toilets in the boys wash room overflowed, and before the condition could be detected and checked, the dirty water from the toilets seeped through to the room below which we had just finished redecorating, undoing most of our work, and finally reached the dining room, splattering one of the tables. The local plumber, Mr. Hoad, assures me that the toilets throughout the house are completely worn out, and because the make is old and obsolete parts cannot be obtained for them. I recommend new toilets throughout the house as an immediate necessity. Toilets which will not flush sometimes, and which will overflow at other times are a danger to the health of the children, not to speak of the damage they are doing to the plaster on the rooms below. The figure given would include the labor of putting them in.

b) Re. refrigeration plant. We are unable to keep meat for any length of time in our refrigerator, after ten or twelve days the meat becomes blue-mouldy. The insulation in the box has deteriorated, and some of the piping will have to be renewed.

c) Re. Paint; Practically every room in the house is in need of paint. We have redecorated a few rooms on our own accord but we could not begin to do them all. The following rooms in my estimation are in greatest need of paint; girls' side; recreation hall, sewing room, Boys' side; staircase, dining-hall, and dormitory. Exterior: The manual training-shop needs repainting.

d) Re. drain-pipe: There is no drain-pipe in our dairy, and as a consequence it is impossible to clean the floor properly.

e) Re. Oil and Varnish: There are three exterior doors which are exposed to the weather. These doors require oiling and varnishing.
f) Re. Land Clearing: There are ten acres of land adjoining the school which could be used for pasture if cleared. We have no pasture for our dairy stock. Unable to obtain tea for the children we have substituted milk. This has necessitated doubling the number of our cows. The price of hay is exceptionally high, especially here where the cost of freighting is great. It would undoubtably be a good investment to have this land cleared by means of a bull-dozer which could be had for $60.00 per acre. The land as it stands is of no practical use whatsoever.

In submitting the above estimates I have kept in mind two things. Firstly, the health and training of the children. For example, the toilet rooms which are damp for the most part are an excellent breeding ground for bacteria; and which despite our efforts to the contrary are often times quite odoriferous, cannot but be a menace to the health of the children. In training the children to desire what is clean and wholesome, it is apparent that their surroundings at school should excel in this very thing. Secondly, I have not overlooked the fact that the department is especially anxious during war time, to keep down unnecessary expenses since Canada needs all available monies to carry on her part in the prosecution of the present war. For these reasons I have submitted only those items which I feel to be absolutely necessary, and in all of them I have given the lowest possible figure, with the intention of using whenever possible our own labor.

Moreover, it would seem to be false economy to allow the buildings and surroundings to continue to deteriorate. If the cost of repairs is fourteen hundred now, it will surely not be less after the war when the government is struggling to readjust itself economically.

I realize I am late in submitting the above. However, I received my appointment here only in August. It was necessary to observe all the condition to determine what was of primary importance.

Enclosed please find two copies for your convenience in forwarding same to the department in Ottawa.

Yours very truly

H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I.
Principal.
Sir:

I am in receipt of the enclosed letter from the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Residential School. This building is the property of the Department.

The repairs listed are necessary, but I have not checked the cost, except for item (a) $430.00 which is approximately correct - if the materials can be obtained. This amount includes labour and materials. There is certainly an effluvia from these toilets at times, and the original installation was badly done.

The refrigerating plant has given trouble for some time, and the former Principal used to keep it going under difficulties. Until someone with a knowledge of such plants has checked up on it, I can give no close estimate of the cost, and I think the Principal's figure can be only an outside guess.

There is no question but that some painting should be done inside the building, and the exterior doors oiled and stained to protect them from the weather, but the figure shown can be scaled down, if necessary. Part of this painting and other work is due to damage caused by the toilets overflowing and seeping down to the floors beneath, including the refectory.

With regard to the land clearing, the 10 acres would no doubt make good pasture land for the cows which the former Principal purchased. He took over a Japanese dairy ranch near the School, and they use that for pasture also. The 10 acres is mostly covered with small trees and stumps and $600.00 should clear it for seeding to clover. A small part of the area has been cleared by the pupils and school employees but the work is too heavy for small boys.

I would recommend that, if at all possible, the above work be done, especially the plumbing work, which is a health consideration. The amount spent on this School has been very moderate in the past, and I hope you will give it your favourable consideration.

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

D.M. MacKay Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, enclosing Indian Agent Ball's letter of the 5th instant, requesting an expenditure of $1475.00 for repairs at the Sechelt Indian Residential School. This is the first intimation that the Department has received that such extensive repairs are necessary at this school. No such information was contained in the Indian Agent's estimates for the current fiscal year and consequently we only approved an amount of $100.00 for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Sechelt School. We have already authorized an amount of $350.00 and this was only possible by taking the excess of $250.00 from a small unallotted amount in our appropriation. The funds at our disposal will permit very little further expenditure, but on reviewing the matter I believe that we can allow another $200.00. You may decide on which of the items listed this amount should be spent. However, I may say that the Department does not favour spending any money at the present time for land clearing.

I beg to advise that the Reverend Principal of this School has requested some extra hose and two fire axes for fire protection. At the last fire drill, evacuation was made at night in 3 minutes, and a full practice carried out. The hose they now have did not reach all the buildings. Three extra lengths would give protection to the Council House and Church on the Reserve in addition to all the school buildings.

In the event of fire, there is no other assistance to be expected and they have an excellent fire-fighting team. At present they are making a hose reel as none can be purchased here.

This Reserve and School being on the Coast, there is some apprehension among the people that it might suffer from enemy action if mistaken for barracks or other military building, and their fears have been accentuated since the shelling of Estevan by a submarine.

I am placing the request before you for your consideration, although you advised me some time ago that fire hose was not available at that time. I presume the fire axes will be authorized as that is a small matter, and respectfully recommend that the hose also be supplied if possible. The size required is No.3, 2½ inches, 300 lbs. pressure, 3 lengths needed.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa,
November 24, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Re: Supplies, Sechelt Residential School

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received from Indian Agent Hall. The subject matter of this letter, you will note, is self-explanatory.

In this connection I should like to refer you to Departmental letter dated October 15, 1942. In view of existing conditions it is exceedingly difficult for the Department to provide supplies or undertake repairs at any of our schools, unless provision has been made for these supplies and repairs in the regular estimates. A great many repairs have been undertaken at Sechelt during the course of the year for which no provision whatever had been made.

We are naturally anxious, however, to do everything humanly possible to safeguard our buildings from destruction by fire. If you can secure the 3 lengths of hose which appears to be urgently needed, you are authorized to do so. The fire axes should also be purchased.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

An application has been submitted by Reverend Father Dunlop, O.M.I., of the Sechelt Indian Residential School, for some 70 sheets of paper wall-board for the windows of the school in order to comply with the new dim-out regulations now in force on the Pacific Coast. Material, such as was supplied to the Alert Bay Residential School, is available locally at an estimated cost of $88.20. I would recommend approval of the application, and, as the matter is urgent, would appreciate a reply by air-mail. Copy of Mr. Ball's letter, regarding the matter, is enclosed.

For your further information I am giving the following itemized account of the work to be done, included in the above figures:

1) Finish balance of wall in Junior Boy's play hall with V. Joint.
   Due to bad plaster part of the wall was done with V. Joint.
   The remainder of the wall is need of same now. -- $35.00

2) Gyproc Girls Sewing room. The plaster for the main part is beyond repair. Gyproc being less expensive, more durable, and obtainable -- $55.00

3) Finish balance of wall in Junior Girls play hall. The same condition exists as in the Junior Boy's hall --- $35.00

4) Vello Junior class room -- $36.00

5) Gyproc Senior Girl's Dormitory. The plaster is in very bad repair. Part has fallen, and a great portion is quite loose -- $70.00

8) Vello and repair Senior Boy's class room -- $50.00

year's appropriation, it is possible that we may be
able to allow another $100.00 or $150.00 later in the
year, when we are more fully aware of our commitments
at other schools.

portion of the Principal's letter, in which he refers to
the floors in the four play halls. We have recently
examined plastic tile, manufactured by the Storror
Manufacturing Company, Weston, Ontario. This can be
laid over concrete floors, and it is evident from the
floors that our officials have examined that the dust
nuisance is stopped. I am writing to the firm mentioned
and requesting them to communicate with you, giving you
full particulars regarding the material and its cost.
Possibly you are aware of other material that would be
satisfactory, but I thought you might like to know of
this firm's product.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

re: Sechelt Residential School.

With reference to the allowance of $500.00 granted for repairs to Sechelt Indian Residential School, the original requisition, dated May 27th 1943, showed a list amounting to $1365.00. When you advised me that only $500.00 would be available, I went into this matter carefully with the Reverend Principal to see which jobs required attention first and we agreed upon the following:

1. Replacing old fire escape on west side of the building as ordered by the fire inspector - $75.00. (This is imperative because the old escape is unsafe and could not be used in case of fire).

2. Flooring the two lower floor rooms on the boys' and girls' side - $225.00. (These rooms are cement floored and dampness has broken up the cement. The only solution is a wooden floor on tarred joists).

3. Repairing the walls and giving them a coating of "vello" of a similar casein paint - $100.00

4. Repairing the refrigeration plant - $100.00.

Total cost .......$500.00.

This latter job was not included in the original estimate of $1365.00, but was vitally necessary to protect the meat, milk, and other perishables when school re-opened. This job has been completed and bills sent in.

Items 1 and 2 are being done at the present time. It has been a difficult task to obtain both material and labour but this has been overcome and the work is well under way. These figures include labour and material.

After these jobs are completed, there are many places where the plaster has fallen off and should be repaired, and
considerable interior work of this kind should be done. However, a priority painting job is that on the main fire escapes. Unless these are protected from the weather, they cannot be expected to last long.

I would recommend that these fire escapes be painted as soon as funds are available, the cost would be $125.00 for labour and material, including the painting of the new fire escape mentioned previously.

Four panic locks are required on the fire escape doors. At present the doors have to be kept unlocked and this permitted an intoxicated Indian to enter the girls' dormitory at 1 a.m. last winter. These locks should be installed at a cost of $60.00.

All the dormitories require repairs to the plaster and a coat of vello, not only for appearance, but for reasons of cleanliness. It is not easy to give the exact costs in work of this kind, but the nearest estimate for labour and material that I have been able to obtain is $45.00 for each room, or $270.00 in all.

There is considerable plaster repair work to be done in the halls and if this is done, the halls will also have to be given a coat of vello. Some varnishing will also be necessary and the cost would be approximately $350.00.

The Reverend Principal was anxious to have the manual training building near the school given protection against the weather by painting. It has never been painted, and would require considerable paint and oil. Vello would not be suitable here. It would cost $145.00 to do this job. The original estimate by the Principal was $120.00 but it would require three coats, whereas he figured on two only.

To sum up, the cost, in order of importance, of work above the $500.00 already allotted would be as follows:

| Item                          | Cost   |
|-------------------------------|--------|
| Painting all fire escapes     | $125.00|
| Panic locks                   | $60.00 |
| Repairs to dormitories        | $270.00|
| Repairs and renovations of halls | $350.00|
| Painting manual training building | $145.00|

Total........ $950.00

I would appreciate advice as to what items shown above can be provided for in addition to the work being done at present.

Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

re: File No.215-14-7864

With reference to your letter of November 5th last authorizing a total of $1305.00 for repairs, renovations, etc. at Sechelt Indian Residential School, all the necessary material was purchased after much delay on account of shortages, etc., and the work has been proceeded with as expeditiously as possible, but on account of the lack of suitable labour progress has been slow. We have had only one man working on the job. Fortunately he is able to do all the various jobs entailed in this project and has been most satisfactory in every way (I may say that when he is finished at the School, the Roman Catholic authorities have engaged him to build their own Church at Sechelt).

The point now is that we cannot finish before March 31st all the work authorized. To March 18th we have expended $853.40 leaving a balance of $451.60, for labour, all the material having been purchased. About $85.00 more will be expended in labour by March 31st. Will you please advise me what we should do, as I do not want the work left incomplete? There is keen satisfaction at the school with what we have done up to date, and it would be unfortunate if a matter of book-keeping is to stop further progress.

I would request also that the Department be asked (by air mail) for a further advance of $315.00 in order that wages may be paid to March 31st when all advances to date will be accounted for in the usual way. The man who is doing the work has been approached also by the Union S.S. Co. and several private individuals to do building and other work for them, so you will understand why I am anxious that we do not have to let him go.

An extra copy of this letter is enclosed and early action will be appreciated.

Indian Agent

B/DH.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Ball's letter of even date advising that owing to labour difficulties it will be impossible to expend the full amount provided for the repair of Sechelt Indian Residential School. While all the material has been purchased, there will be an unexpended balance in the labour account of $368.50 at the end of the month, it being impossible to complete the work within the current fiscal year. Mr. Ball requests that if at all possible this amount be provided for the carrying out of the work immediately on the opening of the new fiscal year in order that the man working on the repairs can remain on the job until it is completed as he feels that if this is not done it may be some considerable time before he will again be available or another man could be secured owing to the difficult labour situation.

I would recommend approval of this application if the money can be provided as requested. You advice by air mail would be appreciated.

For D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa,
March 24, 1944.

AIR MAIL

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O.

Re: Conditions, Sechelt Indian Residential School.

A few days ago the Principal of the marginally-noted school visited this office and while here discussed with me, at considerable length, certain administrative problems confronting him at the school.

The Principal spoke very highly of the Agent's interest in the school and the co-operation extended to him by the officials of the Department, generally. He was convinced, however, or at least appeared to be, that the amount of money placed at his disposal from year to year, for the construction of additional buildings, particularly a gymnasium, and to keep the main building in a proper state of repair, was in no sense adequate. In this connection I pointed out to him that the money at our disposal for the repair and purchase of equipment at Indian residential schools, since I entered the Department, had never been sufficient at any time to meet the demands for expenditures sent in by principals from year to year. I did assure him, however, that in reviewing our estimates, the same consideration was given to the Sechelt School and to its needs that was given to our other schools.

The Principal is of the opinion that a gymnasium at this school is a matter of extreme urgency. On wet days there is no place for the youngsters to pay, with the result that when kept indoors they are exceedingly difficult to manage. In addition to this, he informed me that very few vegetables, if any, were grown at the school. This
necessitates the shipment of vegetables, cattle feed and indeed all the supplies required from Vancouver, which fact adds substantially to the cost of operating the institution.

I am particularly anxious that we should do everything humanly possible to keep our better schools, such as Sechelt, Kuper Island, Alberni, and others that might be mentioned, from deteriorating rapidly. I have already asked you to make a survey of conditions at Alberni, and I have been wondering if you or the agent could not undertake a somewhat similar survey at Sechelt. Mr. Phelan informs me that there is a large barn at Sechelt. It would be interesting to have a report from you on the necessity of this barn, if the school farm or school lands are incapable of producing the food necessary to maintain stock. Would it be possible to turn this barn, or a portion of it, into a playground for the male pupils? It will be appreciated, of course, that this is a suggestion made by one who is wholly unfamiliar with local conditions. The suggestion, therefore, may be wholly impracticable. I am deeply interested, however, in our school buildings, and I want to state quite frankly that unless we can secure more funds for the repair and upkeep of these buildings, it will be exceedingly difficult, in the period immediately ahead of us, to maintain them in a state of efficiency. It would be deeply appreciated, therefore, if we could have from you or from the agent a very frank expression of opinion on the condition of this school, its buildings and the general administrative setup.

I may add that there is available for repairs at this school during the present fiscal year the sum of $600.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I wish to make a strong appeal that the amount of monies asked for be granted. As has been brought to the attention of the department, this school through lack of a sufficiently large yearly grant for upkeep in the past, has fallen into a rather poor state of repair. Unless the full amount asked for be granted we are bound to fall behind once more in this very necessary work.

It is evident that a building this size requires constant attention, not only for the protection of the health and wellbeing of the children but for economy's sake as well. For example the repairs for the kitchen ($80.00) has been brought about by a leaking roof. Again we find several boards in the fire escape completely rotted due to lack of paint. It is patent that lumber exposed to Pacific Coast weather must be repainted at regular intervals.

As this is a government building -- a taxpayers investment, entrusted to the care of the Oblate Fathers I feel a very serious obligation to see that their investment be protected. It can only be protected by constant attention to repairs and with sufficient means to meet these repairs.

I wish to express my gratitude for the great amount of work we were able to accomplish through the cooperation of your office in the past year.

Enclosed please find two copies of estimates.

In your letter of the 25th September last regarding repairs to Sechelt Residential School, it was mentioned that $600 had been authorized. An extra $50.00 was allowed when the fire escape was found to be in a dangerous condition.

This money has been expended and considerable work done which we had no means of determining in advance. For instance, in painting the window frames, it was found that the window sills on the south side of the school were mere shells, all the wood having perished, and only the painted outside of the sills remained. With the slightest pressure, these sills crumbled and we had to replace them with cement sills. This meant extra expense, which could not be foreseen.

In repairing the fire escape, some massive looking pillars holding up the 2nd and 3rd floors were out of alignment and on examination the bases were found completely rotted. These also were repaired with concrete. A heavy load on either floor might have caused a collapse of what looked like a solid structure.

These are only a few items, but many others could be mentioned. Only where such conditions rendered them unsafe were repairs made.

The amount authorized has been slightly over-expended but we have had to omit repairing the refrigerator which was included in the original estimate. The walls of this plant have been holed by rats and the fumes from the plant escape into the refrigerator. The solution is to rebuild the refrigerator itself and have it placed in the main school building instead of in a shed by itself. The machinery can remain in the shed and the pipe brought underground to the new site - a distance of only a few feet. I have asked for an estimate of this work, which I hope will be allowed.
The over expenditure referred to amounts to approximately $75.00 and I trust that a further advance will be forwarded as it is required for wages. I have stopped all further work on the School pending your instructions.

You will have received a report from Mr. James Coleman, Inspector of Indian Agencies, who accompanied me to Sechelt to see the work which has been done there. For the small amount allowed, we have done major repairs and renovations at low cost only because we were fortunate in having a conscientious and practical workman in the person of Mr. Henry Hoad to do the work.

The following work is only part of what he has done:

- New Floors laid in boys and girls play room and in sewing room.
- Concrete floor laid in boys' lavatory and approaches. Several toilets repaired.
- All passage ways, dormitories, class rooms, two sick rooms, dining rooms, laundry, etc., renovated.
- All outside wood-work painted, including several dozen windows.
- Window sills renewed and painted.
- New fire escape built and old fire escapes repaired.

Under some circumstances, such work might cost several thousand dollars and several different tradesmen would be required to do it. I may add that Mr. Hoad did most of the work in designing and building the new Roman Catholic Church at Sechelt, and the Church authorities want him to build another Church at Gibson's Landing. He is non-Catholic and there is no question as to his ability and integrity, otherwise he would not be employed by them.

Will you kindly convey these facts to the Department, and request a further advance of, say, $100.00 so that the balance of wages can be paid for the work done so far?

MEMORANDUM TO:

The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From the Inspector of Indian Agencies

Re: Skehalt Indian Residential School

In accordance with your instructions pursuant to the Department's request of July 10th, 1944 (File 167-16-5) I proceeded to Skehalt Indian Residential School on September 19th, 1944, to Mr. Indian Agent Bell, returning the following day, to make a survey of conditions at the school and report on the necessity of a school gymnasium and farm operations. It is apparent that routine annual maintenance was not kept up and as a result deterioration of the school proceeded to the point where its restoration became imperative and costly. Some of this work has been overtaken during the past two years.

Gymnasium: As this is what apparently gave rise to the request for a report I will deal with it first. The reason given for building is that weather conditions necessitate keeping the children under cover most of the time. With this I do not entirely agree. Weather conditions are about the same as Alert Bay, North Vancouver, Mission and other Residential schools on the Coast. However, there is no doubt that a gymnasium is very desirable if funds can be provided.

An attempt was made to convert the hay mow of the school barn into a gymnasium without much success as it can never be entirely cleared of old hay dust and the gambrel roof trusses present a hazard. There is no access for light and the electric lights are inadequate. There appears to be very little equipment. About all that can be said of it is that it is better than nothing for this purpose but on the other hand, the school stock are still housed in the lower part of the barn and the hay mow is essential to their needs.

A photograph of the barn is attached and also one of the combined manual training shop and laundry drying and ironing room, housed in a very old building that is practically falling apart. The laundry is on the ground floor. The stairway entrance to the manual training shop is shown on the photograph and as it was the only escape the laundry operations underneath created a dangerous fire risk. I advised the acting principal, Father Murray, in the absence of Father Dunlop, to install a ladder escape from one of the windows but the use of the building should be discontinued and it should be torn down to prevent its use for some other purpose equally hazardous to the children.

Apart from a gymnasium, the school needs an auditorium which is now provided for by the conversion of two of the class rooms for this purpose which, consequently, are not available for educational work. Projection of motion pictures has been arranged for by cutting a hole in one of the class room walls and setting up the projector in an adjoining room. A stage has also been set up in one of the class rooms, which open into each other by a large sliding or folding door.
The manual training shop, gymnasium and auditorium could all be combined under one roof. Basketball and badminton would be desirable exercises and the minimum floor space requirements would be 55' x 75' or 55' x 65' if a stage at one end were included. Probably in the interests of safety and speedy evacuation the ground floor would be preferable for the auditorium and the manual training and boat building shop located on the first floor, with a ramp for taking out large boats. Lumber and material could be stored in the attic. The cost would probably run to at least $17,500 depending on finish, labour arrangements, etc., if and when that amount of building material could be made available, as the priority would not be very high, although Indian Agent Hall advises that he can secure it. I would recommend provision of this building when funds are available and subject to prior needs at this school.

I am not in favour of extensive farming operations at Indian Residential schools for the reason that sooner or later a Principal will be tempted to exploit the pool of child labour available in the institution. If the schools offered a definite course on agriculture to the pupils, the farms would be of great value, but from my observations the training is largely confined to hoeing, pitching hay and milking, etc., with no class room work or discussion of the principles of farming. I consider the problem in general is one that calls for careful investigation, review and direction by the Department.

The stock and implements at this date consist of:

- 5 milk cows
- 3 beef cattle
- 2 sows
- 1 boar
- 1 horse (no harness)
- 75 hens (estimated)
- 1 disc harrow
- 1 harrow
- 1 plough
- 1 cultivator
- 1 wagon

The school site and grounds cover a lot of 4.4 acres, with 10.6 acres of partly cleared pasture at the back of the school, all being within the boundaries of Seehelt Indian Reserve No. 1. It is reported that the school was given the use of the 10.6 parcel by the Band on February 17, 1915.

The barn is in need of some minor repairs and repainting at a probable cost of about $200.00.

The poultry house shown on the photograph attached is a most ramshackle structure that should be torn down and replaced. Actually it is just outside the easterly boundary of the 4.4 acre lot, on a small lot apparently set aside by the Band for the missionary's residence, which it is stated was built in 1925 by the Band or the Department. As poultry keeping should be a training project, the old chicken house should be torn down as it is a disgrace, and a new standard type of house built on school property, complete with deep nests etc., for which the cost of material would probably amount to about $200. The construction should be carried out by the pupils, under supervision, as a project.
The school, or Oblate Fathers, are reported as owning or leasing a fair sized farm, formerly Japanese property, near the school, but no details could be secured. I am informed animals are not employed on it. Apart from this, I don't think the 10.6 acres could support more than two cows and then only with intensive cultivation. Probably two or three milk cows, a single horse, two sows and about one hundred hens will give the children all the training possibilities they require (they will not engage in farming after graduation) and provide the school with at least part of its milk and egg requirements. With this in view the barn would be necessary to the school farm.

An effort should be made to establish a school garden of at least an acre in order to train the children not only in cultural processes but in nutritional standards. With this in view a soil survey and soil improvement study should be made of any proposed garden site. The soils here are mostly lacking in nitrogen due to this essential requirement to growth being leached out by heavy rainfalls.

I will review briefly the condition of the buildings other than those already mentioned.

Main Building

Windows

These have either developed a shrinkage in width of about 5/8" or were badly fitted. Due to lack of maintenance painting the sash in many of them has rotted. There are 130 - 145 windows, all exposed to gales off the sea. The result is that the rooms facing the wind become practically untenantable and fuel costs are increased enormously. The remedy is overhauling and where possible refitting by splicing a strip on one edge of the sash as per sketch:

This could possibly be carried out on the manual training power tools by the carpenter usually employed by the school at somewhat less than anticipated by the Reverend Principal. The window panes should be properly caulked between the panes and brick work. The Principal's estimate is $650.00. Fuel savings will possibly pay for this work in two or three years.

Floors

The basement floors have been treated with some bituminous substance and are not very satisfactory. Some rooms have been covered with fir flooring. I consider one of the mastic floor coverings would have been preferable, especially in the kitchen where it is proposed to use ordinary fir flooring. I cannot estimate the cost at present but would suggest that it would not be less than $1000.00.

Kitchen Ceiling

Roof leaks need locating and repair and walls, which are glazed brick, repair and joints repainted. Probable cost, $100.00.
Cupboards
Require to be provided or repaired in kitchen, storeroom and sewing room. Estimated cost $500.00 by Principal.

Plumbing
A very poor job was made in roughing this in when the building was erected. The Principal would like to see it replaced by copper piping at a cost of $1000.00. It will probably come down to sundry repairs at a cost of $250.00.

Plaster
Broken plaster creates a fire hazard apart from the question of appearance. Repairs to the extent of about $100.00 required.

Interior Decoration
Some good work has been done in the past two years but there still remains the greater part to be done, which the Principal estimates will cost about $700.00.

Stair Treads
On the main stairways they are worn down to the risers. Repair costs will probably amount to $75.00.

Fire Escapes and Hardware
Two panic bolts are required for fire doors. Many door locks and knobs require repair and replacement. Estimated cost $100.00.

The wood verandah posts on fire escapes at each end of the building were rotten at the ends and collapsing. It is imperative that these be replaced as soon as possible. Will probably cost $200.00.

Heating
The plant requires investigating as it fails to heat the junior boys' dormitory and the senior boys' class rooms. Quite possibly repairs to windows and caulking will remedy the defect.

Window Shades
Are required for most of the windows and will cost about $45.00.

Furniture and Woodwork
Painting and revarnishing woodwork, beds and desks should be undertaken when possible at an estimated cost of $500.00.

Exterior
The brick used in construction of this building was rough and over-burnt, but well laid. The brick walls were not cleaned off on completion of construction.

There is evidence of leakage in the front wall on the left wing and requires some attention. It is difficult to estimate, but if condition is not extensive it would probably amount to about $200.00. The rain storms drive in from the sea and eventually work through weak spots in the masonry.
Exterior (Cont'd)

There is need for repainting of wood and metal work and this with other items likely to arise on closer investigation will probably run the cost up to at least $5,000.00, including replacement of eavestroughs which are badly corroded.

School Grounds

There is considerable room for improvement in the upkeep of the lawns and flower beds in the front of the school. No cost should be estimated for this.

Refrigeration

The plant is housed in an outbuilding at the rear of the school. The cooler walls are in need of reconstruction and exhaust filling replaced by more efficient insulator.

At the time of my visit the door of the building was open and there was no protection against injury to the children, the engine and compressor being without guards. I discussed this with Father Baxter and asked him to see that it was properly guarded. Cost of Reconstruction, etc., will probably amount to $150.00.

Barn

Construction commenced but not completed. Estimated cost to finish by boarding and painting is $95.00.

Dairy

At present a room in the school is used for this, but would be more desirable to have a separate building at a cost of $250.00.

Slaughter House

Slaughtering was being done in the barn, which is not good practice. If enough to warrant a building it should be installed. Estimated cost for material, $100.00.

Floor Coverings

The Assistant Principal suggested transferring unused linoleum from Alberni Residential School for use in this school.

Land Clearing

There still remains some land clearing to be done on the ten acre block, at an estimated cost of $600.00, if and when funds ever become available.

General

The trouble here is very similar to conditions at Cranbrook Residential School, a residential school and staff with a day school attendance. The quota is eighty, but only sixty-nine were attending at the time of my visit. The cost of maintenance is not proportionate to the pupilage when we compare it with the three hundred pupilage of Kamloops Residential School and the result is that these small schools cannot divert funds to proper maintenance and in consequence it costs more in the long run than if this was attended to every year.
The staff consisted of:

Father Dunlop - Principal
Father Baxter - Assistant Principal
Brother MacLeod
Sister Superior Anna Maria
Sister Angi - senior class teacher
Sister Josephine - junior class teacher
Sister Joseph Henry - children's cook
Sister Raphaela - staff cook
Sister Helen - sewing and laundry
Farm hand and engineer.

It is very probable that with the advent of "Children's Allowances" this, and other Residential schools, will have a great deal of trouble maintaining their quota of pupils and it might be advisable to note the trend at Bechet before expanding any very large amounts on repairs. A twenty percent decrease in school population would probably make it impossible to finance.

The children appeared to be receiving excellent physical care. I made no attempt to assess the academic work of the school.

Your File 167-18-5

I have to refer to your letter of July 10, 1944, regarding the Sechelt Indian Residential School. Following receipt of your letter arrangements were made for Inspector Coleman to inspect the school buildings and look into the question of the provision of a gymnasium. A copy of Inspector Coleman's memorandum dealing with these matters is attached.

It is true that with but a few exceptions our Residential School buildings have not been maintained in a proper state of repair. This is particularly evident with respect to the Kootenay, St. George's and Sechelt Schools on which substantial outlays will have to be made to meet existing needs. In preparing the list of worthwhile works that might be undertaken in this Province immediately following the close of the war, this matter was kept in mind and an amount of $7,500.00 included for each of these schools. No provision, however, was made therein for a gymnasium. It is only recently that this question has arisen. Father Dunlop's predecessors and those who have inspected the school in the past ten years either overlooked the matter or were satisfied that the existing facilities for sports and amusements were sufficient for the time being.

The barn at the school is needed for stock and the storage of grain and hay, and is, therefore, not available for conversion into a gymnasium. In any case, it is highly doubtful if it could be made suitable for such purpose without a large expenditure which could be used to better advantage towards the cost of an entirely new structure.
I am satisfied that the most pressing need is to carry out the necessary repairs and improvements to the main building and funds should first be provided for this purpose. I agree that a gymnasium is desirable and would recommend that an item providing for a suitable building be included in the post war programme of new construction. Accommodation for a gymnasium, manual training shop and also a laundry if the present accommodation isn't suitable might be provided in one building. The ground floor could be used for a gymnasium and auditorium and the basement for the manual training division and a laundry or other service. A building of the dimensions suggested by Mr. Coleman would at present costs of labour and material cost much more than his estimate of $7,500.00. I should say that $15,000.00 would be much nearer the amount required.

The construction of a suitable poultry house, also a dairy building and a slaughterhouse could be undertaken as manual training projects and should be proceeded with as soon as funds can be secured.

The administration of the school by Reverend Father Dunlop is reported to be satisfactory.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Ottawa, February 14, 1945.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, reporting on the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

I have discussed with Mr. Hoey your recommendations regarding future improvements at this school, and in our post-war program we are including an amount to cover the expenditure that would be necessary. However, our proposed expenditures on post-war work have not yet been definitely decided.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Sechelt Residential School

I have received the enclosed letter from the Rev. Principal of the above school.

Since Father Dunlop took over the principalship here he has rented a former Japanese dairy farm and has supplied the school with beef and pork from stock kept on this farm. He also keeps several milk cows and the pupils all receive milk with their meals.

They have hitherto done the slaughtering in the barn which was unsanitary and unsatisfactory in every way. Recently they were compelled by health authorities to erect a proper slaughterhouse. This will cost about $125.00 as it has to have a concrete floor and proper drainage, and the Principal asks that we pay something towards the cost. The amount of $50.00 would supply the lumber while the cement and other material and the labour would be paid from their grant.

Will you please advise if this request can be entertained.

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent

With reference to Mr. Phelan's recent letter advising of a balance of approximately $2300.00 unspent from the amount included in the B.C. Special Vote for technical education purposes, I enclose herewith Vancouver Agency Vouchers Nos. 561, 562 and 563 for $153.75, $113.05 and $84.00, respectively, covering the purchase of material and labour in connection with the extension of the poultry housing facilities at the Sechelt Indian Residential School. I beg to report that the refrigeration at Sechelt Indian Residential School has broken down completely and needs renewal. It is an old ammonia system, I believe it was put in the original school over 25 years ago. The pressure caused an explosion and they were fortunate that there was no fatality as the man who handled it was standing over the plant when it happened. This break was welded but immediately broke again in several places. There has been leakage from half a dozen places in the plant and the operator resigned as the ammonia fumes could not be controlled.

When the break-down occurred, the school had just killed and they lost half a beef before it could be taken care of. I visited the school on Monday, the 10th instant, and made temporary arrangements with the Union S.S. Store to give us refrigerator storage until Sept. 30th. The Union S.S. hotel closes for the month of October and they will let us use their refrigerator until October 30, although it is rather small for school purposes.

On the 11th a man was sent from Vancouver to look over the system to see what could be done. He sent the engine to Vancouver and they advise me this morning that there is absolutely no hope of repairing it and similar engines are not to be found now, as it is so much out of date.

I have contacted some local firms and the General Refrigeration Engineering Co., Ltd., of 83 Alexander St., Vancouver a subsidiary of Fleck Bros., Ltd., which supplies logging outfits, etc. appear to be the best available source, but they cannot guarantee delivery until mid-October at the earliest. Other firms are in even worse position.

The refrigerator box is in bad shape and should be renewed and placed in another situation altogether. It is at present in an old building which used to be the boys' dormitory in the original school, and is too exposed.

(over)
The figures I have obtained are as follows:

For a fully automatic water cooled 1 H.P. engine, completely installed with coils, etc. ........... $875.00

A new door for the refrigerator $75.00

Building a new refrigerator $250.00

This makes a total of $1200.00. The present system has a 2 HP engine in good condition and also fairly new coils which could be credited against this cost. A water-cooled 1 HP motor would be more economical and more satisfactory and the automatic system would save much labour time.

This company installed the Union S.S. store and hotel refrigerators and for that reason would be a convenience as they make regular inspections of both plants there, saving expense of bringing a man from Vancouver for inspection, etc.

The new refrigerator box costs $375.00 complete, in Vancouver, but we could save $75.00 on this by having the carpenter at Sechelt build it there, the only part which should be bought is the door.

This matter is an emergency as the food situation at the school is critical and after October 30th I do not know where we can find storage.

Presumably this is a problem for the Reverend Principal to solve, but he is completely at a loss as to what should be done.

Indian Agent

Dear Mr. Ball:

Wood has been used exclusively in this school both for heating and cooking since its erection. This wood has been obtained from the reserve lands. All the accessible wood has been cut down and it has become increasingly difficult and increasingly expensive to swamp out the year's fuel. Roads have to be made over rough terrain, equipment is continually breaking, and finally a horse has to be kept the year round for the hauling. In the beginning the wood was near the school and accessible, now it is distant from the school and hard to get at. It would lighten the expenses of the school and relieve us of a great deal of trouble and worry if coal were to be used. Evidently an automatic stoker is necessary if coal heating is to be economical.

An automatic stoker can be had from St. Augustine's Church in Vancouver for $200. This stoker cost $650.00 three years ago when wartime emergency required that institution to change from oil to coal heating. It is an excellent buy. Would the department consider purchasing it for the school?

Very truly yours,

H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I.

Replying to your letter of the 9th instant, I have gone carefully into the matter of changing the fuel at Sechelt Residential School from wood to coal.

The Reverend Principal gave several reasons for the change, viz., the increasing difficulty of obtaining suitable wood; the necessity of keeping a horse 12 months when it is used only 3 months of the year for hauling wood; the making of roads to new timber, etc., but in my opinion the strongest argument is that timber is being burned which is much more valuable for lumber. This should be conserved wherever it grows and of course the tendency is to cut it where it is more easily available.

We have an offer of an automatic stoker in perfect condition for $200.00. Coal could be sent up by scow and taken to the school by their truck. The steady heat of coal would be considerably better than wood, and I believe it would be a big saving of expense to the school.

Dear Sir:

ESTIMATES 1946-7.

1- GYMNASIUM: In submitting these estimates for 1946, I should like to bring to the attention of the department once more our dire need for a gymnasium in connection with the school. The long rainy periods of Coastal B.C. makes such an undertaking essential. For example, the past three days of the Christmas holidays have been days of continuous rain. Picture if you will, a large group of children cooped up in small play rooms for such a length of time with little or no outlet for their pent-up energies. A gymnasium, as all the inspectors who have been here in my time have recommended is not a luxury but an absolute necessity. Approximate cost ---------------- $12,000.00

2- WINDOWS: As pointed out last year the windows throughout the school are ill-fitting. This occasions a great deal of draughts and loss of heat. We have done what we could to tighten them up this year, but they need to be refitted and caulked. Cost ------------ $ 650.00

3- KITCHEN: The ceiling of the kitchen has been destroyed by a leaking roof. The masonry needs to be fixed ----- $ 90.00

4- CUPBOARDS: We need cupboards in the kitchen, the store room and the sewing room. The lack of same makes work difficult and gives the place an untidy appearance -- $ 600.00

5- EXTERIOR OF BLDG: The roof needs staining, the rain pipes are rusted away, allowing the water to seep under the foundation of the building, the outside walls need weather proofing as the moisture has been penetrating the walls on the weather side and has destroyed a good deal of the interior decorating we did a year ago. Cost ----------------------------- $ 2000.00

6- PLUMBING: The plumbing is more than twenty years old, as little has ever been done to it in the past it is in very bad shape. We are having continual trouble with it. The plumber is of the opinion that anything other than a complete renewal of all supply lines and fixtures would be a waste of time and money ------- $ 1000.00

7- BARN REPAIRS: The barn is in a very bad state of repair. This is understandable as nothing has been done on it for years. As pointed out in last years estimates this building, which is relatively a new building should be attended to right away, otherwise permanent damage will be done to it. The Secretary,

Re: Improvements at Sechelt Indian Res. School, B.C.
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Reverend Father Dunlop of the above school, has had during the last twelve months, a larger number of pupils than he is authorized to accept and it is desired that the pupilage be increased by 20. This latter number will take care of at least part of those children who are now clamoring to be admitted.

This school, as well as all the B.C. schools, due to war conditions, has been neglected in the matter of general repairs and I suggest that the sum of $2,000.00 be placed to its credit in the coming estimates, for such purpose and that the principal be so advised through the Commissioner, so that he may plan for next summer vacation, for such work as he will deem most necessary for the good upkeep of his school.

The school library should receive some attention as it is very small and does not contain a sufficient variety of books to interest the children and to develop in them a taste for reading.

All B.C. schools situated on Vancouver Island and the Western shore of the province, have very wet climate and the recreation facilities provided in the basement of the schools are certainly not sufficient. The Sechelt School should have an outside gymnasium where the children, both boys and girls, could take their recreation on wet days and receive such physical training as is so essential for the

over.....
health of boarding school children. I do not know how much such a building would cost but a frame structure would be sufficient for the purpose and I think that the sum of $5,000.00 would be enough to erect it.

Very truly yours,

J.O. Flourde, O.M.I.
Ottawa, 13 September 1946.

EX'D.

Dear Father Plourde:-

We have your letter of the 7th instant with reference to the Sechelt Residential School.

We have noted your recommendation that $2,000 be included in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48 and we will also reconsider the suggestion for providing an outside gymnasium.

For your information, we may say that in the current year's appropriation, we have provided an amount of $750.00 for repairs and improvements to this school but we have not received any request from the Principal in regard to any requirements he may have.

If there are any urgent repairs required, Father Dunlop should communicate with his Indian Agent.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

With reference to your letter of the 27th ult., regarding the request of Sechelt Indian Residential School for assistance in purchasing a new sound projector, I beg to advise that the matter was again taken up with the Reverend Principal who advises as follows:

1. The School already has a film strip machine for visual education purposes.
2. The sound projector now in use and the new one required are only 16 mm. and the Reverend Principal and others on the staff are competent to operate this type of machine.
3. Repairs are not expensive and the cost of such is borne by the School.
4. Film rentals are paid for by the school.
5. The film used is non-inflammable and no fire hazard is involved.
6. A film strip machine cannot replace the much needed entertainment value of a sound projector for a school so isolated as is Sechelt, where there is nothing to relieve the monotony. Climatic conditions allow for no variety in summer and winter sports, and there are no picture shows in the vicinity. The children have been given a show every two weeks and the films shown are selected for both educational and entertainment value.

If a grant of $150.00 could be obtained from the Branch, the School will provide the remainder needed after a trade-in has been arranged.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

With reference to Agency Estimates 1946-47 and to provision therein for buildings and repairs for Sechelt Indian Residential School, I would ask to be advised if funds are available to provide for any of the following, listed in order of preference:

1. Repairs to kitchen ceiling, badly damaged by leaking roof. $90.00.
2. Shingle repairs and staining for roof of barn. $190.00.
3. New roof, foundation and walls for woodshed, now used for coal storage. $250.00.
4. Replacing derelict fencing around School grounds. $650.00.
5. Re-fitting and caulking of all window frames to prevent present draughts and loss of heat. $650.00.
6. Renewal of plumbing supply lines and fixtures, over 20 years old. $1000.00.

The sum of $12,000.00 was also inserted to provide a new gymnasium, which has long been recommended by school inspectors and other officials as a definite necessity. Unless the total amount required is available at one time, I would not recommend that any portion of the funds available for any of the above listed purposes be diverted towards the cost of the gymnasium.

Memorandum
To The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From The School Inspector

Re: Sports Equipment for the Sechelt Residential School

Facilities for recreation at the Sechelt Indian Residential School are very limited. The majority of sports are held out of doors with the exception of a limited amount of basketball which is played in a very unsuitable gymnasium located in the top half of the school barn. It is not possible to play games in this auditorium and at the same time have the pupils watch the progress of the game.

In order to occupy the time of the pupils it is necessary to provide them with equipment which may be used outside. The school has laid out a badminton court in the grounds and has space which can be used for lacrosse if they are supplied with the necessary equipment. It would seem that the amount of time that the pupils could devote to badminton on an outside court with the amount of wind that prevails at Sechelt would be very limited and if the Department considers that the requisition should be reduced it is recommended that the badminton supplies be deleted from the list.

Regarding the request for lacrosse sticks, these are more practical than the badminton equipment as the wind will not affect the playing of this game as it would in the case of badminton and it is believed that this sport would assist greatly in providing recreational activities which are needed at this school.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools.

Ottawa, Ont.

SECHELT BOARDING SCHOOL.

The needs brought to my attention this summer during my visit are as follows:

1. 25 School desks.
2. Chapel pews.
3. Electric light for the Sisters' quarters.
4. Barn.
5. Root cellar.

I understand that the root cellar would be situated where the old building is now, immediately behind the new structure. Over it could be placed rooms for one or two lay Brothers, or hired help.

The water supply is adequate for the time being. The villagers, who use the same system, may urge for a greater quantity of water, but this is a selfish reason. A hydrant for fire purposes might be supplied. I spoke to Mr. Ditchburn regarding supplying a typewriter for the school, from the D. S. C. R. surplus.

The Sisters complain of the differentiation between boarding and industrial schools, and I am of the opinion that the whole matter of category should be inquired into. Perhaps a new classification could be made on the bases of farm and garden facilities and transportation costs.
