Reference yours of June 10th, regarding funds allotted in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements to the Sechelt Indian Residential School, I note that the sum of $1103.65 is available after deducting $396.35 ear-marked for plumbing, and boiler repairs. Authority is requested to expend this balance as follows:

1. Labour and material for cupboards in kitchen, store-room, scullery and sewing room. Contract price of Mr. H. Hoard $875.00. There is a great scarcity of cupboard space which seriously affects the efficient operating of the school's internal economy. In the sewing room, articles are piled upon open shelves, and there are no facilities in the kitchen, scullery, and store room, for storage of food supplies.

2. Electric food chopper - $225.00. This will eliminate much repetitive labour and will aid sanitary preparation of food. Where 300 meals are served daily, a machine is necessary, taking some of the drudgery out of kitchen work, and rendering it more attractive to the girl pupils assigned to such work. There is no housekeeping education in daily manual recurring tasks in kitchen work, and efficient administration is greatly enhanced with power equipment.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 167-18-5 (WT1)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of June 2nd advising that $1,500 have been provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, it is noted that $96.35 has already been spent for re-tubing boiler No. 44069 and an amount of $300 has been authorized for plumbing at the school, which will reduce the amount available to approximately $1,100.

Mr. Indian Agent Taylor, reference his letter of June 24th, has now requested authority for an expenditure of $875.00 for labour and material for the construction of cupboards, and $225 for the purchase of an electric food chopper which, if approved, will exhaust the funds provided. In addition to these expenditures application has been made for authority to purchase fire hose and fire reel at a cost of $450, reference Mr. Neary's letter of June 23rd. I understand from Mr. Taylor that the Rev. Principal would prefer that if the cost of the firehose and reel can only be met from the amount appropriated for the school the matter be dropped this year and priority given to the construction of cupboards and the purchase of an electric food chopper. I am unable to agree with the Rev. Principal in this respect as it seems that fire protection should receive first priority. It has occurred to me, however, that approval may not be given to the purchase of the food chopper as I understand it is against the policy of the Department to provide such equipment in which case the cost could be applied toward the purchase of a fire hose and possibly the Department may be able to make up the difference. I would therefore recommend that:

(1) An expenditure of $875.00 be approved for the construction of cupboards.
That arrangements be made to purchase the fire hose and reel. In this connection I am enclosing quotations received from Gordon Belyea Ltd., covering the supply of fire hose reel at a cost of $125.32; Marshall-Wellis B.C. Ltd., covering the supply of fire hose at a cost of $168.20; and McLennan, McFelly and Prior Ltd., covering the supply of ten fire extinguishers, 5-gallon, hand pump style, at a cost of $139.50.

I am prepared to ask the Rev. Principal to provide a sample hose coupling but it is thought that the following information with respect to the couplings should enable the wholesalers to identify the type:

(a) The couplings for 1½" hose are 1½" standard pipe thread.

(b) The couplings for the 2½" hose have an outside diameter of 2 15/16" with eight threads to the inch.

I should like to suggest that the supply of an electric food chopper be given favourable consideration once funds can be provided for the purpose.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Mr. Taylor: Re. Fire Escape - workshop.

Upon recommendation by Mr. Coleman in September 1944 a ladder was placed by the window at the rear of the manual training shop. Later a storage for the oil drums was built by the side of the garage. As the garage roof is only a couple of feet below the rear window of the manual training shop, the construction of storage for the oil drums made a fairly easy means of escape from the manual training shop proper. Because this new means of escape seemed adequate to us and because one of the young men from the village was discovered in the act of entering the shop during the summer holidays obviously for reasons of theft, the ladder was taken down.

However, upon receipt of your letter, June 25th, a landing has been built beneath one of the windows with an easy means of descent from same.

Yours truly,

"H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I."

Authority is requested for an expenditure of $75.00 for cleaning out of the septic tank at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and cleaning and replacement of the open-joint tiling therefrom.

I am advised by the School Principal that the cost of cleaning will be $35.00 but that the present amount of tiling does not conform with the requirements of the Provincial Health Department.

I cannot secure a definite price on cleaning and augmenting the present tiling as, until it is inspected and removed, after the tank is cleaned, it is not known just what is required.

The above amount should take care of needs.

I inspected the tank last year and found it badly in need of attention. The disagreeable odour emanating has been a source of complaint from passers-by and the condition should undoubtedly be remedied without undue delay.

Dear Mr. Taylor:

Now that building materials and labour are again available, may I suggest that you bring to the attention of the Department the following very necessary undertakings in connection with the school:

Our first and greatest need is a gymnasium for the school. That a gymnasium should be placed at the top of the list should not be surprising to one familiar with the weather conditions of coastal B. C., and far less surprising to one familiar with the construction of this school. The architect who constructed this building was either unaware of the need young bodies have for exercise, or, was labouring under the delusion that all future pupils would be invalids. The result was that two very small and poorly ventilated rooms were set aside for recreational purposes. No games involving running can be undertaken in these small rooms. We must therefore depend entirely on outdoor sports for healthful recreation.

The rainfall in Vancouver district averages 50" per annum. Practically this whole amount falls between the month of November and the month of April. Sometimes there are long periods when it is impossible to undertake games outdoors. Picture, then, a group of active boys and girls penned up in small recreation rooms for days on end. The moral and physical effect on the children need no description.

Were we able to indulge in winter sports like APR 17th 1948 and skiing, our need of a gymnasium would not be
so imperative. Here we are committed entirely to field games, weather permitting.

The gymnasium, were it built, should contain in the basement a Manual Training shop, a drying room and a machine shop. At present the above is housed in what was left of the old school. The building is a fire hazard, is virtually beyond repair and should be demolished.

I have no figures on the cost of a building approximately seventy-five feet by fifty and containing the above. It probably would be well in excess of $14,000.

Repairs to the school on a large scale should be undertaken immediately. The present building has been standing for twenty-five years. For years no money whatsoever was granted for repairs. Of late years, the average has been under $1,000. Last year when $1,500 was granted, we congratulated ourselves that at least things were moving in the right direction. A few weeks later, $400 was deducted for fire equipment! The result has been that with such paltry amounts we have been unable to make any repairs of a substantial nature and have been obliged to content ourselves with building cupboards, doing a little decorating while the building itself continues to deteriorate.

For example, the brick on the weather side of the school should have been waterproofed years ago. Because money was not granted for this purpose it is impossible for me to estimate the extent of the damage done. We know what damage has been done on the surface in the way of rotted baseboard, destroyed plaster and decoration. Just what has taken place underneath I do not know. This seepage of water through the brick has been greatly facilitated by the fact that drain pipes are completely rotted away and have been for years. For renewal of drain pipes and waterproofing of walls a grant, certainly, of $4,000 would be necessary.

The plumbing throughout the entire building needs replacing. It has been installed for twenty-five years and because our water supply is not filtered it is almost completely blocked. There is little or no pressure on the third

I enclose a copy of a letter received from the Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School and I concur fully in his observations regarding the inadequacy of funds provided annually to maintain this government-owned building in repair.

The continual deterioration will eventually result in a major expenditure being necessary.

A reasonable percentage of the estimated value of the building must be made available annually if the pupils are to be maintained in a condition in accordance with health and welfare requirements.

I sense great discouragement and a feeling of frustration on the part of the Principal and staff in having to carry on their most estimable work under such adverse conditions.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In all the years I have been at Sechelt I have never written a letter of criticism to the Department. Since I have shown considerable restraint in this regard I trust that this letter will be given very serious consideration. I am writing because I feel that the accumulated actions and decisions of the Department in the past seem to indicate a policy of discrimination toward this school, and an attitude toward me, its Principal, which is belittling if not outright insulting.

It seems logical that if the Department feels a man is competent and capable of running one of their schools, the Department should put some trust in his judgments, at least in small matters. On the other hand, if the Department judges a man to be unworthy of trust the Department should obviously ask for his resignation. The Department has followed neither of these courses but continues to make decisions in the most minute matters in opposition to wishes of the Principal and the Agent whose advice is sought in all matters relating to the school. The implication is that the Department regards the Principal as though he possessed
no more intelligence than that of a school boy. I want you to know that I resent this type of treatment most vehemently.

To quote an example from among many, this year we were granted $250. for equipment. I requested among other things that out of this sum one electric motor be provided for the manual training shop. The motor was to cost $45. As my duties as Principal require my presence in the school twenty four hours daily, I feel, that at least geographically, I am in a better position to state what things are most useful in the school than one, let us say, who lives 3000 miles away, and has never even seen the inside of the school! Yet, this request was flatly refused although this motor was to be used for the operation of equipment already supplied by the Department. What utter nonsense is this!!

Again this year we were granted $2000 for plumbing. When the contractors were called in to look over the work it was found that a complete job would require almost double the amount. It was therefore unwise to proceed with this work. As the Department absolutely refused to build a gymnasium for the school I looked into the question of converting the barn, not in use, into a gym and found that a good job could be made of it for approximately $1800. I then discussed the proposition with Mr. Arneil and Mr. Taylor. These men are well acquainted with conditions pertinent to this school. Mr. Arneil has already spent two days here, while Mr. Taylor visits the school regularly many times each year. Both these men were keenly in favor of the proposition. At this time of writing
the requisite permission is still being withheld while the proposition is still being suspiciously examined as though it were the brain child of a moronic mind instead of the joint proposition of three men whom you should be able to trust. In the meantime the fall rains have set in and the children are denied the pleasure and healthful recreation of a good gym floor.

This is the kind of treatment that gives one a feeling of utter frustration in work of this nature. And the above are by no means to be considered as isolated cases. It is the kind of treatment that makes one wonder just what kind of men the Department is looking for. It is most assuredly the kind of treat that I deeply resent. This tightfisted policy of the Department in making grants for the upkeep of the place which are entirely inadequate and then quibbling for months over the expenditure of same is most stultifying to a man's initiative, and would cause a man not obligated in other ways to resign.

As regards discrimination, why was this school given an increase, retroactive to March quarter mind you, of only $300 when at least one other school more favorably situated than this one received double the amount per child? Why is the per capita grant for this school so much lower than other schools whose water freight rates are very little higher than our own and who like us are not in a farming district and have little or nor gardening
facilities? Surely, you have not based the increase on the auditors report, which even the Auditors themselves agree cannot begin to give a true picture of conditions.

If this school kept out of the red during the past year it was largely due to the fact that four Oblates, working here full time, received in salaries from Jan 1947 to Jan 1948 the grand total of $1800. This works out to $35 per month for each man and this includes my salary as Principal. Surely your office boy receives doubly that amount. It would seem, then, for the crime of making the school books balance at considerable expense to the Oblate Fathers we have been penalized.

I am asking, therefore, that compensation be made for the Department's failure to grant this school a reasonable increase in the per capita grant. And secondly, that our requests be treated with understanding and respect. We are not morons, despite all evidence to the contrary, and we are not, believe me sir, trying to fleece the Department.

Yours truly,

H. F. Dunlop,
Principal.
Dear Father Dunlop:

We have your letter of the 4th instant with reference to the Sechelt Residential School.

No doubt you have already been advised by Mr. Arneil that the Department is prepared to allow an amount of $2150 towards the cost of converting the barn so that it can be used as a gymnasium.

The electric motor was not authorized due to the fact that we do not consider favourably the use of power tools for manual training shops at Indian Residential Schools.

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50, it is hoped to provide funds to repair the plumbing.

I can assure you that we do not feel towards you the way that you think we do but we have many difficulties as well as yourself and we are endeavouring to treat all the schools as fairly as funds permit.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

Rev. H.F. Dunlop, O.M.I.,
Principal,

June 16, 1949

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Div.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, ONTARIO.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

On April the 30th I sent a bill to the Department to the amount of $114.98, which amount represented the cost of transporting the children to Vancouver for tonsillectomies. To date, I have not received a refund. Could you please find time to look into the matter.

I discovered accidently that the Department makes a small grant for children resident in the schools who are attending the local High School. I feel it is rather unfair of the Department not to notify us of these extras. However, I would like to know if it will be possible for me to collect for the children who were attending the local High School last year as well as for those who are attending this year.

Mr. Hargreaves inspected the plumbing last week. He is totally in agreement with the recommendation I made to you that all existing plumbing be replaced. It is most important that something be done this year. We cannot face another year with the plumbing in such a deplorable state.

As you know, nothing has been done in the way of repairs since 1939 when the roofing was renewed. It is true that we have
received small amounts for repairs, but these grants have never been sufficiently large to undertake the essential repairs.

This building is owned by the Department and I suppose it is no concern of mine if the Department wishes to see it go to pieces. Nevertheless it is very disheartening to watch a good building disintegrating. Frankly, that is what is happening here. During storms blowing in from the South East I have seen water actually running down the walls on the inside. I do not need to mention what damage this is doing to plaster, woodwork and decorations. There is also question of the tower which is rusted right through. One day it will fall down and I hope it will not do as much damage as I anticipate it will do.

The above are some of the essential repairs to be done and which cannot be undertaken with the size of grants we have been receiving. However, plumbing is still our first consideration. I have mentioned the other repairs simply to impress upon you the necessity of getting something done this year.

Yours truly,

H. F. Dunlop, O.M.I.
Principal.

MEMORANDUM

Res: Sekhelt Indian Residential School,
Sekhelt, British Columbia.

Ottawa, July 6, 1949.

On the occasion of his recent inspection trip to schools in British Columbia and Alberta, our Mr. Hargreaves visited the above in accordance with a request made by Major MacKay, and the following report is submitted for your information and transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch.

The school was built in 1923 and is in a fairly good state of repair. The main source of trouble in this institute is caused by the domestic hot and cold water distribution system together with inadequate storage and heater capacity.

Cold water is brought into the school from a property main in the village which is fed from an elevated tank, which in turn is supplied from a dam; both tank and dam owned and operated by the Union Steamship Company, of Vancouver, B.C.

A two inch cold water line enters the school in the girls toilet section of the basement and the two inch continues and is connected to a system of standpipes for fire protection. From this line in the basement a 1½ inch connection is taken off for distribution to the domestic requirements. Both the hot and cold domestic hot water lines are greatly undersized and what is more, they are badly clogged with deposits of fine silt.

No means of straining silt out of the main entering the school was provided and this has resulted in the blockages throughout the system and has also been the indirect cause of burning out jacket heaters. The fire line has about 70 to 75 lbs. pressure at the point of entry to the building and a hose test did not indicate blockage in the standpipes. Since the standpipes are all two inch and the pressure is constant, any silt is rapidly blown out of the hose when put to use. Also these standpipes are not used except on rare occasions so that additional silt is not brought into these lines.

The faucets on all the fixtures are in a bad state of repair and are of poor quality and design. Higher than normal water pressures, the lack of air chambers or a pressure reducing valve, together with quantities of silt have combined to ruin these faucets over a period of time. It would be cheaper to install new faucets throughout than to attempt repairs.

The domestic hot water tank has a capacity of approximately 250 Imperial gallons of water and it is now being served by a broken down burnt out and vastly undersized jacket heater.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
The heating system though of a more or less obsolete design works fairly well. It is a two pipe gravity vapour system without traps at the ends of the mains and on account of this building being smaller than an average residential school, its operation has been more or less satisfactory in the past. The system is served by two square sectional cast iron low pressure steam boilers rated at 31 horsepower each. One of these boilers is stoker fired and the other one is seldom used.

The stoker was bought second hand by the school authorities and appears to be in fairly good operating condition as far as could be determined. There are no controls and as a result, the stoker is started and stopped manually, which is not a desirable method. In addition, the pressure gauge on the boiler is broken, and there is no means of knowing when a dangerous level has been reached. The safety valve on the boiler could be expected to release at about 10 lbs but in the meantime if such a pressure was reached on this heating system, it could result in damage to the radiators and the piping before the boiler safety valve would pop. Since the fireman exercises great care to make sure that excessive pressures are not reached, there is a tendency to operate the system at very low or atmospheric pressures which results in the farthest rooms being cold part of the time.

While the principal did not specifically complain about the heating system, it is felt that the pressure gauge on the boiler must be replaced and essential controls installed, so that the stoker may be safely operated and better efficiencies obtained.

The domestic hot and cold water piping is in such a bad state that it must be replaced in its entirety. No patch work job could be made to improve the condition.

It is therefore recommended that in order to correct the mechanical services in this school, the following operations should be carried out as soon as possible,

(a) Provide new faucets on all basin sinks and slop sinks throughout the building.

(b) Remove all existing hot and cold water piping and replace with new and properly sizes lines.

(c) Provide suitable strainer of a type easily cleaned and locate same at point of entry inside the building.

(d) Provide and install new domestic hot water storage tank of approximately 800 gallon capacity together with indirect steam fed heater and self contained regulating valve.

(e) Provide at point of entry on cold water lines to fixtures, pressure gauge and pressure regulating valve to reduce water pressures to a maximum of 50 lbs. per square inch, which will give protection to the fixtures and faucets.

(f) Remove existing boiler return trap and replace with suitable condensation pump.

(g) Provide float and thermostatic traps at ends of steam mains and branch mains.
If funds are available three additional W.C. should be installed in the girls toilet in the basement and two new W.C. on the boys side. The present facilities are below the number required for the personnel.

Until the detailed layout can be prepared, it cannot be accurately estimated what this work will cost, but it may be safely estimated that a sum of about $7,000.00 would be required.

When approval is given, we will proceed with the design and specifications covering the aforementioned points, as soon as possible.

Chas. H. Buck,
For Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.
Ottawa, July 13th, 1949.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, October 4, 1949.

Re: Sechelt Indian Residential School,
Sechelt, British Columbia.

With reference to Major MacKay's memorandum of October 3rd bearing your marginal comment of the 4th instant in connection with the above, you are advised as follows:

We have no objection to locating the new domestic hot water tank in the boiler room, provided that suitable wall space can be found. Our records show no means of access to the boiler room except a small door and since this door will have to be enlarged to get the tank in, it must be made large and built up in accordance with the structural detail on the contract drawings.

We do not approve of the suggestion to use an immersion type tank heater as suggested by the contractor. We have found that this type of heater is more difficult to clean and in many cases, no attempt is made to properly clean or service the element. In order to clean the element, it is necessary to empty the entire tank, an operation requiring an extra effort on the part of the operating engineer.

With the indirect heater, it is possible to withdraw this element and clean the tubes of scale without draining the tank and this has proven to be much more advantageous.

Therefore if the contractor is willing to place the tank in the boiler room at no extra expense, taking into consideration that a suitable access door will be necessary, we will approve of the change. We do not approve of changing the heater and consider that the heater specified and shown should be supplied and connected in accordance with the detail on the drawing.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In view of some of the correspondence of the former Principal of this school with the Department, especially regarding yearly estimates, it pleases me very much to be able to address my first letter to you in a satisfied and commendatory vein.

At the very moment of writing, plumbers are busy in the building remedying conditions which have long awaited attention. The work as outlined and undertaken by the Department is eminently satisfactory and our sincere thanks are due to the members of the Department who have expended time and attention to our local problems.

It is our earnest hope that the attention shown Sechelt School in the past year will not wither away and be forgotten since there is much left to be done even in a remedial way as regards material sustenance of this establishment.

I wish you could be on hand to see the rubble and hear the comments of the men who know their work and plumbing necessities, as they remove what has passed these many years for an adequate plumbing system.

Again may I say thank you in the name of the children and staff for these first steps taken to improve the material conditions at the Sechelt School.

As the estimates are being considered in the near future for the forthcoming year, I am enclosing herewith a list of the requirements towards continuing the essential repairs begun recently.

Though bearing seems to be a prerequisite accomplishment of Indian School Principals, I personally feel confident that you and other members of your staff are certainly aware of our common interests and efforts for the schools and doing your utmost to foster them.

I am looking forward to sending you a more detailed commentary on the improvements being attended to at this school when they are completed.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. L.Vindy O.M.I.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Domestic Hot and Cold Water and Heating System, Indian Residential School, Sechelt, B.C.

At the request of Mr. N.P. Robinson of this office I made a progress inspection of the alterations and revisions to the domestic hot and cold water and heating systems at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, and found the work being carried out satisfactorily and in general in accordance with the drawings supplied by the office of the Chief of this Department.

I have, therefore, signed the first progress payment form to the amount of $4,500., supplied to us by Mitchell Bros. who are doing this contract.

During my visit to the school, I noticed a few extra items outside of the present contract which I feel you should know about and I am, therefore, drawing them to your attention.

ADDITIONAL WORK SUGGESTED

1. Basement Radiators

Fourteen only basement radiators should be fitted with steam traps and, if possible, braced to the walls since they are at present hanging from the ceiling by rods and can be rocked quite easily as they are not firmly supported.

2. Plumbing - Basement

Girls Lavatory

Fire line leaking at intake valve situated here since fittings originally black iron and have rusted through. This could be repaired and would run to approximately $5.00.

Twenty-four new reclosing wash basin taps should be fitted since the present ones are practically worn out. One complete new W.C. assembly is required as bowl is broken and tank and seat damaged beyond repair.

Two W.C. seats required for other units in this room. Lavatory actually needs repainting and some plastering work done.

Boys Lavatory

Twenty-two new reclosing taps should be installed for the wash basins since the ones presently installed are worn out.

Two W.C. seats required. Lavatory needs painting and some plastering over the entrance needs repair.

Urinal flushing tank requires adjusting and new outfall pipe.
Pantry

Dish washing sink consists of two laundry tubs which have no grease traps fitted and cause drainage stoppage frequently. These tubs should actually be replaced with a proper dish washing sink since all the dishes for the school are washed here.

The main steam line which passes through this room has practically no insulation on it now since the moisture has deteriorated the insulation material. This should be fixed up.

Laundry

Three taps required for laundry tubs.

Bakery

One new tap required for sink.

3. Plumbing - Main Floor

Staff Lavatory

Wood tank for W.C. should be replaced with new unit since it is practically beyond repair.

4. Plumbing - Top Floor

Girls Bathroom

Two complete W.C. tanks required. Two W.C. seats required.

Wash basin taps in this room appear to be alright at present but it would probably be better to renew them.

Staff Lavatory

One W.C. seat required

Boys' Sick Bay

New trap for sink required.

Boys' Washroom

Two W.C. seats required. Present urinal has no flushing tank. It would be better if a 5" trough was installed with a flushing tank as the present facilities are inadequate. It would probably be advisable to fit new wash basin taps here too.

Brother Supervisor's Room

New trap required for wash basin.

5. General

Wells

Outside walls should be waterproofed

Gutters

Gutters are rusted through and leaking badly.
Electrical System

In general lighting in classrooms is poor and modifications are required to bring the system up to code. The new 12kw 230v 36 clothes dryer, delivered on September 15, is not connected yet.

"Thomas A.G. Beeching"

RE: SECHELT RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
REPAIRS TO PLUMBING, etc.

There is nothing on file to show that Sunset Hardware (Gibsons) or J. P. Veitch submitted a quotation on plumbing or repairs at the Sechelt School.

In a letter dated April 16, 1948, addressed to H. E. Trylor, Rev. Father Dunlop, Principal of Sechelt School, states that the greatest need is a gymnasium. Copy of this letter was forwarded to Mr. Arneil by Mr. H. E. Taylor, under cover of his communication of April 17, 1948. Mr. Arneil submitted this correspondence to Ottawa on April 24, 1948. Official reply dated May 1, 1948 advises Mr. Arneil that $2,150.00 was provided in Estimates for 1948-49 for repairs to plumbing and for interior decorating and an amount of $250.00 for equipment, and that this amount will be expended in any manner which Mr. Taylor and Mr. Arneil consider in the best interests of the school.

On October 16, 1948, Mr. Taylor advises Mr. Arneil that the plumbing repairs and replacements will cost considerably more than the amount provided ($2150). He advises in that letter that it would be inadvisable to do part of the work only.

In the same letter Mr. Taylor mentions the long-felt need for a recreation building. It is suggested that the school barn, (unused) be converted into a gymnasium and basketball hall. Mr. Arneil writes to the Department on October 23rd concurring in Mr. Taylor's recommendation.

On November 1, 1948, Mr. Arneil was asked to forward a requisition for the material required and he was advised that the total amount the Department would supply for material and labour was $4,150.

In memorandum to Lands & Development Services, dated 23 February, 1949, they were requested to have one of their engineers, who, it was understood, would be visiting Western Canada, to go to the Sechelt School.

As you know, Mitchell Brothers' tender was accepted and while the work was being carried out the Reverend Principal brought to their attention the condition of the basin taps, etc., and Mitchell Brothers, reference their letter of October 30th, a copy of which was forwarded to you on November 8th, quoted a price of $966.75 for replacement of the faulty plumbing on the understanding that the replacements would be installed while their men were at Sechelt in connection with the heating...
installation. Feb. 9th, 1950

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In November last you requested I write you in January to supply particulars regarding equipment I mentioned in a previous letter. I have recently obtained information (enclosed) regarding a food mixer and chopper which would suit our requirements. The meat grinder we have, made by the Osborne Co., is not adaptable by attachments. Hence a complete new machine is required.

As to the replacing of our general washing machine, which as an ancient wooden type is about to collapse, I have found that Stanley Brock Co. of Vancouver can supply an all-metal Canadian made machine, Norwood "Cascade", size 24" x 36". Such a unit could be easily installed and would match in capacity and efficiency the new tumbler dryer supplied last year through the same company.

Mitchell Bros. of Vancouver have just now completed their contract for repairs to the heating and water system. Final inspection by the Engineers Dept. was made today and except for two or three details to be cleared up the work seems satisfactory. The transformation wrought by the new installations is a great boon to us.

Incidentally, I suppose the report on the general inspection made by Mr. Beeching is confidential so I can hardly expect a copy for our files. However I do believe his inspection and report was comprehensive and factual as well as official and could serve well as a guide for any future mechanical installations or repairs to the Sechelt School. It occurs to me that there would be evident advantages to having periodic inspection of our buildings by some official of the Engineers Branch. Such men are best equipped to observe and remark on the buildings and equipment we must maintain.

In closing I must express our thanks for two other concessions made by the Department recently, namely the allotment of a heating system for our gym and the increase in our per capita grant. For your information the retroactive increase given Sechelt will just about take care of our extra fuel bill this winter. It has been a tough year but we certainly are not unthankful for even small blessings.

Should you have occasion Mr. Phelan to travel westward again this summer, we would like you to visit Sechelt officially, or better still for holiday purposes. We boldly promise you that you would have no cause to regret it despite the fact that "The Playground of the Pacific" has been anything but pacific this winter.

Yours very sincerely,

L. Viner O.M.I.

BELTED MOTOR DRIVE—Shall consist of hooks for holding the cylinder door open, tub door interlock, covered drive shaft, fully enclosed gear guard and fully enclosed belt guards.

Accuracy of illustrations and description of equipment shown herein applies to product as manufactured at time of publication. Printed in U.S.A.
Machine shall be constructed with such characteristics and shall be equipped with such accessories as specified in our letter of proposal, to which this specification is attached, and as described below.

CYLINDER — Shall have heads, staves, and ribs of selected, long leaf yellow pine.

Staves and lifting ribs shall be rabbeted at heads. Staves shall be secured to the heads by screws.

Heads shall be gained to receive the three lifting ribs.

The above shall be cut from stock as follows:

| Diameter of Cylinder | 30 | 36 | 40 |
|----------------------|----|----|----|
| Heads                | 2  | 3  | 3  |
| Staves               | 1½ | 1½ | 1½ |

An upper and lower driving tub door, equipped with a supply door, shall operate in guides provided on adjustable, encircling hoops, fitted with take-up bolts.

A water-level gauge shall be suitably fitted into left end of tub to indicate the height of the liquid in the cylinder.

A metal splash apron shall be provided at bottom of door opening to protect the staves.

FRAMES — Shall be cast iron of one-piece, heavy construction, equally bolting to tub heads, and shall support weight of the cylinder, tub, and driving mechanism. Also see Belted Motor Drive.

BEARINGS — Journals of cylinder trunnions shall operate in solid-bored cast-iron bearings supported by the frame and equipped with easily-accessible lubricators.

GEARS — Shall be made from precision solid blanks and covered with a narrow, rounded gear guard.

Cylinder-drive gears shall be furnished at right end of machine only; except on 30-inch diameter with elevated header, double drive shall be furnished where ordered.

On 30-inch diameter, 30 and 36-inch lengths, main gear shall be of solid-hub type; on all other sizes main gear shall be of split type. All main gears shall be keyed to transmission.

WATER INLET — 2-inch water inlet-connection shall be provided at rear of tub; lengths over 54 inches shall have two inlets connected by a manifold.

OUTLET VALVE — Shall be of the foot-operated, positive-closing, self-cleaning type, 4 inches in diameter on the 30, 6 inches on the 36 and 40-inch diameter machines.

GEAR LOCK — A gear-lock, for locking cylinder in stationary position while the washer is being loaded or unloaded, shall be provided.

INCHING DEVICE — On 36 and 40-inch diameters, gear lock shall be combined with a handwheel on worn-gear shaft for bringing the cylinder door into alignment with the tub door.

Major Mackay, Director,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship and Immigration
Booth Building,
Ottawa.

Dear Major Mackay -

I wish to bring to your attention two matters for your kind consideration, the first concerns the Sechelt Indian Residential School and the second the projected building at Williams Lake.

1) SECHELT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL - In conformity with the wishes of your Department and of ourselves, the Mother Provincial of the Sisters who teach at the Lejac, Williams Lake and Sechelt Indian Residential Schools plans to send some of her Sisters to Normal School this year so that they will be fully qualified to take up their work again in these respective schools in September 1952. This is a move long desired both by yourselves and by us. The Principal of the School at Sechelt is most anxious, as are all our School Principals, to co-operate with the Mother Provincial in this plan but it brings up a problem of replacements by Lay-teachers which can be solved I hope, with the co-operation of the Department. The plan is to withdraw Sister Antoinette and send her to Normal School but the Provincial has no Sister to replace her. Consequently it will mean the hiring of another Lay-teacher. I will now quote for you from a letter written by the Principal, Rev. Father Viney and dated June 28th. "Therefore, dear Father Provincial, I must employ one teacher to replace Miss Janestin who intends to remain at home in Saskatchewan next year and this will require a higher salary, ($1050.00 last year), perhaps $1500.00 for a qualified teacher this year. Our light or electricity, water and fuel costs have increased a lot along with smaller increases and so we face running in the red as well as not being able to improve staff and general resulting conditions of the School for another year. Do you think that through Major Mackay or Col. Neary you could get one or two of our teachers on the Ottawa payroll directly? Otherwise shortage of staff keeps having its effect and we face the possibility of not being able to pay our bills or of paying salaries."

Therefore dear Major Mackay, I ask you to give the payment of these two Lay-teachers at Sechelt your very kind and serious consideration. You know how much confidence I have in you and I am certain a priori that you will do your utmost to help us solve this situation.

2) RE CONSTRUCTION AT WILLIAMS LAKE - B.C. - It is with a very heavy heart indeed that I note that nothing concrete has been done yet with regard to the construction at Williams Lake and I am very upset indeed at the thought that another winter will have to be passed
under the conditions that have endured for so long. Furthermore I am very upset by a passage in the letter from Father Viney reporting on the teacher question, in which he quotes a statement of Sister M. Dorothy, the above-mentioned Provincial, - "That conditions at Williams Lake have been exceptionally hard this year and she would welcome the closing of that School thus releasing four Sisters to be sent to Normal School." We, the Oblate Fathers are very much opposed to the closing of the Williams Lake School even for a period of one year, and I must say conscientiously that we could not allow it to be done without protest on our part. To close a School of that kind for a period of one year would be to set back the work of education in that territory for a period of at least ten years. I am sure that you and Colonel Neary with your experience in Indian education realize the truth of my statement.

I know that your Department as such is not to blame for the undue delay in the construction of the unit at Williams Lake, but I must say that the lack of action is a cause both of very keen disappointment and alarming discontent. May I therefore ask you, dear Major Mackay, to use the influence which your position affords, to investigate the cause of this delay at Williams Lake and to do whatever lies within your power to see that the actual work of construction is begun within the very near future so that the outside work will be completed by the time the Caribou Winter comes. I feel that in addressing myself to you, dear Major Mackay, and begging your help and co-operation in this matter that I am appealing to one who is very sympathetic and who understands the terrible conditions up there. You know what splendid ammunition this delay would make to enemies of the Department and the present regime. I beg to assure you that I am not in any sense laying any of the blame at your door, dear Major Mackay; on the contrary I know that you must be as keenly disappointed as we are. I am taking the liberty of speaking to Colonel Fortier the Deputy Minister regarding this matter within a day or so. Perhaps he can get some action.

Trusting that you had an enjoyable holiday and that you are enjoying good health and that the Lord will keep you with the Department for many years to come, I am, dear Major Mackay,

Yours very sincerely

(Very Rev.) JOSEPH R. BIRCH O.M.I.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your voucher No. 7019, for $35.30, covering the cost of transportation of pupils of the Sechelt Indian Residential School going home on holidays.

As the individual charges for pupils are comparatively small, the Department presumes that the children live close to the school. Under these circumstances, we cannot understand why arrangements were not made with the Indian parents to come for their children and save any expense, either to the Department or the school management. In connection with travelling expenses of children at this school, I would refer you to official letter of July 5, 1933. I would also point out that no authority has been given since the first of the fiscal year for travelling expenses at the Sechelt School. Under the above circumstances, the account is not being paid at the present time, but, when your reply to this letter is received, stating the necessity for incurring this expenditure, the matter will receive further consideration.

Our funds are so limited, that it is only possible to consider payment of expenditure that has been previously authorized.

Your obedient servant,

Philip Phelan,
for Supt. of Indian Education.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
203-6 Rogers Building,
Vancouver, B. C.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo regarding Voucher No.7019 for $35.50 for transportation of Sechelt school children.

I must admit that I have no very clear understanding about this matter. About three years ago I refused to send in a voucher for the Reverend Principal, and he took up the matter with you and it was paid and he claimed that the Department advised him then that such expenses would be paid for children going home for the summer vacation.

The Reverend Principal, Father E.Maillard, is in France and not expected back until the late Fall so I am unable to consult him or find out whether he has any authority on file.

Many parents of the Sechelt School children call for them on their way to the fishing grounds but others claim they have no money to pay fares. I do not think the Reverend Principal has made any strenuous effort to collect the fares from the parents and I feel quite sure that if he advised them the children would be kept at school until sent for, they would all either fetch them or send their fares. They all manage to pay the fares when the pupils return to school after the vacation.

Personally I consider it should be paid by the school out of their grant. The Reverend Principal has never asked for authority to incur this expense, and if payment of the account is definitely refused, both to this and other schools, I have no doubt the pupils would be sent home just the same.

Reverend Father Maillard said he would call upon you on his return from France and you would then have an opportunity of discussing it with him. Of course if the practice is to pay other schools, Sechelt will expect the same treatment.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

B/HM.

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, regarding the accounts which you have received from the Principal of the Sechelt Indian Residential School covering the cost of the transportation of 48 pupils to various places for their summer holidays.

In this connection I have to say that the Department expects that every effort will be made by principals and agents to have the parents provide for the transportation of their children to and from their homes for summer holidays. In cases where the parents are unable to pay the full cost, or, at least, part of the cost, the Department will favourably consider payment, but it is first expected that the Principal will inform the Department, through your office, of the number of pupils who will be granted holidays, whether or not the parents will pay the cost of their transportation, and what amount the Department will be called upon to provide. Our Appropriation for transportation expenses is limited, and we have to be careful in apportioning the amount among the various residential schools in Canada.

If you will forward a voucher, in triplicate, covering the cost of the transportation of the 48 pupils from the Sechelt School, with receipts attached for all payments, the Department will favourably consider payment of the account.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,

Sir:

I beg to report in reference to the four truants from Sechelt School, as per instructions contained in your wire of the 17th instant.

The children were missed on Wednesday evening, the 14th instant, after 6 p.m. The principal, Father Fahlman, tried to get in touch with me, but I was up coast in the launch. On Thursday morning he phoned the office, and Miss Heelas asked the Daily Province News radio news reporter to include in his 8.30 p.m. newscast a message to me to contact the School. I was some distance from Sechelt, but left at once and on arrival at Fender Harbour, the Provincial Police advised me that they had received word of the runaways and were watching for them. We kept a sharp lookout along the Squamish, but a southeast gale was blowing with heavy seas, and I hoped the boys had been too much afraid to go by canoe. There were no other launches or fishboats at sea, but I notified those tied up out of the weather to watch for the boys, and all promised their help.

Near Sechelt, the Provincial Forestry Department lent me a light delivery truck, and Constable McAllister, of the R.C.M.P., and I drove through the whole length of the road over which the boys might have passed. On Saturday afternoon I reached the School to find out further particulars. Two of the boys were from Homalco Band in the extreme northern part of the Agency; and the other two were Squamish Reserve No.1 (North Vancouver). I was surprised when I reached the school to find that although there are five men, including two priests, at the School, none was out searching for the boys. Father Fahlman said the janitor, Andrew Fahlman, had been looking around the district, but without success. I concluded that all four boys would instinctively head for the nearest Squamish Reserve, which was either Chekwelp No.26 or Kaikahlun No.25, the only way to reach the latter being by foot. By good fortune, a Provincial policeman searching for a wanted Chinaman near Kaikalahun Reserve, found the two Homalco boys, but the other two were hiding in the bush. They later boarded a tug and arrived home in North Vancouver Sunday. The weather was very wet, but not cold; they had food, and found shelter at night. Two are in school again and the other two are leaving on the Sechelt boat tomorrow (Tuesday).

I was afraid they had tried to escape by sea, which would have been fatal in a canoe, as we experienced heavy weather and had an uncomfortable trip even on a launch. We had full cooperation on every hand, and I notified roadworkers, forestry camps, truck drivers, fishermen, and police. Const. McAllister, of the R.C.M.P., who is attached to this office for duty, gave valuable assistance; we searched day and night from...
the launch, by truck and on foot, but I think if the people at the School had gone out immediately the boys were missed. On Wednesday, they would have caught up with them. Of course, there was not the same danger as in the LeJac case, because the weather was not severe.

I am glad to report successful conclusion of this case, and Father Pahiman has suggested that the boys lose their summer holidays, and be kept at the School as a punishment, with which I have concurred.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

B/DH.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
On the 15th at 8.30 P.M. I received a message over the news broadcast that I was wanted at Sechelt Residential School, and left for that place arriving next day, where I found four boys had left without leave and could not be found. Two rainy days and nights were spent searching for them and the first sight of them was by a Provincial Policeman who was searching for a Chinaman. All four were eventually found and returned to school. The Provincial Forestry and Police services gave valuable assistance by lending a truck, and also in searching and Constable MacAlister, of the R.C.M.P. who accompanied me on the trip to the reserves was indefatigable also. I returned to Vancouver on Sunday the 18th.

F. J. C. Ball.

The Department has just received the December quarter return of the Sechelt Indian Residential School. I would appreciate if you would point out to the Principal the importance of forwarding quarterly returns promptly at the end of each quarter.

In preparing the returns not more than 25 names should be entered on each sheet.

The name of Louis Johnson, No. 155, was shown on the September quarter return but does not appear on the December return although no application has been received for his discharge. Please advise regarding this boy. You may inform the Principal that the Department approves the discharge of the following pupils:

William William, 160
Sydney Newman, 174
Stanley Joseph, 177
Gabriel Noel, 187
Emily Pielle, 0180

No reply has yet been received to my letter of December 1, 1937. You will note that that letter requested an application form for Donald Walker, No. 193. I understand from your letter of the 24th ultimo that application forms will be forwarded in the near future for pupils 196, 197, 0198, 0199, 0200 and 0201.

Yours truly,

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent
416 Federal Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Replying to your letter of the 2nd instant, I have advised the Principal of Sechelt Indian Residential School of the instructions contained in the first two paragraphs. I have now received a few more application forms from the School, which I enclose herewith for approval, as follows:

No.189 George D. Paul (Sechelt Band)
0196 Veronica Hackett (Homalco Band)
0198 Olive Band (Squamish Band)

The Donald Walker mentioned in your letters of December 1st 1937 and March 2nd 1938, should be Donald Baker, No.193. The parents of this boy are separated, the mother being somewhere on Vancouver Island, while the father is working off the Reserve, so that we have so far been unable to obtain their signatures. If he can be located, I will obtain his signature to an admission form, and forward it to you.

Forms covering Nos.0199 and 0200, mentioned in your last paragraph, were forwarded to you on February 28th last, and the admission form for Joe Harry, No.197, was also forwarded at that time. I have not yet been able to get the form for No.0201-Elise Wilson, as her parents are away fishing.

It would be appreciated if you would kindly advise me whether you have received forms covering No.0187-Mary Louise Williams, and No.0188-Angeline Gabriel, two children from New Westminster Agency admitted to the School in August, 1936. Sir,

Province Date
B.C. September 24th, 1938.

File References
Re: Patrol of Indian Reserves, Vancouver Agency.
Asstee., Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources.

Headquarters
1. On 20-9-38 acting on instructions, at the request of the Indian Agent, Vancouver, B.C. I left Vancouver, B.C. via Union Steamship on a patrol to Squamish, B.C. Travelling requisition No. 17/5723, to investigate a complaint that a number of Indian Children in the Squamish District had failed to return to the Residential schools at Sechelt, B.C. and North Vancouver, B.C. arrived at Squamish, B.C. in the late p.m. of the above date.

Sub-Division
2. The 21-9-38 was spent patrolling the Indian Reserves in the Squamish District, a number of the parents of the Indian Children being of school age were located, and arrangements were made for these children to be sent back to school immediately.

Detachment
3. In the a.m. of 22-9-38 Auto Livery was obtained and the Indian Reserves at Brackendale, B.C. and outlaying District were visited, the parents of the remainder of the children who had not returned to school were interviewed, and arrangements made for the return of the children to their respective schools, soon as transportation could be obtained.

P.C.R.
4. Left Squamish, B.C. in the early p.m. via Union Steamship Lady Cynthia, of 22-9-38 arriving back in Vancouver, B.C. the same evening.

Sir:

I have been requested by the Reverend E.J.Cornell, O.M.I., Principal of the Schult Residential School, to write you regarding their grant for the September quarter.

For several reasons, principally I believe on account of the continued summer weather in September this year, the attendance was considerably below normal. It has recovered to normal this term, but Father Cornell points out that his overhead expenses were almost as high in September as if the School had been full, and it has worked a hardship on the management of the School.

The grant as calculated on the Quarterly Returns would be approximately $400.00 less than they had figured upon.

If the Department will give this matter consideration, it will be appreciated by the Reverend Principal.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(F.J.G.Ball)
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to refer to our Voucher No.10598 in favour of the Union S.S.Co. for $61.10 and dated October 5th 1939. I have received a letter from the Rev.E.J.Cornell, O.M.I., Principal of Sechelt Residential School, saying the account for fares of pupils to and from school has not been paid.

I find now that Father Cornell sent me the accounts from the Union Steamship Co., but later paid the Company direct, expecting we would obtain a refund for him. As the accounts he sent us were not receipted, we naturally made out the voucher in favour of the Steamship Co. instead of the School.

The Company received a cheque on November 13th 1939 for $61.10, No. B O 40220, but Father Cornell having paid them before they received this cheque, they returned it to the Receiver General, with a covering letter saying that the account had already been paid. Presumably this cheque should now be paid to Father Cornell, and I would appreciate it if you would kindly do this.

I have the honour to be,

B/DH.

Your obedient servant,

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

Agent's report on Vancouver Agency for March 1940.

On Saturday night, the 2nd, I received an urgent phone call from Snelt Residential school that two young Indian boys had left and were heading towards Vancouver. This means crossing the sea for five miles at its narrowest, and I had no doubt they were on their way home to North Vancouver. On account of quite heavy storms, I was afraid they might get into difficulties, and commenced a search of the shore line after notifying every person who might see them, such as steamship officers, look-outs, and lighthouses, but it was not until the 7th that the Union Steamship officials found them. They had broken into a number of summer camps and had stolen a row boat, crossing to Bowen Island in calm weather at night. They were returned to school none the worse for their adventure. This incident raised a question with the school as to responsibility for truants. The school made no effort to locate them outside the reserve, as they said their responsibility ceased the moment the pupils left the school grounds. However, we have straightened out that misunderstanding.

F. J. C. Ball,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

As there has been a drastic reduction in our appropriation for the current fiscal year it is necessary that every possible effort be made to reduce expenditure. It will, therefore, be advisable to inform the Principal of the Sechelt Residential School accordingly and you should direct his special attention to the item of transportation of children. We will only be able to allow a percentage of the amount previously provided. As a result you should cooperate with the Principal in having parents take their children home and return them to the school without expense to the Department.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Sir:

I beg to advise that the Reverend Principal of Sechelt Indian Residential School has forwarded me accounts amounting to $69.65 for transportation of Indian pupils at the school.

In your letter of November 20th, 1940, File No. 167-18-10, you advised me that authority should be obtained each year for this expense. Father McGrath has not been at the School very long, and, although I wrote him on November 25th 1940 advising him of the contents of your letter, it was evidently overlooked that authority should be obtained.

Last year an amount of $50.00 was granted, and I respectfully recommend that if possible the school receive the same consideration this year.

May I add that the school has never been operated so successfully in the past as it has under Father McGrath and this is remarkably reflected in the attitude of both the pupils and parents to the School. When one remembers the troubles and trials which occurred there in the past, I am thankful that Father McGrath and his staff have completely changed that situation. I believe it is due to two things, viz., the food, and the keen interest of the pupils in the many efforts made to keep them occupied out of school hours. Sports are well organized and necessary work is not made laborious. The cheerfulness of the children speaks highly of their well-being.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to report that Mrs. Joe T. Wilson, No. 37 of the Homalco Band, called at Sechelt Indian Residential School on Friday last and demanded that her daughter Mary, aged 12, be allowed to return home to Homalco Reserve. There is no reason for the girl to leave school and the Reverend Principal refused to allow her to leave until the end of the term.

On the 27th, the Principal received a telephone call from Mr. T.T. Taylor, barrister, etc. of Powell River, demanding that the girl be sent home, and upon refusing, Mr. Taylor advised the Reverend Principal that he "would take proceedings to compel him". Reverend McGrath telephoned me asking what should be done, and I advised him to keep the girl in school.

I have reported several times on the activities of this lawyer, and most of the trouble at Sliammon Reserve is caused by his success in obtaining the dismissal of Indians on technical grounds when they are brought before the local Courts. If he is permitted to dictate to our Schools also we shall have a steady procession of pupils being taken out on various pretences.

I do not quite understand what legal points are involved in such a matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to Mary Wilson, pupil No. 0220 of the Sechelt Indian Residential School.

The application for the admission of this girl was forwarded to the Department under cover of your letter of December 21, 1939. The application was signed by the mother and reads:

"I hereby make application for the admission of the under-mentioned child to the Sechelt Residential School to remain therein under the guardianship of the Principal for such term as the Minister of Mines & Resources may deem proper."

The Department has always taken the stand that once a child is properly admitted to a school, as was the case in regard to this girl, we can hold such pupil until the age stated in the Indian Act.

However, if the mother is insistent on obtaining her discharge she is likely going to cause the Principal considerable inconvenience. Possibly you should get in touch with Indian Agent Daunt with a view to ascertaining the home conditions of the mother and, if the latter is in a position to support the child and send her regularly to the day school on the Homalco Reserve, it might be well to apply for her discharge at the end of June.
